(3)	Computer hardware; 
(4)	Computer software; 
(5)	Imaging systems; 
(6)	Electronic kiosks; 
(7)	Electronic ticket writers; or 
(8)	Docket management systems. 
(b)	The fund shall be administered by or under the direction of the city commission. 
(Code 1996, § 8.1203; Ord. No. 99-06, 9-26-1999)  
Chapter 6 - ANIMAL CONTROL[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Treatment of animals, Texas Health and Safety Code § 821.001 et seq.; dangerous dogs generally, Texas Health and Safety Code § 822.001 et seq.; Rabies Control Act, Texas Health and Safety Code § 826.001 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 6-1. - Keeping of poultry, fowl, and rabbits. 
(a)	Whatever is dangerous to human health, whatever renders the ground, water, air or food a hazard or injury to human health, and the following specific acts, conditions and things, are, each and all of them, declared to constitute nuisances: 
(1)	The keeping, harboring, maintaining or permitting the presence of any poultry or fowls exceeding 12 in number, or rabbits exceeding two in number on any one lot or parcel of land in an unsanitary condition. 
(2)	The keeping of any poultry, fowls or rabbits within any structure in the city, without scraping the floors of such room, coop, box or compartment and thoroughly cleaning the area within which such fowls, poultry or rabbits are kept at least once in every 24 hours and so maintaining such structure and enclosure that no odors are emitted therefrom. 
(3)	The keeping of any chickens, fowls or rabbits within any structure, the interior of which is not whitewashed at least once every six months and/or without spraying an effective disinfectant on the roosting places at least once in each calendar month and/or keeping same covered with deep dry litter to discourage insects, fleas, mites, and flies. 
(4)	Permitting garbage, trash, rubbish, offals, tin cans, decaying animal or vegetable matter, decayed fruits, or other refuse matter to be on any property in this city except when same is deposited within a trash can or other receptacle with a close fitting top thereon placed within easy reach of but not in any alley or street for immediate removal. 
(5)	The deposit of garbage in anything but fly-proof, water-tight receptacles. 
(6)	The disposal of accumulation of any fowl, decaying or putrescent substance of other offensive material dangerous to public health, in or upon any lot, street or highway, or the escape of any gases to such extent that the same or any of them shall be reason of offensive odors, become a source of discomfort to persons living or passing in the vicinity. 
(b)	If any person, within the limits of the city, shall permit or suffer any of the nuisances described in subsection (a) of this section on premises occupied by him or under his control, any police officer or the animal control officer shall order the owner or occupant thereof to remove and abate such nuisance at his expense within a time not to exceed 24 hours. The said order shall be sufficient, if delivered orally to such owner or occupant or to his representative if such owner or occupant cannot then be found within the city or said order may be in writing. When such order is written, it shall be served by a police officer of sanitary inspector by delivering a copy thereof to the owner, occupant or agent of such property. If the owner or agent of the property is unknown or absent, with no known representative or agent, upon whom the notice can be served, then the police officer or sanitary inspector shall post a written or printed notice upon the property or premises setting forth that unless the nuisance is removed or abated within 24 hours, at the expense of the owner or occupant, the nuisance will be abated at the expense of the owner. 
(c)	All poultry, fowls or rabbits removed to abate a nuisance shall be impounded at the city pound. 
(1)	If, within 48 hours after any poultry, fowls or rabbits have been impounded, the owner thereof pays the cost of abating such nuisance and agrees that upon the return of such poultry, fowls or rabbits, as has been removed from his property, he will forthwith dispose of such poultry, fowls or rabbits in a manner which does not violate any ordinance of this city such poultry, fowls or rabbits shall be released to its owner at the city pound. 
(2)	If the owner of poultry, fowls or rabbits so impounded shall fail, neglect or refuse to call at the city pound within 48 hours after the impounding of such poultry, fowls or rabbits or to pay the cost of abating such nuisance and agree to dispose of such poultry, fowls or rabbits in a manner which does not violate any ordinance of this city, the sanitary inspector shall sell the poultry, fowls or rabbits to a poultry dealer and immediately turn the proceeds over to the city auditor, who will credit the amount against the cost of abating the nuisance and pay over the excess, if any, to the owner of such poultry, fowls or rabbits. 
(d)	The term "poultry or fowls," as used in this chapter, means chickens, turkeys, guineas, ducks and geese. 
(e)	There shall be no poultry, fowls or rabbits kept, harbored, maintained or raised within 200 feet of any residence within the city limits. 
(f)	Any person who violates any of the provisions of this chapter not otherwise provided for shall, upon conviction, be fined in accordance with the general penalty provision found in section 1-6. Each day shall be considered and constitute a separate violation. 
(Code 1975, § 2-5; Code 1996, art. 2.400)  
Sec. 6-2. - Humane society agreement. 
The mayor is hereby authorized to enter into such agreements as he deems necessary with the nonprofit Houston Humane Society to care for and, when he deems necessary, to euthanize, all stray or abandoned animals found in the city. 
(Code 1996, art. 2.500; Ord. of 7-21-1992; Ord. No. 2016-03A, 8-16-2016)  
Sec. 6-3. - Dangerous dogs. 
(a)	As used in this chapter, the term "dangerous dog" means a dog that makes an unprovoked attack on a person that causes bodily injury and occurs in a place other than an enclosure in which the dog was being kept and that was reasonably certain to prevent the dog from leaving the enclosure on its own; or commits unprovoked acts in a place other than an enclosure in which the dog was being kept and that was reasonably certain to prevent the dog from leaving the enclosure on its own and those acts cause a person to reasonably believe that the dog will attack and cause bodily injury to that person. 
(b)	It shall be unlawful and an offense for any person to keep, harbor, or maintain a dangerous dog within the city limits. 
(c)	Whether a dog is dangerous shall be determined as provided in Chapter 822 of the Texas Health and Safety Code (Texas Health and Safety Code § 822.041 et seq.). 
(Code 1996, art. 2.700) 
State Law reference— Authority of municipality to regulate dangerous dogs, Texas Health and Safety Code § 822.041 et seq.  
Sec. 6-4. - To run at large, defined. 
As used in this chapter, the term "to run at large" means to go free or be free on private or public property outside of secure enclosure and without leash securely attached to the dog or cat and without such leash being held by a person of competent strength to hold and control said animal, or without such leash being securely fastened in a manner to cause such animal to be unable to leave the property under the control or in the use of the owner or harborer of such animal. 
(Code 1975, § 2-1; Code 1996, § 2.111)  
Secs. 6-5—6-26. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - LICENSING OF DOGS AND CATS AND CONTROL OF RABIES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Authority of municipalities to establish rabies control programs, Texas Health and Safety Code § 826.015. 
 
Sec. 6-27. - License and fee. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to own, keep, or have in his possession any dog or cat, over four months of age, within the corporate limits of the city, unless a license fee for said dog or cat has been paid for the current year. On or before February 1 of each year, each person owning, keeping or having in his possession any dog or cat shall pay an annual license fee, as provided for in the fee schedule, on each dog or cat, which license shall be effective for the ensuing calendar year. 
(Code 1996, § 2.101)  
Sec. 6-28. - Vaccination. 
Before any license is issued for any dog or cat, the owner or person applying for the license shall present to the city secretary a certificate from a licensed veterinarian stating that said dog or cat has been vaccinated against rabies, within a 30 day period preceding licensing. 
(Code 1996, § 2.102)  
Sec. 6-29. - Tags. 
It shall be the duty of each person owning, keeping or having in his possession any dog or cat to keep the city license and vaccination tags for the current year attached to the collar or harness of the dog or cat for which it was issued. 
(Code 1996, § 2.103)  
Sec. 6-30. - Duty of owner or harborer of any dog or cat. 
It shall be unlawful for the owner or harborer of any dog or cat to permit said dog or cat to run at large within the city limits. 
(Code 1996, § 2.104)  
Sec. 6-31. - Duty of officers to impound. 
It shall be the duty of the city health officer, the chief of police, or any police officer of the city to cause to be taken up or impounded all dogs or cats loose or at large in violation of the terms of this article. 
(Code 1975, § 2-1; Code 1996, § 2.105)  
Sec. 6-32. - Right to redeem. 
The person entitled to the possession of any dog or cat taken up and delivered to the city pound, upon proper application within 72 hours from time of impounding of said dog or cat, shall be entitled to have said dog or cat delivered to him, after applying for and receiving a license as provided in sections 6-27 and 6-28, and the payment of a impounding fee as provided for in the fee schedule. 
(Code 1975, § 2-1; Code 1996, §2.106; Ord. of 11-19-1991(01))  
Sec. 6-33. - Dogs or cats not redeemed. 
It shall be the duty of the city to destroy or offer for sale all dogs or cats not redeemed within 72 hours after impoundment. No dog or cat shall be sold for less than the impoundment and kennel fees. 
(Code 1996, § 2.107)  
Sec. 6-34. - Quarantining of dogs or cats exposed to rabies. 
Any dog or cat that has rabies or symptoms thereof, or that is suspected of having rabies, or that has been exposed to rabies, shall at once be released by its possessor for disposal or confinement in a veterinary hospital approved by the city health officer; or immediately and securely confined by tying with a chain of good quality and kept there under the supervision of the department of health for a period of not less than 60 days or as otherwise directed by the health officer. 
(Code 1996, § 2.108)  
Sec. 6-35. - Quarantining of rabid dogs or cats or animals which have bitten persons. 
Every dog or cat that has rabies or symptoms thereof, or any animal that bites, scratches or otherwise attacks any person, shall be immediately and securely confined by the owner, or one having custody, by tying with a chain of good quality for a period of ten days in such a place that no person or animal may be bitten by it, and there held subject to inspection from time to time so as to be able to determine whether said animal is affected by rabies; or said animal shall be quarantined and held for a like time in any veterinary hospital approved by the city health officer, or shall be held at the city pound for ten days, after which time the dog or cat shall be killed if in quarantine at the city pound. 
(Code 1996, § 2.109)  
Sec. 6-36. - Keeping of dogs and cats. 
(a)	No person shall, within 500 feet of a residence, keep or maintain at one place within the corporate limits of the city more than two dogs or two cats, except that puppies or kittens less than three months of age when kept with their mother shall not be included. 
(b)	Any person who shall harbor or keep on his premises or in or about his premises or premises under his control any dog or animal of the dog kind, or any cat or animal of the cat kind, which, by loud barking, howling, or crying shall cause the peace and quiet of the neighborhood or the occupants of adjacent premises to be disturbed, or reasonably liable or be disturbed, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(c)	All pens, yards, buildings, and enclosures used for confining dogs or cats shall have all litter and droppings from such dogs or cats collected every other day and stored in a fly-tight container and hauled away at intervals of not to exceed four days. 
(d)	It shall be unlawful for any person to intentionally release a dog or cat within the limits of the city. 
(e)	No person shall interfere with, hinder, or molest any agent of the city or its agents except as provided in the ordinance of the city. 
(Code 1975, §2-2; Code 1996, art. 2.200)  
Secs. 6-37—6-60. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - CONTROL OF LIVESTOCK 
 
Sec. 6-61. - Distance requirements for keeping cows. 
No person shall keep or milk more than one cow at any one place within the corporate limits of the city, which place is located closer than 100 feet to a house on the adjoining property, except that calves under six months of age when kept with their mothers shall not be included. This section shall not apply to cows, kept on acreage, for which a permit has been secured from the city commission to keep same within the city limits. Such permit may be granted by the city commission without cost, upon written application therefor, and shall be revocable at the will of the city commission on its own motion. 
(Code 1996, § 2.301)  
Sec. 6-62. - Dairy stables for more than one cow. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to build, erect, establish, operate or maintain within the limits of the city any dairy or cow stable where more than one cow is kept or milked, without first obtaining a permit therefor from the city commission. 
(Code 1996, § 2.302)  
Sec. 6-63. - Keeping of horses, mules, jacks, jennets, goats, sheep or bulls at one place. 
It shall hereafter be unlawful for any person to keep or maintain, at one place, within the limits of the city any one or more of the following animals: horses, mules, jacks, jennets, goats, sheep and bulls. This section shall not apply to livestock, kept on acreage, for which a permit has been secured from the city commission to keep same within the city limits. Such permit may be granted by the city commission without cost, upon written application therefor, and shall be revocable at the will of the city commission on its own motion. 
(Code 1996, § 2.303)  
Sec. 6-64. - Disturbances by stabled animals. 
Any person who shall stable or keep a horse, mule, or any other animal in the city limits, in such a manner that said animal, by stamping or kicking, creates such a noise as shall be a disturbance to those living in the vicinity, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1996, § 2.304)  
Sec. 6-65. - Breeding. 
It shall be unlawful to breed, permit or cause to be bred any livestock within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1996, § 2.305)  
Sec. 6-66. - Tying on lots. 
Any person who shall stake, tie or hobble any animal whatsoever on any lot of which he is not the owner, or on any lot or block within the city limits in such a manner as to allow such animals to go upon the adjacent sidewalk or street, shall be guilty of an offense. 
(Code 1996, § 2.306)  
Sec. 6-67. - Hitching to trees in streets or public places. 
Any person who ties or fastens any animal to any shade tree, or to the box around any tree planted or growing in any street or public place, shall be guilty of an offense. 
(Code 1996, § 2.307)  
Sec. 6-68. - Display or sale of livestock on streets. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to use any street of the city as a place on which to display horses or other livestock for sale or to sell the same on said street in any manner that will create an annoyance, or which will create any inconveniences or nuisances to the public in the free and uninterrupted use of said street or streets. 
(Code 1996, § 2.308)  
Sec. 6-69. - Breaking horses or mules on streets. 
Any person who breaks, or attempts to break upon the streets, or who exercises in harness, or attempts to exercise in harness, any wild or unruly horse or mule upon the streets shall be guilty of an offense. 
(Code 1996, § 2.309)  
Sec. 6-70. - Horse racing in streets, etc. 
Any person who shall run, or be in any way concerned in running, any horse race in, along or across any public square or street in this city shall be guilty of an offense. 
(Code 1996, § 2.310)  
Sec. 6-71. - Running at large. 
The running at large of horses, mules, jacks, jennets, cattle, sheep, goats, bulls and hogs within the city limits is hereby declared to be a nuisance and shall be unlawful and constitute a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1996, § 2.311)  
Sec. 6-72. - Duty of officers to impound. 
It shall be the duty of the chief of police, or any police officer of the city, to cause all animals running at large in violation of this article to be impounded. 
(Code 1996, § 2.312)  
Sec. 6-73. - Right to redeem. 
The person entitled to the possession of any animal impounded by the city, upon proper application, shall be entitled to possession of such animal provided he has paid the city an impounding fee for each animal redeemed, and has paid any and all expense incurred by the city due to the impounding of said animal. The impounding fee shall be in an amount as established by the city commission from time to time. 
(Code 1996, § 2.313)  
Sec. 6-74. - Keeping of hogs and goats and sheep. 
It shall hereafter be unlawful for any person to keep or maintain within the limits of the city one or more hogs, swine, pigs or goats; provided that this section shall not apply to milch goats for which a permit has been secured from the city health officer to keep same within the city limits, which permit shall be revocable by the city health officer at any time the premises upon which such goats are not maintained in a sanitary condition. This section shall not apply to hogs, and goats, kept on acreage, for which a permit has been secured from the city commission to keep same within the city limits. Such permit may be granted by the city commission without cost, upon written application therefor, and shall be revocable at the will of the city commission on its own motion. 
(Code 1996, § 2.314)  
Sec. 6-75. - Temporary possession. 
Nothing in this article shall prohibit the temporary possession of livestock in the hands of packing houses or other slaughter houses, nor shall this article prohibit the temporary exhibition of livestock at stock shows. However, these exemptions shall not relieve the persons in charge of such livestock from the operation of other laws and ordinances of the city relative to the sanitary conditions and the noise from said livestock. 
(Code 1975, § 2-3; Code 1996, § 2.316)  
Secs. 6-76—6-93. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - WILD ANIMALS 
 
Sec. 6-94. - When unlawful to keep wild animals. 
It shall be unlawful within the city limits for any person to possess, keep, permit, suffer, cause or allow any wild animal within any residence or within 300 feet of any residence or building used for human habitation. 
(Code 1996, § 2.601)  
Sec. 6-95. - Wild animal defined. 
The term "wild animal" means and includes any mammal, amphibian, reptile or fowl which is of a species which is wild by nature, and of a species which, due to size, vicious nature or other characteristic, is dangerous to human beings. Such animals include, but are not limited to, lions, tigers, leopards, panthers, bears, wolves, raccoons, skunks (whether deodorized or not), apes, gorillas, monkeys of a species whose average adult weight is ten pounds or more, foxes, elephants, rhinoceroses, alligators, crocodiles, and all forms of poisonous reptiles. The term "wild animals" does not include gerbils, hamsters, guinea pigs, mice or rabbits. 
(Code 1996, § 2.602)  
Sec. 6-96. - Violation and penalty. 
Any person who shall possess, keep, permit, suffer, cause or allow any wild animal within any residence or within 300 feet of any residence or building used for human habitation in violation of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined in accordance with the general penalty provision found in section 1-6. Each day any such violation of this article occurs shall constitute a separate offense. Further, the keeping of more than one of such wild animals in violation hereof shall be a separate offense for each such wild animal. 
(Code 1996, § 2.603)  
Sec. 6-97. - Impoundment of wild animals. 
The animal control officer shall seize all animals found in violation of this article and impound all such animals at the city pound or such place as is suitable. The animal control officer or any police officer or any employee of the city as may be designated by the animal control officer shall have the right to enter any building to seize such wild animal in violation of this article upon the consent of any adult occupant of such building or the owner of such building or such person who has the right of possession of such building, or under a warrant issued by a magistrate. 
(Code 1996, § 2.604)  
Sec. 6-98. - Redemption of impounded animals. 
Upon a showing to the animal control officer or his authorized representative of clear and convincing proof of right of possession of any such impounded animal, such person may redeem such animal within seven days of the date of impoundment upon payment of the fees set out in section 6-99, provided that: 
(1)	Such animal is not infected or believed to be infected with rabies or any other disease. 
(2)	Such person submits to the animal control officer a sworn affidavit setting out the location where the wild animal will be kept, and that he will not permit, suffer, cause or allow such animal to be within any residence or within 300 feet of any residence in the city. 
(Code 1996, § 2.605)  
Sec. 6-99. - Impoundment fees. 
The fees, as provided for in the fee schedule, shall be charged for impoundment and boarding of wild animals. 
(Code 1996, § 2.606)  
Sec. 6-100. - Disposition of unredeemed animals. 
If such wild animal is not redeemed within seven days of the date of initial impoundment, the animal control officer shall be authorized to offer such animal to any public zoo or medical institutions using such animals for research. If such wild animal is not accepted by such public zoo or medical institution within 30 days of the date of initial impoundment, the animal control officer is hereby authorized to destroy any such animal. 
(Code 1996, § 2.607)  
Sec. 6-101. - Applicability of article. 
The provision of this article shall not apply to the keeping of wild animals for treatment in a facility open and operated by a veterinarian licensed by the state. 
(Code 1996, § 2.608)  
Sec. 6-102. - Use of live vaccine prohibited. 
No person shall vaccinate, or attempt to vaccinate, any wild animal against rabies by the use of live vaccine. 
(Code 1996, § 2.609)  
Sec. 6-103. - Possession of animals vaccinated with live vaccine prohibited. 
No person shall possess, keep, permit or allow any wild animal within the city if such animal has been vaccinated against rabies with the use of live vaccine. 
(Code 1996, § 2.610)  
Secs. 6-104—6-120. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - DOG PARK[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Resolution No. R02-2016, §§ 1—4, adopted Jan. 5, 2016, did not specify manner of inclusion, hence, codification as art. V, §§ 6-121—6-214 was at the discretion of the editor. 
 
Sec. 6-121. - [Dog park established.] 
That there is hereby established a dog park for use of the citizens of the City of Galena Park to exercise and train their dogs which shall be called the "Galena Park Dog Park" and shall be located on the city's property at 1302 Keene Street, Galena Park, Texas 77547. 
(Res. No. R02-2016, § 1, 1-5-2016)  
Sec. 6-122. - [Operation, control and maintenance.] 
That the director of parks and recreation department shall be responsible for the general operation, control and maintenance of the dog park subject to the approval of the city commission. 
(Res. No. R02-2016, § 2, 1-5-2016)  
Sec. 6-123. - [Rules and regulations.] 
That the following rules and regulations are hereby adopted governing the use and operation of the dog park, to-wit: 
(1)	Hours of operation. The Galena Park Dog Park shall be open daily from 7:00 a.m. and shall close at 9:00 p.m. 
(2)	Children at the dog park. Children under the age of 16 years old and under are to be accompanied by an adult and strictly supervised at all times. 
(3)	Dog owners are responsible for the actions and behavior of their dogs at all times while at the dog park. 
(4)	Dogs are required to be leashed when entering and exiting the dog park. 
(5)	Owners are required to accompany their dogs inside the fenced area, carry a leash, have their dog within sight and under voice control at all times. 
(6)	Items prohibited from dog park—Alcoholic beverages, glass containers, food of any kind, female dogs in season, aggressive dogs, sick dogs, dogs four months of age and under, and pets other than dogs are prohibited in the dog park. 
(7)	At the first sign of aggression, dogs are to be leashed and immediately removed from the dog park. 
(8)	Limit of two dogs per adult. No person shall be allowed to have more than two dogs in the dog park at the same time. 
(9)	All dogs shall meet vaccination and licensing requirements of the City of Galena Park as set forth in the City's Code of Ordinances at Article 2.100, Section 2.101 and Section 2.102. All dogs must display a valid and up-to-date rabies vaccination tag while at the dog park. Owners are required to carry a copy of the dog's vaccination certificate. 
(10)	Dog owners are responsible for picking up after their dogs and disposing of feces or waste from their dog. 
(11)	A large dog is one whose weight is more than 20 pounds and a small dog is one whose weight is less than 20 pounds. 
(Res. No. R02-2016, § 3, 1-5-2016)  
Sec. 6-124. - Enforcement. 
The director of parks and recreation of his designees shall be responsible for the enforcement of the foregoing rules and regulations governing the dog park and are authorized to order the removal of any owner and their dogs for the violation of such rules and regulations. 
(Res. No. R02-2016, § 4, 1-5-2016)  
Chapter 10 - BUILDINGS AND CONSTRUCTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— General enforcement authority of municipalities for preservation of health, property and good government, Texas Local Government Code § 54.001 et seq.; International Residential Code adopted as municipal residential building code throughout the state, Texas Local Government Code § 214.212; International Building Code adopted as municipal commercial building code throughout the state, Texas Local Government Code § 214.216. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 10-1. - Heating and air conditioning work. 
The city secretary shall collect an inspection and permit fee at the time of issuing the permit in accordance with the schedule as provided for in the fee schedule. 
(Code 1996, art. 3.900; Ord. of 11-19-1991, § 1)  
Sec. 10-2. - Underground tanks. 
The fee for the installation and removal of underground tanks shall be as provided for in the fee schedule. 
(Code 1996, art. 3.1100; Ord. of 11-19-1991)  
Sec. 10-3. - Enforcement and citation authority. 
(a)	The building inspector, code enforcement officer, or other designee of the mayor are hereby authorized to enforce within the city the provisions of this chapter and the state minimum codes adopted herein. 
(b)	The building inspectors, code enforcement officer, their officers and assistants, or other designee of the mayor are hereby authorized to issue citations for violations of this chapter. The citations shall contain the following information: 
(1)	Name of alleged violator; 
(2)	Location of alleged violation; 
(3)	Description of alleged violation; 
(4)	Date violation observed; 
(5)	Name of issuing officer; 
(6)	Time and date to appear before court; and 
(7)	Name and address of municipal court. 
(Ord. No. 2016-03A, 8-16-2016)  
Sec. 10-4. - Required. 
Unless otherwise exempted by this Code, the planning and zoning appendix, or a technical code as adopted by reference in this Code, no person shall construct, develop, reconstruct, alter, change, restore, remove, relocate, demolish or perform any building, construction, electrical, or plumbing work as covered by this chapter on any building or structure in the city without first obtaining a building permit as issued by the city.  
Sec. 10-5. - Fire hydrants. 
Contractors shall pay a deposit in an amount as established by the city commission from time to time for each water meter placed on a fire hydrant. Upon return of the water meter, the contractor's deposit shall be returned. 
(Code 1996, App. A, § 12.200; Ord. No. 2009-04, § 1, 6-2-2009)  
Sec. 10-6. - Contractor fees. 
(a)	All contractors performing work within the city, except for state licensed plumbing contractors, shall be required to register, prior to performing any work in the city by filing an application with the city secretary and paying a registration fee per year in an amount established by the city commission from time to time. 
(b)	All contractors, including plumbing contractors, shall provide the city secretary proof of public liability insurance in an amount of not less than $100,000.00 per occurrence, with an aggregate of $300,000.00 maximum per occurrence upon registering to perform work in the city. 
(Res. No. R15-2012, § 2, 11-20-2012)  
Secs. 10-7—10-26. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - BUILDING CODES 
 
Sec. 10-27. - Codes adopted. 
(a)	The following named codes are hereby approved, adopted and incorporated by reference into this Code, to-wit: 
(1)	2009 International Building Code. 
(2)	2009 international Residential Code. 
(3)	2009 International Energy Efficiency Code. 
(4)	2009 International Property Maintenance Code. 
(5)	2009 Uniform Mechanical Code. 
(6)	2009 Uniform Plumbing Code. 
(7)	2011 National Electrical Code. 
(8)	2009 International Fire Code. 
(b)	Any subsequent editions or amendment to any of the codes adopted in subsection (a) of this section may be adopted by resolution of the city commission. 
(Code 1996, § 3.101; Ord. of 6-5-1990; Ord. No. 2012-06, § 1, 9-18-2012)  
Sec. 10-28. - Building permit fees. 
The city secretary shall collect an inspection and permit fee at the time of issuing a building permit for any additions or structural alterations done on any structures in the city, in accordance with the fee schedule, as provided for in the fee schedule, based upon the valuation of the work done on each structure. 
(Code 1996, art. 3.200; Ord. of 11-19-1991)  
Sec. 10-29. - Rules of construction for technical codes. 
(a)	Wherever the word "municipality" is used within the technical codes which are adopted by reference in this article, it shall be held to mean the city. 
(b)	Wherever the term "chief appointing authority" is used within the technical codes which are adopted by reference in this article, it shall be held to mean the city. 
(c)	Wherever the term "corporation counsel" or "legal counsel" is used within the technical codes which are adopted by reference in this article, it shall be held to mean the city attorney. 
(d)	Where reference is made to the duties of certain officials named within the technical codes which are adopted by reference in this article, then that designated official of the city who has duties corresponding to those of the named official in said technical code shall be deemed to be the responsible official insofar as enforcing the provisions of that technical code are concerned.  
Sec. 10-30. - Interpretations. 
The building inspector, code enforcement officer, or other designee of the mayor is hereby authorized to render interpretations of this Code and the adopted technical codes, and to adopt policies and procedures in order to clarify the application of their provisions. Such interpretations, policies and procedures shall be in compliance with the intent and purpose of this chapter. Such policies and procedures shall not have the force and effect of law and shall not have the effect of waiving requirements specifically provided for in this Code or in the adopted technical codes. 
(Ord. No. 2016-03A, 8-16-2016)  
Sec. 10-31. - Administrative liability. 
No officer, agent, or employee of the city charged with the administration and enforcement of this chapter and acting in good faith without malice in the discharge of those duties, shall render himself personally liable for any damage that may occur to any person or property as a result of any act required or permitted, or by reason of any act or omission, in the discharge of his duties under this chapter, and he is hereby relieved from all personal liability for any damage that may accrue to persons or property as a result of any act required or by reason of any act or omission in the discharge of his duties.  
Sec. 10-32. - Referenced codes and standards. 
The technical codes and standards referenced in this Code shall be considered part of the requirements of this Code to the prescribed extent of each such reference. Where differences occur between provisions of this Code and the referenced technical codes and standards, the more stringent provisions shall apply.  
Secs. 10-33—10-52. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - DANGEROUS STRUCTURES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Authority of governing body to appoint building and standards commission to hear and determine cases regarding the materials or methods used to construct a building or improvement and any dangerously damaged or deteriorated buildings or improvements, Texas Local Government Code § 54.031 et seq.; municipal authority regarding substandard buildings and structures, Texas Local Government Code § 214.001 et seq. 
 
Sec. 10-53. - Appointment of members, purpose. 
(a)	The city commission shall appoint a dangerous building board which shall consist of five members, none of whom shall hold any other public office or position in the city. The five members of the board shall be real property tax payers of the city. The mayor and city secretary shall serve as ex officio members of the board. The board shall elect its chairperson from among the appointive members. 
(b)	The purpose and object of said dangerous building board is to act as an appellate body to handle appeals from the building official's action declaring a building or structure dangerous and a nuisance requiring repair, vacation or demolition. 
(Ord. No. 2013-01, § 1, 4-16-2013; Ord. No. 2016-03A, 8-16-2016)  
Sec. 10-54. - Office. 
A member of the dangerous building board can be removed for cause on a written charge. Before a decision regarding removal is made, the Commission must hold a public hearing on the matter if requested by the dangerous building board member subject to the removal action. 
(Ord. No. 2013-01, § 2, 4-16-2013)  
Sec. 10-55. - Proceedings of the dangerous building board. 
The dangerous building board shall adopt rules necessary to conduct its affairs, and in keeping with the provisions of this article. Meetings shall be held at the call of the chairperson, or in his absence, the acting chairperson. The acting chairperson may administer oaths and compel the attendance of witnesses. All meetings shall be open to the public. The board shall keep minutes of the proceedings showing the vote of each member upon each question or if absent or failing to vote, indicating such facts, and it shall keep records of its examinations and other official actions, all of which shall be a public record and shall be immediately filed in the office of the building official and city secretary. 
(Ord. No. 2013-01, § 3, 4-16-2013)  
Sec. 10-56. - Appeals, hearings notice. 
(a)	Any person aggrieved, or any official or department of the governing body of the city affected by any decision or judgment of the building official concerning interpretation or administration of this article may appeal such decision or judgment to the dangerous building board. Such appeals shall be taken within 30 days by filing with the building official and with the dangerous building board a notice of appeal accompanied by a fee as established by the city commission, specifying the grounds thereof. The building official shall forthwith transmit to the board, all papers constituting the record upon which the action appealed from was taken. 
(b)	The dangerous building board shall fix a reasonable time for the hearing of the appeal, give public notice thereof as well as due notice to the parties in interest, and decide the same within a reasonable time. At the hearing any party may appear in person or by agent or attorney. 
(Ord. No. 2013-01, § 4, 4-16-2013)  
Sec. 10-57. - Stay of proceedings. 
Any appeal to the board stays all proceedings in furtherance of the action of the building official appealed from; provided, however, after the notice of appeal is filed with the building official, if the building official, certifies in writing that a stay would, in his opinion, cause imminent peril to life and property. In such case, proceedings shall not be stayed other than by a restraining order which may be granted by the dangerous building board or by a court of record on application. 
(Ord. No. 2013-01, § 5, 4-16-2013)  
Sec. 10-58. - Powers and duties of the dangerous building board. 
The dangerous building board shall have the authority and duty to hear and decide appeals where it is alleged that there is an error in any order, requirements, decision or determination made by the building official in the enforcement of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2013-01, § 6, 4-16-2013)  
Sec. 10-59. - Decisions of the dangerous building board. 
(a)	The dangerous building board may reverse or affirm, wholly or partly, or may modify the order, requirement, decision or determination appealed from and may make such order, requirement, decision or determination as ought to be made, and to that end shall have powers of the administrative official from whom the appeal is taken 
(b)	The concurring vote of a majority of the members of the board shall be necessary to reverse any order, requirement, decision or determination of the building official, or to decide in favor of the applicant on any matter upon which it is required to pass under this article, or to affect any variation in the application of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2013-01, § 7, 4-16-2013)  
Sec. 10-60. - Appeals from the dangerous building board. 
Any person or any board, taxpayer, department, board or bureau of the city aggrieved by any decision of the dangerous building board may seek review by a court of record of such decision, in the manner provided by the laws of the state. 
(Ord. No. 2013-01, § 8, 5-7-2013)  
Sec. 10-61. - Intent. 
(a)	It is the intent of this article that all questions of interpretation and enforcement shall be first presented to the board only on appeal from the decision of the building official and that recourse from the decisions of the board shall be to the courts as provided by the laws of the state. 
(b)	It is further the intent of this article that the duties of the city commission in connection with this article shall not include hearing and deciding questions of interpretation and enforcement that may arise. The procedure for deciding such questions shall be as stated in this section and this article. Under this article, the city commission shall have only the duties of: 
(1)	Considering and adopting or rejecting proposed amendments or the repeal of this article, as provided by law; and 
(2)	Establishing a schedule of fees and charges as stated in this article. 
(c)	The city commission shall establish a schedule of fees, charges and expenses, and a collection procedure for appeals pertaining to this article. 
(Ord. No. 2013-01, § 9, 4-16-2013)  
Sec. 10-62. - Dangerous buildings. 
(a)	Compliance with section and construction contrary to Code. 
(1)	No building or structure shall be constructed, altered, or removed, nor shall the equipment for the operation of a building, structure, or premises be constructed, installed, altered, or removed, except in conformity with generally accepted good practice and the provisions of all applicable building codes and ordinances of the city. 
(2)	Where construction or other work is being done contrary to the provisions of this Code or to the building code, or is being done in an unsafe or dangerous manner, the building official may order the work stopped by notice in writing served on the person engaged in doing or causing such work to be done, and such person shall forthwith stop the work until authorized to recommence it by the building official. 
(b)	Defining "dangerous buildings," and declaring same as nuisances; providing standards for repair, vacation, or demolition; setting forth the administrative responsibility in such matters; and providing a penalty for violation of such standards. 
(1)	Defects. All buildings or structures which have any or all of the following defects shall be deemed dangerous buildings: 
a.	Those whose interior walls or other vertical structural members list, lean or buckle to such an extent that a plumb line passing through the center of gravity falls outside of the middle third of its base. 
b.	Those which, exclusive of the foundation, show 33 percent or more of damage or deterioration of the supporting members or 50 percent of damage or deterioration of nonsupporting enclosing or outside walls or covering. 
c.	Those which have improperly distributed loads upon the floors or roofs or in which the same are overloaded, or which have insufficient strength to be reasonably safe for the purpose used. 
d.	Those which have been damaged by fire, wind or other causes so as to have become dangerous to life, safety, morals, or the general health and welfare of the occupants or the people of the city. 
e.	Those which are so dilapidated, decayed, unsafe, unsanitary, or which so utterly fail to provide the amenities essential to decent living that they are unfit for human habitation, or are likely to cause sickness or disease, so as to work injury to the health, morals, safety or general welfare of those occupying such building. 
f.	Those having light, air and sanitation facilities which are inadequate to protect the health, morals, safety or general welfare of human beings who live or may live therein. 
g.	Those which have inadequate facilities for egress in case of fire or panic or those having insufficient stairways, elevators, fire escapes, or other means of communication. 
h.	Those which have parts thereof which are so attached that they may fall and injure members of the public or property. 
i.	Those which because of their condition are unsafe, unsanitary, or dangerous to the health, morals, safety or general welfare of the people of this city. 
j.	Those buildings existing in violation of any provisions of this Code, the building code, or other ordinances of this city. 
(2)	Standards for repair, vacation or demolition. 
a.	The following standards shall be followed in substance by the building inspectors and the building official in ordering repair or vacation or demolition: 
1.	If the dangerous building can reasonably be repaired so that it will no longer exist in violation of the terms of this subsection, it shall be ordered repaired. 
2.	If the dangerous building is in such condition as to make it dangerous to the health, morals, safety or general welfare of its occupants, it shall be ordered to be vacated. 
b.	In any case where a dangerous building is 50 percent damaged, decayed or deteriorated, it shall be repaired or demolished. In all cases where a building cannot be repaired so that it will no longer exist in violation of the provisions of this subsection, it shall be demolished. In all cases where a dangerous building is a fire hazard existing or erected in violation of the terms of this subsection or of this Code, or of the building code, or of any other ordinance, or of any other requirement of law of the state, it shall be repaired or demolished. 
(3)	Dangerous buildings; nuisances. All dangerous buildings within the terms of subsection (b)(1) of this section are hereby declared to be public nuisances, and shall be repaired, vacated and repaired, or vacated and demolished as hereinbefore and hereinafter provided. 
(4)	Duties of building inspectors. The building inspectors shall: 
a.	Inspect any building, wall, or structure about which complaints are filed by any person to the effect that a building, wall or structure is or may be existing in violation of this section. 
b.	Inspect any building, wall, or structure reported (as hereinafter provided for) by the fire, health or police departments of this city as probably existing in violation of the terms of this section. 
c.	Inspect buildings in the city to determine whether they are dangerous buildings within the terms of subsection (b)(1) of this section. 
d.	Notify in writing the owner, occupant, lessee, mortgagee, agent and all other persons having an interest in said building as shown by the deed records of the clerk of the county where the land is located, of any building found by him to be a dangerous building within the standards set forth in subsection (b)(1) of this section that: 
1.	The owner must vacate, vacate and repair, or vacate and demolish said building in accordance with the terms of the notice and this section. 
2.	The occupant or lessee must vacate said building or may have it repaired in accordance with the notice and remain in possession. 
3.	The mortgagee, agent or other persons having an interest in said building as shown by the deed records of the county clerk of the county where the land is located may, at his own risk, repair, vacate, or demolish or have such work done; provided that any person notified under this section to repair, vacate and repair, or vacate and demolish any building shall be given such reasonable time, not exceeding 30 days, unless, in the judgment of the building official after inspection thereof, it is determined to be necessary to extend such time to do or have done the work or act required by the notice provided for herein. Said building official shall specify, in writing, an additional notice of the date to which said extension is made. 
e.	Set forth in the notice provided for in subsection (b)(4)h of this section, provide a description of the building or structure deemed unsafe, a statement of the particulars which make the building or structure a dangerous building and an order requiring the same to be put in such condition as to comply with the terms provided for above. 
f.	Report to the building official any noncompliance with the notice provided for in subsections (b)(4) and (b)(5) of this section. 
g.	Appear at all hearings conducted by the building official and testify as to the conditions existing in the dangerous building. 
h.	If the building inspector completes inspection of a building and find it to be inherently dangerous and in the opinion of such inspector constitutes a nuisance per se, upon approval of such finding ex parte, by the building official, he shall place a notice on such building forthwith reading as follows: 
"THIS BUILDING HAS BEEN FOUND TO BE A DANGEROUS BUILDING BY THE PUBLIC WORKS DEPARTMENT OF THE CITY OF GALENA PARK. THIS NOTICE IS TO REMAIN ON THIS BUILDING UNTIL IT IS REPAIRED, VACATED AND REPAIRED, OR VACATED AND DEMOLISHED IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE NOTICE WHICH HAS BEEN GIVEN TO THE OWNER, OCCUPANT, LESSEE, MORTGAGEE, OR AGENT OF THIS BUILDING, AND ALL OTHER PERSONS HAVING AN INTEREST IN SAID BUILDING AS SHOWN BY THE DEED RECORDS OF THE COUNTY CLERK OF THE COUNTY IN WHICH THE LAND IS LOCATED. IT IS UNLAWFUL TO REMOVE THIS NOTICE UNTIL SUCH NOTICE IS COMPLIED WITH." 
Provided, however, the approval of said building official and the posting of said notice shall not be construed to deprive any person entitled thereto by this subsection to the notice and hearing prescribed herein. 
(5)	Duties of building official. The building official shall: 
a.	Supervise all inspections required by this subsection and cause the building inspectors to make inspections and perform all the duties required of them by this section. Upon receiving a complaint or report from any source that a dangerous building exists in the city, he shall cause an inspection to be made forthwith. If the building official deems it necessary to the performance of his duties and responsibilities imposed herein, he may request an inspection and report be made to him by the fire department of the city, by the police department, the health department or by any other city department. 
b.	Upon receipt of a report of the building inspection division of the public works department as provided for in subsection (b)(4) of this section, give written notice to the owner, occupant, mortgagee, lessee, agent and all other persons having an interest in said building as shown by the deed records of the county clerk where the land is located, to appear before him on the date specified in the notice to show cause why the building or structure reported to be a dangerous building should not be repaired, vacated and repaired, or vacated and demolished in accordance with the statement of particulars set forth in the building official's notice provided for in subsection (b)(4) of this section. 
c.	Hold a hearing and hear such testimony as the inspectors of the building inspection division of the public works department who have inspected the premises of the owner, occupant, mortgagee, lessee, or any other person having an interest in said building as shown by the deed records of the county where the land is located, shall offer relative to the dangerous building. 
d.	Make written findings of fact from the testimony offered pursuant to this subsection (b)(5) as to whether or not the building in question is a dangerous building within the terms of subsection (b)(1) of this section. 
e.	Issue an order based on findings of fact made pursuant to this subsection (b)(5), commanding the owner, occupant, mortgagee, lessee, agent, and all other persons having an interest in said building as shown by the deed records of the county clerk where the land is located, to repair, vacate and repair, or vacate and demolish any building found to be a dangerous building within the terms of this subsection and provided that any person so notified shall have the privilege of either repairing or vacating, or repairing such building if such repair will comply with the building code of the city, or with other applicable ordinances of the city, or the owner or any person having an interest in said building as shown by the land records of the county clerk where the land is located may vacate and demolish said dangerous building at his own risk to prevent the acquiring by the city of a lien against the land where the dangerous building stands, as provided in this subsection (b)(5). 
f.	If the owner, occupant, mortgagee, or lessee fails to comply with the order or extension thereof, provided for in this subsection (b)(5), within ten days, the building official shall cause such building or structure to be repaired, vacated and repaired, or vacated and demolished, as the facts may warrant, under the standards provided for in subsection (b)(2) of this section; and the building official shall certify the charge for such repair, vacation or demolition to the tax assessor-collector of the city as a charge which shall constitute a lien on the real property affected; said charge shall be a lien upon said property and shall be enforced in the same manner as tax assessments and shall bear interest at the rate of six percent per annum until paid. 
g.	Report to the city attorney the names of all persons not complying with the order provided for in this subsection (b)(5). 
(6)	Violations; penalty for disregarding notices or orders. 
a.	The owner of any dangerous building who shall fail to comply with any notice or order to repair, vacate or demolish said building by any person authorized by this subsection to give such notice, or order, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined not to exceed $200.00 for each offense, and each day's failure to so comply shall constitute a separate offense. 
b.	The occupant or lessee in possession, who fails to comply with any notice to vacate, and anyone having an interest in said building as shown by the deed records of the county clerk where the land is located, and under a legal duty to repair, who fails to repair said building in accordance with any notice given as provided for in this subsection, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined not to exceed $200.00 for each offense, and each day's failure to so comply shall constitute a separate offense. 
c.	Any person removing the notice provided for in subsection (b)(4) of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be fined not exceeding $200.00 for each offense. 
(7)	Duties of the city attorney. The city attorney shall: 
a.	Prosecute all persons failing to comply with the terms of the notices provided for in subsection (b)(4) of this section and the order provided for in subsection (b)(5) of this section. 
b.	Appear at all hearings before the building official in regard to dangerous buildings. 
c.	Bring suit to collect all municipal charges, liens, or costs incurred by the building official in preparing or causing to be vacated or demolished dangerous buildings. 
d.	Take such other legal action as is necessary to carry out the terms and provisions of this subsection (b)(7). 
(8)	Emergencies. In cases where it reasonably appears that there is immediate danger to the health, life or safety of any person unless a dangerous building is immediately repaired, vacated and repaired, or vacated and demolished, the building inspector shall report such facts to the building official and the building official shall cause the immediate repair, vacation or demolition of such dangerous building. The cost of such emergency repair, vacation or demolition of such dangerous building shall be collected in the same manner as provided for in subsection (b)(5) of this section. 
(9)	Where owner absent from the city. In cases, except emergency cases, where the owner, occupant, lessee, or mortgagee is absent from the city, all notices or orders provided for herein shall be sent by registered mail or certified mail to the owner, occupant, mortgagee, lessee and all other persons having an interest in said building as shown by the deed records of the county clerk where the land is located, to the last-known address of each, and a copy of such notice shall be posted in a conspicuous place on the dangerous building to which it relates. Such posting and mailing shall be deemed adequate service. 
(10)	Administrative liability. No officer, agent, or employee of the city shall render himself personally liable for any damage that may occur to the person or property as a result of any act required or permitted in the discharge of his duties under this subsection. 
(11)	Duty to report dangerous buildings. It shall be the duty of all city employees to make a report, in writing, to the building official or to any building inspector of the building inspection division of the public works department of the city of all buildings or structures which they believe are, may be, or are suspected to be dangerous buildings within the terms of this subsection. Such reports are to be made within a reasonable time after the discovery of such buildings or structures. 
(Ord. No. 2013-01, § 9, 4-16-2013)  
Sec. 10-63. - Order to remove; city's remedy on default. 
(a)	Whenever in the opinion of the city commission any building, fence, shed, awning or any erection of any kind, or any part thereof, is liable to fall down and endanger persons or property or is a dangerous structure, the city commission shall order the owner, agent, or occupant of the dangerous structure or the premises on which it stands or is attached to take down and remove the same or any part thereof within ten days after notice is served or published as directed by order of the city commission. 
(b)	In the event the owner, agent or occupant shall fail or refuse to remove the same after notice is served or published as directed by order of the city commission, then the city commission shall have the power to remove the same at the expense of the city on account of the owners of the property or premises and assess the expense on the land on which it stood or to which it was attached in such manner as may be directed in the order of the city commission. 
(c)	All buildings or structures which are structurally unsafe, or not provided with adequate egress, or which constitute a fire hazard, or otherwise dangerous to human life, or which in relation to existing use constitute a hazard to safety, or health or public welfare, by reason of inadequate maintenance, or dilapidation, or obsolescence, or fire hazard, or abandonment, are hereby declared to be dangerous structures. All such dangerous structures are hereby declared to be public nuisances and shall be abated by repair, rehabilitation, demolition, or removal in accordance with the procedure specified in this article. 
(Code 1996, § 3.301)  
Sec. 10-64. - Notice; service. 
(a)	The building official shall examine or cause to be examined every building or structure or portion thereof reported as dangerous, damaged, or unsafe and, if such is found to be an unsafe or dangerous structure under the provisions of this article or other effective ordinance of the city, the building official shall give the owner of such building or structure written notice stating the defects found to exist in violation of this article or in violation of any other effective ordinance of the city. 
(b)	The notice from the building official shall require the owner or person in charge of the building or premises to commence either the required repairs or improvements or demolition and removal of the building or structure or portions thereof within 15 days from the date such notice is received by the owner or person in charge of such building or premises, and all such work shall be completed within 90 days from date of notice, unless otherwise stipulated by the building official. Said notice shall also require that the owner be required to submit proof of the scope of any work that may be required and the time it will take to reasonably complete the work. Such notice may also require the building, structure, or portion thereof to be vacated forthwith and not occupied until the required repairs and improvements are completed, inspected, and approved by the building official. 
(c)	Service of such notice may be by certified mail or personal service. 
(d)	The building official shall cause to be posted at each entrance at such building a notice to read: "DO NOT ENTER. UNSAFE TO OCCUPY. BUILDING OFFICIAL, City of Galena Park." Such notice shall remain posted until the required repairs, demolition, or removal are completed. Such notice shall not be removed without written permission of the building official and no person shall enter the building except for the purpose of making the required repairs or demolishing the building. 
(e)	In case the owner shall fail, neglect or refuse to comply with the notice to repair, rehabilitate or to demolish said building or structure or portion thereof, the building official may proceed to prosecute said owner or person in charge of said building or structure as a violator of the provisions of this article or other applicable chapter of this Code or ordinance of the city. 
(f)	In case the owner shall fail, neglect or refuse to comply with the notice to repair, rehabilitate or to demolish and remove said building or structure or portion thereof, the building official shall notify the city commission of such fact and the city commission may order the building official to proceed with the work specified in such notice or order such building or structure demolished or removed and may cause the cost of such work to be paid and levied as a special assessment against the property at a public hearing before the city commission. 
(g)	The city commission shall give notice to the owner or person in charge of such building or structure of the public hearing before the city commission and the order directing the building official to proceed with the work and assessing the cost thereof against the property. The city shall also make a diligent effort to discover each mortgagee and lienholder having an interest in the building or property and shall send to each a notice containing: 
(1)	An identification of the building and the property on which it is located; 
(2)	A description of the violation of municipal standards that is present at the building; 
(3)	A statement that the municipality will vacate, secure, remove or demolish the building or relocate the occupants of the building if the ordered action is not taken within a reasonable time; and 
(4)	A statement of the date, time, and place that the hearing before the board will take place. 
(h)	Notice of the public hearing to be held before the city commission shall be given by causing a notice of such hearing to be sent by certified mail with receipt return requested, or by delivery by the United States Postal Service using signature confirmation service, or by personal delivery at least ten days before the date of such hearing to the record owners of the affected property, and each holder of a recorded lien against the affected property and to all unknown owners, by posting a copy of the notice on the front door of each improvement situated on the affected property or as close to the front door as practicable by publication of a notice of such hearing before the city commission at least one time in a newspaper of general circulation in the city prior to the date of such hearing. 
(i)	If the owner, agent or occupant of the dangerous building or structure or of the premises on which it stands or is attached shall appear before the city commission at such hearing, no further notice shall be required, but if he fails to appear, then notice of the order of the city commission made at such hearing shall be by mailing a copy of such order to the owner, agent or occupant of the dangerous building or structure or the premises on which it stands or is attached at his last known address by certified mail and by publication of a copy of such order at least one time in a newspaper of general circulation in the city. 
(Code 1996, § 3.302)  
Sec. 10-65. - Procedure after service of notice. 
Upon the expiration of ten days from date of service of the order of the city commission upon the owner or person in charge of such dangerous structure and the publication thereof as required in this article, the building official shall proceed with the work specified in the order of the city commission. 
(Code 1996, § 3.303)  
Sec. 10-66. - Default of owner; suit to recover. 
In the event the owner, agent or occupant of the premises shall fail or refuse for a period of 30 days to pay off and discharge the expenses assessed by the city commission then the city may commence an action in any court having jurisdiction to recover the expenses assessed by the city commission. 
(Code 1996, § 3.304)  
Sec. 10-67. - Penalty. 
Any owner, agent or occupant of premises, including any person having ownership, occupancy or control of any property in the city on which there exists a nuisance as herein set out and shall fail, refuse or neglect to remove or abate such nuisance or refuse to allow the removal of said dangerous structure or part thereof after receiving due notice as herein set out, or refuse to abide by any order requiring the removal of said dangerous structure or part thereof, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be fined in accordance with the general penalty provision found in section 1-6. Each day such violation continues to exist shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1975, § 3-1; Code 1996, § 3.305)  
Secs. 10-68—10-90. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - MOBILE HOMES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Texas Manufactured Housing Standards Act, Texas Occupations Code § 1201.001 et seq.; regulation by municipality of mobile and manufactured housing, Texas Occupations Code § 1201.008; regulation of certain types of housing and buildings, reservation of municipal authority, Texas Occupations Code § 1202.252. 
 
Sec. 10-91. - Codes adopted. 
The Texas Mobile Home Standards Act, including the rules and regulations adopted by the Mobile Home Division of the Texas Department of Labor and Standards, a copy of which is on file with the city secretary, is hereby adopted by the city and is incorporated in this Code by reference herein for all purposes. 
(Code 1996, § 3.401; Ord. of 7-17-1990)  
Sec. 10-92. - Administrative enforcement. 
The purpose of this article is to provide basic and uniform regulations and performance objectives establishing reasonable standards and safeguards for the safety, health, and welfare of the occupants and users of mobile homes, which shall be designed and constructed to comply with the provisions herein set forth and the parking and location of mobile homes in said city. This article is hereby declared to be remedial and shall be construed to secure the beneficial interest and purpose thereof, which will be health, sanitation, general public safety, and welfare, by regulating the location, installation, construction and maintenance of all mobile homes. 
(Code 1996, § 3.402)  
Sec. 10-93. - Scope. 
This article provides the minimum standards with respect to strength, durability, corrosive resistance, fire resistance and other qualities for materials, assemblies, construction and equipment. Also regulated under the provisions of this article are the use and occupancy of mobile homes, and the licensing thereof and permits and fees. Pre-fabricated and modular buildings (other than mobile homes) are not regulated by the provisions of this article, but are regulated by other code provisions and ordinances. 
(Code 1975, § 3-2; Code 1996, § 3.403)  
Sec. 10-94. - Definitions. 
Unless otherwise specified, regulation of mobile homes herein shall be equally applicable to those structures classified as HUD-Code manufactured homes, and said terms shall be interpreted as being interchangeable. 
(Code 1996, § 3.404)  
Sec. 10-95. - Restrictions and zoning. 
The provisions of this article shall not be deemed or construed to repeal, modify or constitute an exception to any fire zone restrictions, zoning ordinance, deed restrictions, or restrictive covenants running with the land. No mobile home shall be parked, placed or permitted to remain on any lot or tract of land in the city in violation of the zoning ordinance of the city, any deed restrictions or restrictive covenants running with the land. Any permit or license issued hereunder for the placement of a mobile home upon any lot or tract in the city in violation of any zoning ordinance, deed restrictions or restrictive covenants running with the land shall be null and void and of no effect. 
(Code 1975, § 3-2; Code 1996, § 3.405)  
Sec. 10-96. - Maintenance and existing location of mobile homes. 
Mobile homes located within the city limits at the time of the passage of this article may continue to be so located and their occupancy continued if such use of occupancy was legal at the time of the passage of this article, and, further, provided that such continued use conforms to all requirements herein and is not dangerous to life. The replacement, relocation, or rearrangement of a mobile home shall not be permitted, unless such permission is granted under the provisions of this article. This prohibition specifically includes replacement of a mobile home with a HUD-Code manufactured home. All mobile homes, both existing and new, and all parts thereof shall be maintained in a safe and sanitary condition. All devices or safeguards which are required by this article shall be maintained in good working order. 
(Code 1975, § 3-2; Code 1996, § 3.406)  
Sec. 10-97. - Placement of mobile homes prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful to place any mobile home, as opposed to a manufactured home, in the city. Manufactured homes shall be allowed upon compliance with all relevant provisions of this article. Those mobile homes now present in the city shall be unaffected by this section, however, said mobile homes may not be moved to any new location in the city. 
(Code 1996, § 3.407)  
Sec. 10-98. - Duties and powers of director of public works. 
The director of public works and his authorized representatives shall enforce all the provisions of this article and shall act on any question relative to the mode or manner of construction and the materials to be used in the erection, addition to, alteration, repair, removal, location, occupancy, and maintenance of mobile homes, except as may otherwise be specifically provided for by statutory requirements, or as herein provided. 
(1)	Applications and permits. The director of public works shall receive applications and issue permits for the placement and alteration of mobile homes and inspect the premises for which such permits have been issued and enforce compliance with the provisions of this article. 
(2)	Building notices and orders. The director of public works shall issue all necessary notices or orders to remove illegal or unsafe conditions, to ensure compliance with all the requirements of this article for safety, health and general welfare of the public. 
(3)	Compliance with state law. All mobile homes constructed within the state or imported into the state after the effective date for compliance with the provisions of Texas Occupations Code § 1201.008 shall have a label or mark of compliance permanently affixed certifying compliance with the standards and provisions of said law. The city shall have the right to inspect all mobile homes for the purpose of determining that they are maintained so as to comply with the provisions of said state law and the city shall further have the right to inspect for safety and for compliance with the provisions of this article all mobile homes, whether constructed prior to or subsequent to the effective date of said Texas Occupations Code § 1201.008. 
(4)	Test reports. The director of public works may accept reports from recognized testing laboratories which have complied with the professional licensing laws of the state of the domicile, if any, with respect to new materials and methods of construction purposes for use and which are not specifically provided for in this article when such report certifies that such material or method of construction equals or exceeds the performance standards required by the provisions of this article. The cost of all such tests or other investigations required under this provision shall be paid for by the applicant. 
(Code 1996, § 3.408)  
Sec. 10-99. - Placement and compliance permit. 
(a)	Generally. No mobile home shall be placed on any lot or site in the city unless a permit therefor has been issued by the city approving said placement. Said placement permit shall not become final and absolute until said director of public works inspects said mobile home in place and certifies on said placement permit that said mobile home in place is in compliance with the terms of this article. Said mobile home owner or occupant shall have 20 days to secure the certification of compliance after the mobile home has been placed on a lot in the city. No placement permit will be issued until an affidavit has been submitted to the city stating that the purpose for which the permit is being sought will not violate this article, the city zoning ordinance, any deed restrictions, or covenants running with the land to which the property may be subject. The city shall not issue a permit fee required herein until the owner or occupant of said mobile home has paid said fee as provided for in the fee schedule. 
(b)	Outside licensed parks. It shall be unlawful for any person to locate or maintain for occupancy any mobile home or travel trailer in the city, other than in a duly licensed and lawful mobile home park or travel trailer park, unless application is made as hereinafter provided. 
(1)	Private lots. Persons desiring to place a mobile home for occupancy on a private lot, whether said lot is vacant or has improvements thereon, shall first secure a permit from the city by filing a written application for such permit with the city secretary, giving the name and address of the applicant, size of the mobile home, and a description of the property upon which said mobile home is to be located. 
(2)	When permits may be issued. 
a.	Thereafter it shall be the duty of the public works director, city building official or city engineer and city secretary to submit said application to the city commission at its first regularly scheduled meeting after the submission of the said application to him. The city commission may refuse to grant any such permit unless the applicant shall first show to the satisfaction of the city commission that such applicant can and will comply with the requirements of the Uniform Mobile Home Code, and Texas Mobile Home Standard Act, and other applicable ordinances. Further, no permit will be issued to any applicant unless he shall also show to the satisfaction of the city commission that: 
1.	Such mobile home will be located at least 25 feet from any property boundary line abutting upon a public street or highway and at least ten feet from any other property boundary lines. 
2.	Such mobile home will not be located closer than 50 feet from any building or residence. 
3.	The location of such mobile home is not in violation of any deed restrictions or covenants running the land. 
4.	The location of such mobile home is not within any area zoned for O-Residential, B-Residential, C-Residential, Duplex, or D-Apartment as set forth in the zoning ordinance of the city. 
5.	The applicant has submitted tie-down and foundation plans which meet the approval of the city's public works department. 
b.	If the city commission is satisfied that such application should be granted, the city commission shall issue a permit allowing the mobile home to be located as requested. There shall be no charge for the permit issued under this subsection. 
(3)	Unlawful to maintain mobile home without permit or license. It shall otherwise be unlawful for any person to maintain or allow to be maintained on any premises owned by them or under their control within the corporate limits of the city, any mobile home or travel trailer for occupancy upon the tract on which it rests without first obtaining a permit or a license as the case may require from the city. 
(c)	Penalty. Any person who violates any provision of this section shall be guilty of a Class C misdemeanor and shall be fined in accordance with the general penalty provision found in section 1-6. Further, each day shall constitute a separate violation and the person in violation shall be fined for each day such violation occurs. 
(Code 1975, § 3-2; Code 1996, § 3.409; Ord. of 7-17-1990)  
Sec. 10-100. - Mobile home tie-down. 
All mobile homes located within the city limits shall be provided with tie-downs. The mobile home shall be anchored to resist the overturning or sliding due to wind. Anchors, or tie-downs, such as cast-in-place concrete, "dead men," eyelets imbedded in concrete, screw augers or arrowhead anchors, shall be placed at least at each corner of the mobile home. Each device shall be able to sustain a minimum load of 4,800 pounds. 
(Code 1996, § 3.410)  
Sec. 10-101. - Slabs required. 
All mobile homes moved into the city limits after the passage of this article shall be provided with six-inch reinforced concrete slabs the same size or larger than the mobile home placed on said lot. 
(Code 1996, § 3.411)  
Sec. 10-102. - Skirts required. 
All mobile homes shall have installed within 20 days from the time said mobile home is moved on said lot, skirts of metal, brick or masonry construction extending from the slab to the lower frame of said mobile home. In the event that mobile homes are located in the city prior to the passage of this article without slabs, skirts of metal, brick or masonry construction shall be installed extending from the ground surface to the lower frame of said mobile home in the event there is no slab. 
(Code 1996, § 3.412)  
Sec. 10-103. - Other requirements. 
No mobile home shall be placed on a lot in the city that has an existing residential or commercial building on said lot. All mobile homes located in the city shall be required to have their own separate water and sewer connections. 
(Code 1996, § 3.413)  
Sec. 10-104. - Appeals. 
Any appeals which a person desires to make based upon the refusal of the city to issue permits or based upon an inspection disapproval, or any conditions required by this article, shall be made to the city commission. 
(Code 1996, § 3.414)  
Sec. 10-105. - Compliance, violations and penalties. 
When any person shall have been notified by a written notice issued by the city that a mobile home located in the city is in violation of this article, he shall commence immediately to abate the violation within the time specified in the written notice. Such time shall not exceed ten days and may provide for immediate compliance when a serious threat to life or substantial damage to property may be involved. 
(Code 1975, § 3-2; Code 1996, § 3.415)  
Secs. 10-106—10-123. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - HOUSE MOVING 
 
Sec. 10-124. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
House means any building or structure used or designed to be used for human habitation or occupancy in any manner or for any purpose. 
House moving means the transportation of a house from place to place along or across any public street within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1996, § 3.501)  
Sec. 10-125. - Permits. 
(a)	Any person, firm, partnership, or corporation desiring to move any house shall, prior to beginning work, apply to the city secretary for a permit, showing the present location of the house, the new location, the proposed route of moving, the size and type of construction of the house and such other information as may be required and shall pay a deposit per square foot outside measurement for each structure to be moved. The deposit shall be in an amount as established by the city commission from time to time. The permit shall show: 
(1)	The name of the person, firm, partnership or corporation who will move the house. 
(2)	The name of the owner of the house. 
(3)	The present location of the house. 
(4)	The proposed new location.
