The police department shall file all necessary legal papers, supply all necessary documentation, and provide necessary testimony as required for pursuing violation of this article by either the minor or by any parent or guardian. 
(b)	Provided that if a police officer shall find a minor in violation of section 34-147, who has once previously been so found, and warned as in subsection (a) of this section, the officer shall again record the name and address of the minor and his parent or guardian, shall issue a second warning notice, and direct the minor to go home by the most direct means and route. He shall immediately contact the minor's parent or guardian by phone or in person concerning the violation. A copy of the second warning shall be forwarded to the juvenile officer of the city, who at this point shall schedule a person-to-person conference with the parent or guardian and the child concerning this article and the city's expectation and requirement for parental control. 
(c)	Any police officer, upon finding a minor in violation of section 34-147, who has twice previously been found in violation and issued warnings as provided for in subsections (a) and (b) of this section, shall transfer the case to the proper authorities for handling under the provisions of Title 3 of the Texas Family Code. In addition, a complaint will be filed against the parents in municipal court for violation of section 34-147(b). The police department shall file all necessary legal papers, supply all necessary documentation, and provide necessary testimony as required for pursuing violation of this article by either the minor or by any parent or guardian. 
(Code 1996, § 7.904)  
Sec. 34-150. - Penalties. 
(a)	Any minor violating the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a Class C misdemeanor as defined in the Texas Penal Code and shall be dealt with in accordance with the provisions of Title 3 of the Texas Family Code. 
(b)	A parent of a minor violating this article shall be guilty misdemeanor, which shall be punishable by a fine in accordance with the general penalty provision found in section 1-6. 
(c)	In assessing punishment for either a parent or a child, the municipal court judges are encouraged to consider the community service program. 
(Code 1996, § 7.905; Ord. No. 2007-09, 9-18-2007)  
Secs. 34-151—34-168. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VII. - REGULATION OF SEX OFFENDER RESIDENCY 
 
Sec. 34-169. - Findings and intent. 
(a)	The city commission finds that sex offenders that use physical violence and who are convicted of preying on others are sexual predators who present an extreme threat to the health, safety, and welfare of our citizens. Sex offenders are likely to use physical violence, to repeat an offense, have many more victims than ever reported, are prosecuted for only a fraction of their actual sexual offenses, and children not only lack the ability to protect themselves, but additional measures should be taken to keep known sex offenders from having access to children in areas where children generally feel safe. 
(b)	It is the intent of this article to serve the city's compelling interest to promote, protect and improve the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the city by creating areas around locations where children regularly congregate in concentrated numbers wherein registered sex offenders and sexual predators are prohibited from establishing temporary or permanent residency. 
(Ord. No. 2015-05, § 7.1101, 3-17-2015)  
Sec. 34-170. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Child or children means a person younger than 18 years of age. 
City means the City of Galena Park, Texas. 
Permanent residence means a place where the person abides, lodges, or resides for 14 or more consecutive days. 
Sex offender means a person with a reportable conviction or adjudication who is required to register with the state department of public safety under the provisions of Texas Code of Criminal Procedure ch. 62. 
Temporary residence means a place where the person abides, lodges, or resides for a period of 14 or more days in the aggregate during any calendar year and which is not the person's permanent address, or a place where the person routinely abides, resides, or lodges for a period of four or more consecutive or nonconsecutive days in any month and which is not the person's permanent residence. 
(Ord. No. 2015-05, § 7.1102, 3-17-2015)  
Sec. 34-171. - Sex offender residency prohibition, penalty, and exceptions. 
(a)	If a person is required to register on the state department of public safety's sex offender database it is unlawful for that person to establish a permanent or temporary residence within 2,000 feet of any premise where children commonly gather, including a playground, school, child care facility, video arcade facility, public or private youth center, neighborhood, or public swimming pool, as those terms are defined in Texas Health and Safety Code § 481.134. It shall be prima facie evidence that this section applies to such a person if the person's record appears on the database. 
(b)	For the purpose of determining the minimum distance separation, the requirement shall be measured by following a straight line from the outer property line of the permanent or temporary residence to the nearest property line of the premises where children commonly gather, as described herein, or in the case of multiple residences on one property, measuring from the nearest wall of the building or structure occupied or the parking/driveway, whichever is closer to the nearest property line of the premises where children commonly gather, as described herein. 
(c)	Any person violating a provision of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction shall be subject to a fine in accordance with the general penalty, section 1-6. 
(d)	Nothing in this article shall be interpreted to modify or reduce the state's child safety ban. A person as described in subsection (a) of this section residing within 2,000 feet of those places where children commonly gather does not commit a violation of this section if any of the following apply: 
(1)	The person established the permanent or temporary residence and has complied with all sex offender registration laws of the state prior to the date of the adoption of the ordinance from which this section is derived; 
(2)	The person proves that the information on the database is incorrect and that, if corrected, this section would not apply to the person. 
(Ord. No. 2015-05, § 7.1103, 3-17-2015)  
Sec. 34-172. - Property owners prohibited from renting real estate property to sex offenders. 
(a)	It is unlawful to let or rent any place, structure or part thereof with the knowledge that it will be used as a permanent or temporary residence by any person prohibited from establishing such permanent or temporary residence pursuant to the terms of this article if such place, structure or part thereof is located within 2,000 feet, as described in section 34-171(a), of any premises where children commonly gather, including a playground, school, child care facility, video arcade facility, public or private youth center, neighborhood, or public swimming pool, as those terms are defined in of Texas Health and Safety Code § 481.134. 
(b)	Prior to renting any premises, all persons renting property in the city for permanent or temporary residence are required to first check the resident through the state department of public safety website or to call the city police department at (713) 675-3471 to obtain necessary information to ensure compliance with this article. 
(Ord. No. 2015-05, § 7.1104, 3-17-2015)  
Sec. 34-173. - Penalty. 
(a)	It shall be unlawful and a misdemeanor to violate any provision or requirement hereof, and any person, firm or corporation convicted of violating any provision, restriction, requirement, or prohibition of this article shall be fined in a sum of not more than $500.00 for each violation. A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(b)	A culpable mental state is not required for the commission of an offense under this article and need not be proved. 
(Ord. No. 2015-05, § 7.1105, 3-17-2015)  
Secs. 34-174—34-191. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VIII. - ILLICIT SYNTHETIC DRUGS 
 
Sec. 34-192. - Findings. 
The findings contained in the preamble of the ordinance from which this article is derived are determined to be true and correct and are hereby adopted as part of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2015-06, § 1, 3-17-2015)  
Sec. 34-193. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Herbal incense means aromatic plant material, whether referred to as potpourri or otherwise, that is distributed in a loose, leafy, powder or granular form or in a compressed block or blocks that can be crushed to result in a powder or granular form, and can be placed into a pipe, cigarette paper, or other drug paraphernalia for purposes of ingestion by smoking, inhaling or other method, regardless of how the substance is labeled or marketed, including, but not limited to, whether or not such product is labeled as "not for human consumption." 
Illicit synthetic drug means: 
(1)	Any vegetative material, or herbal or plant material, however constituted, designed, intended, marketed, manufactured, or engineered, that contains any quantity of a synthetic chemical or synthetic chemical compound that has no legitimate relation to the advertised use of the product. 
(2)	Any vegetative material, or herbal or plant material, with packaging or labeling that indicates, suggests, or implies that the substance is a substitute for or otherwise mimics the pharmacological effects of marihuana (marijuana), a controlled substance, or a controlled substance analogue as defined by Texas Health and Safety Code § 481.002. 
(3)	Any vegetative material, or herbal or plant material, offered for sale or sold with verbal or written representations regarding the purpose, methods, use, or effect of the substance that indicates, suggests, or implies that the substance mimics the pharmacological effects of marihuana (marijuana), a controlled substance, or a controlled substance analogue as defined by Texas Health and Safety Code § 481.002. 
(Ord. No. 2015-06, § 2, 3-17-2015)  
Sec. 34-194. - Prohibition of illicit synthetic drug. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to possess, provide, sell, barter, produce, manufacture, distribute, or to offer, display, market or advertise for sale, or purchase with the intent to provide, sell, barter, produce, manufacture, or distribute, or to offer, display, market or advertise for sale any illicit synthetic drug. 
(Ord. No. 2015-06, § 3, 3-17-2015)  
Sec. 34-195. - Failure to publicly display or label herbal incense. 
(a)	Herbal incense offered for sale to the public must be publicly displayed at all times through actual or representative packaging. 
(b)	All herbal incense offered for sale to the public must include a label listing each active ingredient. 
(Ord. No. 2015-06, § 4, 3-17-2015)  
Sec. 34-196. - Penalty. 
(a)	Any violation of this article is a misdemeanor punishable upon conviction by a fine not to exceed $2,000.00. Each separate package, container, or other separate unit containing an illicit synthetic drug shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. 
(b)	Any violation of this article is a misdemeanor punishable upon conviction by a fine not to exceed $2,000.00. Each separate package, container, or other separate unit containing any herbal incense shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. 
(c)	Prosecution or conviction under this article is cumulative of and shall never be a bar to any other civil or administrative remedy provided or allowed in this article or by law. 
(Ord. No. 2015-06, § 5, 3-17-2015)  
Sec. 34-197. - Affirmative defenses. 
(a)	It is a defense to prosecution under the provisions of this article that the person possessed the illicit synthetic drug under the lawful supervision of an authorized law enforcement officer to enforce or ensure compliance with this article. 
(b)	It is a defense to prosecution that a violation of this article is expressly permitted by state or federal law. 
(Ord. No. 2015-06, § 6, 3-17-2015)  
Sec. 34-198. - Seizure. 
Any product or substance possessed, provided, sold, bartered, produced, manufactured, distributed, or offered, displayed, marketed or advertised for sale or purchased with the intent to provide, sell, barter, produce, manufacture, or distribute, or to offer, display, market or advertise for sale, in violation of any provision of this article, may be seized by any peace officer. Such product or substance may be destroyed as authorized by state law after its use for evidentiary purposes is no longer required. 
(Ord. No. 2015-06, § 7, 3-17-2015)  
Chapter 38 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Municipal authority to improve land for park purposes, operate and maintain parks and recreation, to construct buildings, lay out and pave driveways and walks, construct ditches or lakes, and set out trees and shrubs, Texas Local Government Code § 331.001 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 38-1. - Hours of operation. 
The areas in the city's public parks as described in Exhibit A, attached to the ordinance from which this section is derived and located in the office of the city secretary, shall be open every day for use by the public at 6:00 a.m. in the morning and shall close every day at 11:00 p.m. in the evening. The public shall not be permitted to use public park areas described in said Exhibit A after closing at 11:00 p.m. in the evening except by special use permit issued by the city secretary. 
(Code 1996, § 1.1201; Ord. of 10-3-1989, § 1)  
Sec. 38-2. - Posting of signs. 
The public works director shall cause signs plainly visible to the public to be posted setting forth the hours during which the public park areas will be open for public use. 
(Code 1996, § 1.1202; Ord. of 10-3-1989, § 2)  
Sec. 38-3. - Loitering or remaining in parks. 
Any person who is found to be loitering or remaining in the public park areas after the said park areas are closed shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be fined in accordance with the general penalty provision found in section 1-6. 
(Code 1996, § 1.1203; Ord. of 10-3-1989, § 3)  
Sec. 38-4. - Glass beverage containers prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to possess a glass beverage container in any park, swimming pool area and athletic facility of the city. 
(Code 1975, § 1-4; Code 1996, § 1.1204)  
Sec. 38-5. - Swimming pools. 
(a)	The city swimming pool shall be open for the public Tuesday through Sunday of each week commencing June 1, 2016, between the hours of 11:00 a.m. and 2:00 p.m. and between the hours of 6:00 p.m. and 9:00 p.m. during the swim season. 
(b)	The city swimming pool shall be closed to the public between the hours of 2:00 and 6:00 p.m. and on every Monday of each week for cleaning and maintenance. 
(c)	The fee for admission to the city swimming pool shall be $2.00 per person for the three-hour period between 11:00 a.m. and 2:00 p.m. 
(d)	The fee for admission to the city swimming pool shall $2.00 per person for the three-hour period between 6:00 p.m. and 9:00 p.m. 
(e)	Swim classes. There shall be four, two week sessions for swim classes during the swim season. 
(f)	Fees for swim classes shall be $30.00 per child. For families with two children the swim classes shall be $40.00; for three children $50.00 and for four or more children $60.00. To receive the family discounted rate for the swim classes all the children must be siblings. 
(Res. No. R03-2013, §§ 1—3, 4-2-2013; Res. No. R05-2016, §§ 1—6, 5-17-2016)  
Secs. 38-6—38-29. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - RENTAL OF FACILITIES 
 
Sec. 38-30. - City's community building/Galena Manor Recreation Center. 
(a)	Except as provided in this article, no fee shall be charged to the following service groups and organizations for the use of the buildings: 
(1)	Galena Park Chamber of Commerce; 
(2)	Galena Park Rotary Club; 
(3)	Galena Park Lions Club; 
(4)	Galena Park Independent School District; 
(5)	Retired Teacher Association; 
(6)	Brownies/Girl Scouts; Cub Scouts/Boy Scouts; 
(7)	Full Circle Club of Galena Manor; 
(8)	Bridge Club of Galena Manor; 
(9)	Galena Park Nonprofit Baseball Organizations; 
(10)	Churches, provided that a member of the church is a city resident with proper identification; 
(11)	City-sponsored events or city-approved community enrichment programs; and 
(12)	Other nonprofit community service groups as approved by the city commission. 
(b)	The city commission shall have the right to determine the frequency and use of the buildings by the above-listed service groups and organizations. All of the above service groups and organizations shall coordinate their requested use of the building with the recreation department. 
(Code 1996, App. A, art. 1.000(1))  
Sec. 38-31. - Rentals to groups and organizations within the city limits. 
All persons, groups and organizations residing inside the city limits shall be charged a rental fee per hour, with a minimum of two hours, a security deposit, a cleaning and damage deposit and an opening/closing fee, the amounts of which are all to be determined by the city commission from time to time. The security deposit and clean up and damage deposits may be refunded per the conditions set out in subsections (1) and (2) of this section. 
(1)	Cleaning and damage deposit. The cleaning deposit must be made at the time the rental contract is signed and shall be returned within five working days after the rental activity, provided the building is left in the same condition in which it was rented. 
(2)	Security deposit. A security deposit shall be made at the time the rental contract is signed and shall be returned within five working days after the rental activity, provided there is no damage to the building after being inspected by a recreation department employee. 
(3)	Opening/closing costs. In the event the recreation department is required to open and close the building, an opening/closing fee will be charged and must be paid at the time the rental contract is signed and is not refundable. If the renter fails to show up for the opening or delays the closing by more than 30 minutes, the renter will pay an additional opening/closing fee for each 30-minute delay. This amount will be deducted from the security and/or clean up deposit. 
(4)	Rental deposit. A rental deposit will be required to hold the date requested by the renter/user of any building. If the renter/user fails to confirm or cancel at least ten days prior to the date reserved, the rental deposit is not refundable. If said renter/user does confirm, this deposit may be applied to their rental charge and/or their cleaning/damage deposit, whichever applies. Should cancellation be made at least ten days prior, the rental deposit will be refunded. This deposit will be required by all users of the building who are required to pay the hourly rental and/or cleaning/damage deposit. 
(Code 1996, App. A, art. 1.000(2))  
Sec. 38-32. - Rentals to groups and organizations outside the city limits. 
All persons, groups and organizations residing outside the city limits shall be charged a rental fee per hour, with a minimum of two hours, a security deposit, a cleaning and damage deposit and an opening/closing fee, the amounts of which are all to be determined by the city commission from time to time. The security deposit and clean up and damage deposit may be refunded per the conditions set out in section 38-31(1) and (2). 
(Code 1996, App. A, art. 1.000(3))  
Sec. 38-33. - Holiday rentals. 
All persons, groups and organizations, whether residing inside or outside the city limits, shall be charged an additional fee in an amount to be determined by the city commission from time to time for all holiday rentals. 
(Code 1996, App. A, art. 1.000(4))  
Sec. 38-34. - Fundraising or special use activities. 
(a)	If the building is rented for a fundraising activity or other special activity the organization will be required to furnish to the recreation department proof of an event insurance-policy. 
(b)	Nonprofit organizations. All organizations that rent or use the building after hours for fundraising or other special activities will pay the security/cleanup deposit. The same rules will apply as to the security/cleanup deposit refund as set out in section 38-31(1) and (2). 
(Code 1996, App. A, art. 1.000(5))  
Sec. 38-35. - City employees, recreation board and volunteers. 
City employees, active recreation board members, active reserve police officers, and active volunteer firefighters will be allowed the use of one of the buildings one time each year at no charge. The security deposit and clean up deposit will be required and will be refunded under the same terms and conditions as set out in section 38-31(1) and (2). 
(Code 1996, App. A, art. 1.000(6))  
Sec. 38-36. - Timely payment of rental fees. 
All rental fees, security deposits, opening/closing fees and clean up deposits must be paid by the renter seven days prior to the desired rental date. If unpaid on or before this time, the renter will not be guaranteed the use of the building. 
(Code 1996, App. A, art. 1.000(7))  
Sec. 38-37. - Alcohol. 
Consumption of alcoholic beverages may be permitted only at the consent of the director of parks and recreation. If alcohol is allowed, the renter shall be required to provide two uniformed peace officers. In the event there are more than 100 people in attendance the renter shall provide an additional peace officer for each additional 100 persons or part thereof. These officers will be hired by the recreation department. The fee for such service will be paid to the city by the person renting the building. The fee for such services will be a reasonable rate charged by peace officers in the county for such services. The number of hours of security will be the same as the number of hours the building is rented. 
(Code 1996, App. A, art. 1.000(8))  
Sec. 38-38. - Ball park facilities. 
Nonresident baseball organizations will pay a fee per day for the use of the city ball park facilities as established by the city commission from time to time. A security deposit as established by the city commission from time to time will also be paid and may be refunded if the ball parks are left in the same condition in which they are at the time of rental. 
(Code 1996, App. A, art. 1.000(9))  
Sec. 38-39. - Swimming pool. 
The fee for use of the swimming pool shall be as established by the city commission from time to time for three hours with one approved Red Cross trained life guard per 20 people. The required life guards are to be employed by the city but will be paid by the renter. 
(Code 1996, App. A, art. 1.000(10))  
Sec. 38-40. - Contracts for rental and use. 
The recreation director of the city or his designee is hereby authorized to execute a contract with private groups or individuals on behalf of the city based on the foregoing rates and on the form contracts marked Exhibits A, B and C, attached to the ordinance from which this section is derived, on file in the office of the city secretary, and made a part hereof for all purposes. 
(Code 1996, § 1.1402; Ord. of 9-1994)  
Chapter 42 - SIGN REGULATIONS 
 
Sec. 42-1. - Scope. 
The provisions of this chapter shall apply to all signs, as that term is defined in section 42-4, within the extraterritorial jurisdiction or the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1996, § 4.1401)  
Sec. 42-2. - Purpose and intent. 
It is the intent and purpose of this chapter to establish the reasonable, orderly and effective display of outdoor advertising on all highways, streets and roads in the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1996, § 4.1402)  
Sec. 42-3. - Superiority clause. 
If any subdivision or individual tract of land contains restrictions or covenants relating to signs, or any person enter into a legally binding agreement which provides for the regulating of signs in a particular development which are more restrictive than these regulations, the more restrictive requirements shall apply. 
(Code 1996, § 4.1403)  
Sec. 42-4. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Advertising means to seek the attraction of or to direct the attention of the public to any goods, services or merchandise whatsoever or a location that provides goods, services or merchandise. 
Alterations or repair to an advertising display means repairs or improvements to a display, sign or sign structure not exceeding 50 percent of its replacement value. 
Banner means any piece of cloth, plastic, canvas or similar material on which there appears a display, typically supported at both ends. 
Business means the erection or use of any property, building or structure, permanent or temporary, for the primary purpose of conducting in said building or structure or on said property a legitimate commercial enterprise in compliance with all ordinances and regulations of the city governing such activity. Business purpose shall not include any property, building or structure erected or used for the primary purpose of securing a permit or erecting a sign. 
Display means the message of any sign whether it is in words, symbols or objects. 
Face means the total display area and border of a sign. 
Federal primary system means the interstate and freeway primary system and the non-freeway primary system. 
Intersection means the intersection of streets, driveways, alleys or any two surfaces intended for motor vehicles. 
Interstate and freeway primary system means the portion of the national system of interstate and defense highways located within the state which are now or hereafter may be officially designated the interstate system by the state highway and public transportation commission and approved pursuant to Title 3, United States Code Section 131, as amended. 
Nameplate means a non-electrical sign identifying only the name and occupation or profession of the occupant of premises on which the sign is located and not exceeding six inches by 18 inches. 
Non-freeway primary system means that portion of the connective main highway located within the state which now or hereafter may be designated the primary system by the state highway and public transportation commission and approved pursuant to Title 23, United States Code Section 131, as amended. 
Owner means the person who owns or leases the on-premises sign, the owner of the off-premises sign, or the owner of the real property on which the sign, whether it is on-premises or off-premises, is located. 
Person means an individual/company, corporation, partnership, association or any other entity. 
Primarily residential area means the right-of-way (and adjoining property area) between two intersecting public streets in which a majority of the total front footage is used for residential purposes. 
Public street means the entire width between property lines of any road, street, way, alley, bridge or other similar thoroughfare, not privately owned or controlled, when any part thereof is open to the public for vehicular traffic, is the responsibility of the city or other similar public agency to maintain, and over which the city has legislative jurisdiction under its police power. 
Reconstruction means the repair of a sign and its structure that has fallen or has been blown down or the repairs amount to a sum in excess of 50 percent of its replacement value. 
Registration means the registration of the currently existing non-permitted signs. 
Relocate means the removal of a sign and any supporting structure from one location and placing it or its replacement at a new location. 
Residential purposes means property devoted to use as a single-family or multifamily residence. Residential purposes shall include, but not be limited to, property used for houses, duplexes, condominiums, town houses, town homes, patio homes and apartments; property used for hotel, motels and boardinghouses shall not be considered as used for residential purposes. Property devoted to both residential and nonresidential use shall be considered as used for residential purposes. 
Right-of-way means the property fronting or immediately adjacent to, and on either side of, a public street or a non-public street which the public authority has the authority to use for the road or street. 
Sight triangle means the triangle formed at an intersection by intersecting curblines and a non-curbline joining the curblines. The distance on the curbline as used in this chapter shall be 40 feet, rather than 30 feet, along each curb and the triangle shall extend to a height of 12 feet above the highest point of the grade. 
Sign means an outdoor structure, sign, display, light, device, figure, painting, drawing, message, plaque, poster, billboard or other thing that is designed, intended or used to advertise or inform. 
Sign administrator means the sign administrator as defined herein and those representatives that he may designate. 
Sign appeals committee means the committee as defined herein and appointed as established herein. 
Sign company means the person who engages in the business of leasing, constructing or maintaining signs or sign structures. 
Sign structure means any structure which supports or is capable of supporting any sign. A sign structure may be a single pole and may or may not be an integral part of a building. 
Time periods means calendar days unless otherwise specified. Such periods shall start on the day following the event starting the time period to run and end at 5:00 p.m. local time on the last day of such period. Any period ending on a day the city hall is closed for any reason shall be extended until the next actual working day at the city hall of the city. 
Visible means that the message, copy area or advertising display seen (whether or not it is legible) without visual aid by a person of normal visual acuity; or, simply stated, it can be seen. 
(Code 1996, § 4.1404)  
Sec. 42-5. - Sign classifications. 
(a)	Site classification. For the purpose of this chapter, signs shall be first classified as either an on-premises sign or an off-premises sign. 
(1)	On-premises sign. The term "on-premises sign" means any sign identifying or advertising a business, person or activity, installed and maintained on the same premises as the business, person or activity. 
(2)	Off-premises sign. The term "off-premises sign" means any sign displaying advertising copy that pertains to a business, person, organization, activity, event, place, service or product not principally located or primarily manufactured or sold on the premises of which the sign is located. 
(b)	Type classification. All signs shall further be classified into one of the following type signs: 
(1)	Ground sign. The term "ground sign" means a sign which is supported by uprights or braces in or upon the ground, including monument signs, two pole monument signs, converted portable signs and portable signs. 
(2)	Marquee sign. The term "marquee sign" means a projecting sign attached to or hung from a canopy or covered structure projecting from and supported by a frame or pipe support extending beyond a building. 
(3)	Monument sign. The term "monument sign" means either a monument sign or enlarged monument sign as follows: 
a.	Monument sign. The term "monument sign" means any sign ten feet or less in height as measured from the natural ground level to the top of the sign. Such sign shall be a maximum of 60 square feet on each side, contain no cutouts from the ground to the top and shall be permanently affixed to the ground. 
b.	Enlarged monument sign. The term "enlarged monument sign" means any sign 12 feet or less from the natural ground level to the top of the sign. Such sign shall be six feet of nonadvertisement and contain no cutouts from the ground to the bottom of the advertising and shall be permanently affixed to the ground. 
(4)	Projecting sign. The term "projecting sign" means any sign which is affixed to any building wall or structure and extends beyond the building wall or structure more than 12 inches. 
(5)	Roof sign. The term "roof sign" means any sign erected, constructed or maintained above or upon the roof of any building. 
(6)	Wall sign. The term "wall sign" means any sign affixed to or painted upon the wall of any building. 
(7)	Flag sign. The term "flag sign" means any sign constructed of cloth, canvas, light fabric or material affixed to a building, wall, fence or on a staff or pole set in a concrete foundation. 
(8)	Awning sign. The term "awning sign" means any sign made of cloth, metal or plastic with a metal frame attached to a building and projecting over a sidewalk, thoroughfare or parking area when the same is so erected as to permit its being raised to a position flat against the building when not in use. 
(9)	Canopy sign. The term "canopy sign" means any sign, other than an awning attached to a building, projecting over a thoroughfare, sidewalk or parking area and not erected so as to permit its being raised to a flat position against the building, does not permit use of marquee letters and is commonly supported by poles or uprights set upon the underlying ground. 
(10)	Multiple business sign. The term "multiple business sign" means that type of sign that is a single structure but has a different display for each different business such as may be found at a shopping center. 
(11)	Improved portable sign. The term "improved portable sign" mean any on-premises portable sign converted to a fixed sign. 
(c)	Special function classification. Any on-premises or off-premises sign of any type may also be included within one or more of the following additional classifications according to the special functions of that sign: 
(1)	Electrical sign. The term "electrical sign" means any sign containing electrical wiring or utilizing electric current, but not including signs illuminated by a light source exterior to the sign structure. 
(2)	Portable sign. The term "portable sign" means any sign designed or constructed to be easily moved from one location to another, including signs mounted upon a motor vehicle or designed to be mounted upon a trailer, bench, wheeled carrier or other non-motorized mobile structure. A portable sign with the wheels removed shall still be considered a portable sign hereunder. For the purpose of this chapter, trailer signs and signs on benches are portable signs. 
(3)	Spectacular sign. The term "spectacular sign" means any sign which has any automatically changing advertising, which is equipped with glaring or rotating strobe or spotlights or which has any moving message whatsoever. 
(4)	Temporary sign. The term "temporary sign" means any sign including a banner constructed of cardboard, wallboard or other light materials not to exceed 12 square feet in size. Further, a temporary sign is intended to be used for a specific period of time (not to exceed 30 days) and then removed. A portable sign and flag sign shall not be considered a temporary sign. 
(5)	Moveable sign. The term "moveable sign" means signs of six square feet or less designed to be moved by hand and normally stored inside the building during the nighttime. 
(6)	Emitting sign. The term "emitting sign" means any sign or symbol that emits any noise, chemical substance or odor. 
(Code 1996, § 4.1405)  
Sec. 42-6. - Sign administration and enforcement. 
(a)	Sign administrator. The mayor shall appoint or shall designate a sign administrator to administer and enforce the terms and conditions of this chapter and all other provisions of the laws relating to signs. The sign administrator is empowered to delegate the duties and powers granted to and imposed upon him by this chapter to other persons serving under the sign administrator. The sign administrator and such other persons shall constitute the sign administration section. The sign administrator is directed to enforce and carry out all provisions of this chapter. 
(b)	Enforcement responsibility. The duties of the sign administrator shall include not only the approval of issuance of permits as required by this chapter, but also the responsibility of insuring that all signs comply with this chapter and all other applicable law, and that all signs for which a permit is required, do in fact have a permit. The sign administrator shall make such inspections as may be necessary and initiate appropriate actions to bring about compliance with this chapter and other applicable laws if such inspection discloses any instance of noncompliance. The sign administrator shall investigate thoroughly any complaints of alleged violations of this chapter. 
(c)	Powers of the sign administrator. The sign administrator shall have the power and authority to administer and enforce the conditions of this chapter and all other laws relating to signs. Included among such powers are the following specific powers: 
(1)	Inspection and approval. Every sign for which a permit is required shall be subject to the inspection and approval of the sign administrator. When deemed advisable by the sign administrator, a sign may be inspected at the point of manufacture if such point is within or adjacent to the city limits 
(2)	Warranties search. Upon presentation of proper identification to the owner, agent or tenant in charge of such property, he will admit the sign administrator or his representative to the premises to inspect said premises concerning the sign. The applicant, owner or other person in charge of the premises where the sign is located agrees, by making application for a sign or renewal for a sign permit, to admit the sign administrator or representative for the purposes of inspecting and investigating signs or sign structure, any building, structure, or other premises or property between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m., Mondays through Fridays; provided, however, that in cases of emergency where extreme hazards are known to exist which may involve imminent injury to persons, loss of life or severe property damage, and where the owner, agent or tenant in charge of the property is not available after the sign administrator has made a good faith effort to locate same, the sign administrator may enter the aforementioned structures and premises at any time upon presentation of proper identification to any other person on the premises. 
(3)	Stop work order. When the sign administrator or his representative discovers that a sign is being constructed not in conformance with this chapter, he shall issue a stop work order to the person known to be so engaged. Upon notice and issuance of a stop work order from the sign administrator, work on any sign being conducted in a manner contrary to the provisions of this chapter or being conducted in a dangerous or unsafe manner shall be immediately stopped. Such notice and order shall be in writing and shall be given to the owner of the property, to his agent or to the person doing the work, and shall state the conditions under which work may be resumed. Where an emergency exists, written notice shall not be required to be given by the sign administrator. The stop work order shall contain a notice of the right to appeal as provided herein. Work shall not resume until the condition causing the stoppage is corrected to the sign administrator's satisfaction or the appeal process results in a reversal of the administrator's stop work order. 
(4)	Permit and license revocation. The sign administrator shall have and is hereby granted the power and the authority to revoke any and all licenses or permits authorized by this chapter for violation of the terms and provisions of this chapter. 
(5)	Appeal procedure. Upon revoking such license or permits, the sign administrator shall notify by certified mail with return receipt requested to the address given by the permutes or licensee on the application for such permit or license, to advise the permutes or licensee of such revocation and notify the permutes or licensee that the revocation will become final if not appealed to the sign appeals committee within ten days. 
(6)	Establish procedures. The sign administrator shall have the authority to adopt procedures and provide forms required to implement the provisions of this chapter. 
(7)	Enforce state and federal regulations. Pursuant to and in accordance with any agreement between the city and the state, or the United States Government, the sign administrator is hereby authorized to enforce any applicable terms and provisions of the Texas Highway Beautification Act, Texas Transportation Code § 391.001 et seq., the Agreement for Carrying Out National Policy Relative to Control of Outdoor Advertising, entered into between the United States of America and the state, by instrument dated May 2, 1972, and any supplements or amendments to that agreement, and any rules or regulations promulgated by the state and/or the state highway department, pursuant to the said Act or agreements, with regard to signs. 
(8)	Issue citations. The sign administrator or his designated representative shall have the authority to issue citations to any owner, agent of the owner or person in charge of the premises for any violation of this Code existing on the premises. 
(Code 1996, § 4.1406)  
Sec. 42-7. - Appeals to city commission 
Any person wishing to appeal a decision of the sign administrator on the grounds that the decision misconstrues or wrongly interprets this chapter may, within ten days after receiving an adverse ruling of the committee either by personal service or by certified mail return receipt requested, appeal the same to the city commission, provided that the appealing party shall personally deliver to the city secretary or deposit that notice in the United States Mail addressed to the city secretary within the said ten-day period. 
(Code 1996, § 4.1407)  
Sec. 42-8. - Violations and penalties. 
(a)	Standards. 
(1)	General. Any person who shall violate any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall, upon conviction by court of competent jurisdiction thereof, be punished by a fine in accordance with the general penalty provision found in section 1-6. Each day in which any violation shall occur shall constitute a separate offense. In addition, the city attorney is hereby authorized to take all actions, both legal and equitable, necessary to ensure compliance with this chapter. 
(2)	Real property owner. Any person who is the owner of the real property upon which an on-premises or off-premises sign is located and who shall permit a violation upon such real property of any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall, upon conviction by a court of competent jurisdiction thereof, be punished by a fine in accordance with the general penalty provision found in section 1-6 for each violation. Each day on which any violation shall occur shall constitute a separate offense. In addition, the city attorney is hereby authorized to take all actions, both legal and equitable, necessary to ensure compliance with this chapter. 
(b)	Subterfuge. Any permit secured before or after the effective date of this chapter which in the opinion of the sign administrator has been secured through subterfuge and not in full compliance with the provisions of this chapter may be revoked by the sign administrator. 
(c)	Denial of entry for inspection. Whenever the sign administrator or his representative, after showing proper identification, is denied admission to inspect any premises, the sign administrator may revoke all sign permits. 
(d)	Work done without a permit. Any person, firm or organization installing, erecting or reconstructing a sign or changing the location of a sign without a proper permit will be assessed an amount twice the applicable permit fees, in addition to any penalties, civil or criminal, which may be assessed as a result of a violation of the terms of this chapter. 
(e)	Illegal political campaign signs. No political campaign signs of any description shall be allowed on publicly owned property or the property of a public utility. All political campaign signs posted on private property shall be posted only with the consent of the owner or lessee of such property. 
(Code 1996, § 4.1408)  
Sec. 42-9. - Sign applications, permits and fees. 
(a)	Application procedure. Applications for permits required by this chapter shall be made upon forms provided by the sign administrator and shall contain or have attached thereto the following information: 
(1)	Name, address and telephone number of the applicant. This shall be kept current at all times. 
(2)	Location of the building, structure, or lot to which or upon which the sign is to be attached or erected, including lot, block, section number and subdivision name, or a metes and bounds description. 
(3)	Position of the sign in relation to nearby buildings or structures and all street curblines and sidewalks bounding any part of the lot on which such sign is to be placed. 
(4)	Two blueprints or ink drawings on a scale not smaller than one inch to 15 feet of the plans and specifications showing the method of construction and attachment to the building or in the ground. 
(5)	Applications for new ground signs when erected or constructed to heights exceeding 12 feet above ground level, or for new roof signs when erected 12 feet above roof level, shall be accompanied by a drawing of the sign structure and sign prepared by and certified by a professional engineer registered in the state. 
(6)	The sign administrator at his option may also require similar certification by a registered professional engineer where any unusual structural provisions of a proposed sign indicate such certification is necessary in the interest of public safety. 
(7)	A copy of stress sheets and calculations showing how the structure is designed for dead load and for wind pressure on every point in the display surface. 
(8)	The name, street address, business address, business telephone number and home telephone number, and driver's license number of the foreman, supervisor or other person in charge of the construction, destruction, placement or relocation of the sign and related structures. 
(9)	Notarized written consent of the owner, lessee or duly authorized agent of the building, structure or land to which or on which the sign is to be erected. 
(10)	Any electrical permit required and issued for the sign. 
(11)	Evidence of the insurance policy required by this chapter. 
(12)	Such other information as the sign administrator shall require to show full compliance with this chapter and all other laws and ordinances of the city. 
(13)	Permission to enter the property under the provisions herein set out for inspection of the sign and its structure. 
(14)	The location of the sign. 
(b)	Permit required. No person shall hereafter erect, take down, construct, destroy, reconstruct, relocate, remove, alter or use a sign without first having secured a written permit as herein provided from the city. All signs illuminated by direct or indirect lighting, shall in addition, be subject to the electrical code and the permit requirements thereof. Permits are not transferable and will be used only by the person to whom it was issued. A copy of the permit will be posted at each erection site. 
(c)	Permit duration. Any permit to erect, take down, construct, destroy, reconstruct, relocate, remove or alter a sign shall become null and void unless erection, take down, construction, destruction, reconstruction, relocation, removal or alteration of the sign is completed within 90 days, or the permit is renewed for an additional 90 days, in which case an additional fee shall be payable equal to one-half the original fee paid and the proposed sign shall meet all of the requirements of this chapter on the date of renewal. 
(d)	Relocation permits. Relocation permits are required before any sign may be removed for relocation. 
(e)	Definition of permits, applications and fees. The following is a list off the various required applications and permits and for which a fee is charged: 
(1)	Application. 
a.	Required. There shall be an application made for all permits or renewal of permits. 
a.	Construction/destruction/reconstruction permit . The term "construction/destruction/reconstruction permit" means the permit required to construct, destroy or reconstruct a sign or sign structure. 
(2)	Inspection. Inspection, except for portable and exempt signs, will consist of three phases: 
a.	Site. Site inspection required before a sign may be located; 
b.	Construction. Construction inspection to determine if the design requirements are met; and 
c.	Hole. Hole inspection is required for all ground signs. 
(3)	Inspection of portable signs. Inspection of portable signs will consist of one inspection after installation to determine if all requirements of this chapter are met. 
(f)	Sign fees. Fees for permits and other administrative procedures shall be as provided for in the fee schedule. 
(1)	Exemptions. 
a.	No permit shall be required under this chapter for the following on-premises signs unless any such sign is a spectacular sign or a portable sign. Any sign listed hereunder shall be erected and maintained in conformity with the provisions otherwise of this chapter: 
1.	Signs painted on glass surface of windows or doors not to exceed 25 percent of the window or door area. 
2.	Directional and regulatory signs erected by the city, state (inducing its political subdivisions such as counties and school districts), or the federal government and the lessees of such governmental entities. 
3.	Railroad signs. 
4.	Legal notices, and house numbers, "no trespassing," "no parking" and other similar warning signs, not exceeding two in number. 
5.	Temporary signs smaller than six square feet, provided the number of such signs on any one address does not exceed one in number. 
6.	Signs required by federal, state or local law. 
7.	On-premises signs setting forth the location of or directions to parking or buildings located on the premises or regulating the flow of on-premises traffic, only if they do not include any electrical wiring. 
8.	Signs displayed, designed or used for or upon motor vehicles as long as such vehicles are used by the business for delivery or identification. (This is not to be construed to exempt signs built or placed upon a motor vehicle solely for the purpose of advertisement.) 
9.	Signs designed and used for display upon or with heavier-than-air craft. 
10.	Signs which are painted on the face of a building not exceeding five percent of that wall's surface area and no higher than the roofline and state only the street number and name of the proprietor; provided that the number of such signs shall be one per address for such premises. 
11.	Signs within a stadium, open-air theater, arena, public or recreational area which are designed primarily to be viewed by patrons within such stadium, open-air theater or arena. 
12.	On-premises real estate signs five square feet or less. 
13.	Christmas displays and similar temporary displays erected without advertising; however, such displays shall be subject to the fire and electrical code and fire safety rules promulgated by the fire marshal. 
14.	A sign not over 40 square feet in area setting forth information concerning a building or other structure under repair or construction or advertising the sale or rental of the premises. 
15.	Subdivision identification signs, one per subdivision 40 square foot or under. 
16.	One flag of the United States and/or the state and/or the flag of the city. 
17.	Fast food establishments may have in and out directional signs with the company logo if they do not exceed 1½ square feet in addition to the five allowed by this subsection. 
18.	Any on-premises sign viewed only from within the premises and not visible from any public road. 
19.	Any nameplate sign placed on the entrance door or within six inches of the entrance opening. 
b.	Signs exempt from operating permit only. 
1.	Any on-premises sign used for the purpose of perpetuating the doctrines and teachings of any generally recognized church or religious organization holding a valid nonprofit charter which has been filed in the Office of the Secretary of State and for which a current tax exemption certificate has been issued by the Internal Revenue Service; 
2.	Signs which are mounted on the face of a building no higher than the roof-line and state only the street number and name of the proprietor; provided that the number of such signs shall be one per address for such premises; or 
3.	Any on-premises sign operated by and used to further the interests of other recognized charitable organizations holding valid nonprofit charters which have been filed in the Office of the Secretary of State and for which current certificates have been issued by the Internal Revenue Service. 
c.	It shall be the duty of any person, company, organization or entity claiming exemption status under this section to provide any documentation or other items of proof to the sign administrator. An organization claiming exemption status as a tax-exempt organization shall submit a photocopy of its charter and state and federal tax exemption certificate to the sign administrator. 
(g)	Normal maintenance, changing of message or electric light bulbs. No sign permit is required for the change of any of the ornamental features, normal maintenance or the advertising display of a sign previously permitted. This provision shall not release a person from complying with all other applicable permitting requirements of the city, including those of the any building and construction technical code as adopted by reference by the city in the building and construction chapter of this Code. 
(h)	Any misstatement, misrepresentation or incorrect information supplied in order to obtain any type of sign permit, whether or not intentionally done, shall be grounds for the revocation of such sign permit. Such sign shall be removed within 24 hours after permit revocation. If the sign is not removed within 24 hours after permit revocation, the city may remove the sign at the owner's expense and place a lien against the property of the owner for the cost of removal. 
(Code 1996, § 4.1409)  
Sec. 42-10. - Sign companies. 
(a)	Insurance required. Each sign company, under the terms of this section, shall submit copies of policies of insurance certified by the agent issuing them, together with written proof that the premiums have been paid, showing that the performance of work in connection with each sign will be covered by approved public liability and property damage insurance in the amount of $50,000.00 for any person injured, $100,000.00 for injury to more than one person and $50,000.00 for property damage. Such policies of insurance shall be in a form selected or approved by the city and shall name the city as an additional insured. In addition, such policies of insurance shall be issued by an insurance company duly authorized to do business and issue such policies of insurance in the state and maintaining an office or represented by an authorized agent in the state, shall expressly state that it may not be cancelled unless ten days written notice is given to the sign administrator before cancellation of the policy, and must contain an endorsement to the effect that the issuer waives any claim or right in the nature of subrogation to recover against the city, its officers, agents or employees. Whenever any policy of insurance is cancelled, the sign administrator shall require that all work to which such policy applies be stopped immediately. No permits shall be issued until such time that the person or company complies with these insurance requirements. 
(b)	Number to be displayed on vehicles. Vehicles owned or operated by a duly licensed sign installer shall have displayed thereon, at all times, the license number shown on such installer's license, prefixed by the initials "P.S.I." 
(c)	Electrical sign contractors. Each sign company, under the terms of this section, whose operations include signs that in any manner include the use of electrical power, shall adhere to the requirements provisions of the electrical code of the city as that code now exists or may hereinafter be amended. 
(d)	Violations of chapter. Violations of any of the provisions of this chapter shall be grounds for the revocation of the license or denial of the license application of any person who has committed such violation. 
(Code 1996, § 4.1410)  
Sec. 42-11. - Sign maintenance and removal. 
(a)	Maintenance. 
(1)	The area around any sign location must be maintained and kept clean by the owner. Grass will be cut a minimum of six feet from said billboard on all sides and entirely to the street curb on the side nearest the street and debris, etc., will be removed at least weekly. 
(2)	All signs shall be thoroughly painted as often as is necessary, unless of galvanized or non-corroding metal or treated with appropriate wood preservative, and shall be kept in good repair consistent with good maintenance. All braces, bolts, clips, supporting frame and fastenings shall be free from deterioration, termite infestation, rot or loosening. All signs shall be able to withstand safely at all times the wind pressures specified elsewhere in this chapter. In case any sign is not so maintained, the sign administrator shall give written notice to the owner or lessee thereof to so maintain the signs or to remove the sign. Non-maintenance shall be considered a misdemeanor and penalty shall be assessed accordingly. 
(b)	Unsafe signs. Should any sign in the opinion of the sign administrator become insecure or in danger of falling or otherwise unsafe, the sign administrator shall give written notice of the condition of the sign to the person owning, leasing or responsible for the sign. Said person so notified shall correct the unsafe condition of the sign in a manner to be approved by the sign administrator in conformity with the provisions of this chapter. 
(c)	Unlawful signs. In case any sign shall be installed, erected, constructed or maintained in violation of any of the terms of this chapter, in addition to any other rights and remedies provided herein, the sign administrator shall give written notice to the owner, lessee or person responsible for said sign ordering said owner, lessee or person to alter the sign such that it complies with this chapter, or to remove the sign. 
(d)	Removal of signs. 
(1)	Removal of unlawful signs by the city. The following procedures will be followed by the city in removal of unlawful signs by the city. 
a.	Signs found on public property. All signs found on public property or public utility property or easement may be removed and discarded by the city without notice to the owner. This removal does not relieve the owner of any penalties. 
b.	Portable signs found on public property. 
1.	The owners of portable signs that have the proper identification on them found on public property or public utility property or easement may be removed by the city and stored for ten days after the notice or removal is received by the owner for the owner to reclaim. If not reclaimed within ten days, the sign may be sold at auction or disposed of by the city. The cost to reclaim shall be the sum of the following: 
(i)	A civil penalty; 
(ii)	Actual cost of removal and hauling (minimum $50.00); 
(iii)	Storage fee charged per day per 160 square feet of storage surface; and 
(iv)	The cost of the employee's time to administer such confiscation. 
2.	The amounts of the above-listed costs and fees shall be as determined and established by the city commission from time to time. 
c.	Other signs removed by city. 
1.	All other signs removed by the city under any provision of this chapter shall be stored for ten days after the notice of removal is issued to the last known address of the owner of the sign or the owner is personally notified. If such sign is not reclaimed by the owner within ten days of such notice, the sign may be sold at auction or disposed of by the city. The cost to reclaim shall be the sum of the following: 
(i)	A civil penalty; 
(ii)	Actual cost of removal and hauling (minimum $50.00); 
(iii)	Storage fee charged per day per 160 square feet of storage surface; and 
(iv)	The cost of the employee's time to administer such confiscation. 
2.	The amounts of the above-listed costs and fees shall be as determined and established by the city commission from time to time. 
(e)	Replacement or repair of sign. 
(1)	When any sign or a substantial part of it is blown down or otherwise destroyed or taken down or removed for any purpose other than maintenance operations or for changing the letters, symbols or other matter on the sign, it may not be replaced, re-erected, reconstructed or rebuilt except in full conformance with the provisions and requirements of this chapter, including, but not limited to, the requirement of obtaining a permit. 
(2)	For purposes of subsection (e)(1) of this section, a sign or substantial part of it is considered to have been destroyed if the costs of repairing the sign is more than 50 percent of the cost of replacing the sign, exclusive of the pole or poles supporting the sign. 
(3)	The engineering specifications must receive final inspection and approval by the city sign administrator or his designee prior to setting. 
(4)	It is unlawful and a violation of this chapter to continue any work after having been verbally advised to stop work or given a stop work order by the city sign administrator or his designee. 
(5)	It is unlawful and a violation of this chapter to remove a stop work order issued by the sign administrator or his designee. 
(6)	In addition to all other requirements of this chapter, a new sign permit is required whenever the cost of repairing the sign, exclusive of the pole, is more than 50 percent of the cost of erecting a replacement sign of the same type at the same location. 
(7)	Whenever there is a change in ownership or use of the business premises upon which an on-premises sign is located, any and all on-premises signs on such premises shall be made to conform to all applicable requirements of this chapter. 
(Code 1996, § 4.1411)  
Sec. 42-12. - Prohibited use of signs. 
(a)	Signs not to be posted on or to public property. It shall be unlawful for any sign other than official signs erected by the city, county, independent school district, state or railway company to be placed or caused to be placed, painted, printed, posted or affixed in any manner, any picture, bill, sign or other advertising matter whatsoever on any curb, sidewalk, pavement, telephone pole, electric pole, traffic signal standard or pole or other public improvement in any public street or grounds, or upon any bridge, overpass, underpass or parts of the same, median, esplanade, road right-of-way or public utility easement, traffic island, or public building, structure or erection of any type belonging to the city. 
(b)	No sign shall resemble an official sign. No sign shall be constructed which resembles any official marker erected by the city, state or any governmental agency or which by reason of position, shape or color would conflict with the proper functioning of any traffic sign, signal or which by its shape or color would conflict with or be confused with emergency vehicle lights, especially blinking lights. Use of words such as "stop," "look," or "danger," or any other word, phrase, symbol or character in such a manner as to interfere with, mislead or confuse traffic is prohibited. 
(c)	Sign not to interfere with official signs. Signs may not be located or illuminated in such a manner as to obscure or otherwise interfere with the effectiveness of an official traffic sign, signal or device, or so as to obstruct or interfere with the view of a driver or approaching, emerging or intersection traffic. All such signs shall comply with the provisions of this chapter. 
(d)	Proper shielding of lighted signals; interference with drivers of motor vehicles. Signs containing lights which are not effectively shielded as to prevent beams or rays of light from being directed at any portion of the traveled way from which the sign is primarily viewed and which are of such intensity or brilliance as to cause glare or to impair the vision of the driver of any motor vehicles, or which otherwise interfere with any driver's operation of a motor vehicle, are prohibited. 
(e)	Spectacular signs. The following types of spectacular signs shall be deemed prohibited: 
(1)	Signs with strobe, rotating strobe or blinking strobe lights. 
(2)	Signs with flashing spotlights, or blinking spotlights shall not be operated in a capacity which will interfere with traffic. 
(3)	Automatically changeable advertising signs with more than one message which changes every three seconds. 
(4)	Flashing lights with bulbs of greater than 15 watts. 
(5)	Spectacular signs placed perpendicular to the roadway with the exception of automatically changeable advertising as regulated above. 
(f)	Signs not to obstruct egress. 
(1)	No sign shall be erected, constructed or maintained so as to obstruct any means of egress, or any opening necessary for required light, ventilation or fire fighting or for escape from the premises, or so as to prevent free passage from one part of a roof to any other part thereof. 
(2)	No sign shall be attached to any exterior stairway, fire escape, fire tower balcony or balcony serving as a horizontal exit. 
(3)	No sign shall be erected, constructed. or maintained so as to interfere with the operation of a counterbalanced section of a fire escape, and no projecting sign shall be erected, constructed or maintained without a minimum of seven feet of clearance over any such counterbalanced section. 
(4)	No sign shall obstruct the free use of any window above the first story. 
(g)	Emitting signs prohibited. No emitting sign shall be permitted and are strictly prohibited at any location within the city. 
(h)	Signs employing motion picture machines. No sign shall employ a stereopticon or motion picture machine. 
(i)	Signs not to create easements. No permit for a sign extending beyond private property onto a public street, public sidewalks or public alley shall constitute a permanent easement, and every such permit shall be revocable at any time by action of the city commission. The city shall not be liable for any damages to the owner by reason of such revocation. The only time such a permit shall be issued shall be in the case of a projecting sign extending over a public sidewalk when such sidewalk abuts the front of the building to which the projecting sign is attached. Nor shall any sign by virtue of its longevity create an interest in real property by limitations or otherwise. 
(j)	Vision restrictions prohibited. Any sign that restricts vision necessary for safety is prohibited. If such a sign is erected and it does restrict vision so as to be a safety hazard it will be removed or modified to correct such restriction and eliminate the hazard. It is the responsibility of the person owning and erecting the sign to ensure that the sign does not create such a hazard. The following are guidelines to construction to prevent such restrictions of vision: 
(1)	Any sign over pedestrian traffic shall be no lower than eight feet above the pedestrian surface. 
(2)	Any sign over passenger vehicle traffic shall be no lower than ten feet above the vehicular traffic surface. 
(3)	Any sign over general vehicular traffic shall be no lower than 14 feet six inches above the traffic surface. 
(4)	Any sign which obstructs vision within the sight triangle. 
(k)	Obscene signs prohibited . No obscene sign shall be permitted. 
(Code 1996, § 4.1412)  
Sec. 42-13. - On-premises and off-premises sign regulations. 
(a)	General requirements. 
(1)	No sign in sight triangle. All ground signs discussed in this section shall not be placed in the sight triangle as defined herein, and shall not be placed in or extend into a public street, easement or right-of-way. 
(2)	Shall not obstruct view. No sign shall in any way obstruct the view of traffic over the sight triangle or as defined in this chapter. 
(3)	Roof sign clearance. Roof signs must have one foot of open space between the roofline and the bottom of the sign and three feet of open space shall be required between the sign structure and the edge of the roof and between sign structures. 
(b)	Height restrictions. No billboard may be erected that exceeds an overall height of 22½ feet, excluding cutouts extending above the rectangular border, measured from the highest point on the sign to the ground level of the ground. A roof sign may not at any point exceed 25 feet above the roof level. 
(c)	Face restrictions. 
(1)	No business may have more than five faces per on-premises location except for wall signs. For signs on a double-faced, back-to-back, four-sided or V-type nature, each face is considered a separate sign in computing the face area. A curved surface sign shall be considered as three faces and a circular sign shall be considered as four faces. Those five signs may not exceed in total face area the greater of: 
a.	Three hundred square feet; or 
b.	One percent of the total useable square feet of the building plus one square foot for each linear foot of frontage on the adjacent streets. 
The total area of all wall signs shall not exceed 20 percent of the area of the wall of building below roofline. 
(2)	No off-premises billboard shall exceed 672 square feet plus cutouts as herein provided. 
(d)	Size and quantity of types restrictions. Total number of on-premises signs allowed at any one business shall not exceed five except for wall signs. The maximum of the individual types of categories of signs are as follows: 
(1)	One portable sign for not more than 60 days a year or one improved portable sign. 
(2)	One monument sign, maximum of 60 square feet each side. 
(3)	Two monument signs if the business has frontage on two roads with a total street frontage of 300 feet or more. 
(4)	One marquee sign. 
(5)	Two canopy signs. 
(6)	One ground sign per separate street frontage. 
(e)	Cutout areas permitted. Exclusions or appendages (cutouts) shall not exceed 20 percent of the total sign face area and shall not exceed five additional feet in height or three feet of additional width. 
(f)	Spacing. No off-premises sign will be placed within 1,500 feet of another sign subject to the provisions hereof. No on-premises pole sign shall be erected within 500 feet of a pole sign for the same business on the same street, except each business within the limit of five signs shall be permitted one sign for each street frontage. 
(g)	Movable signs. Movable signs in addition to all other regulations herein contained shall observe the following rules applicable to the installation and operation of moveable signs. 
(1)	The number of moveable signs allowed for the first street of frontage is one moveable sign. 
(2)	One additional moveable sign will be allowed for each additional street that adjoins the business. 
(h)	Subdivision signs. Only one off-premises sign with the name of the subdivision and directions thereto will be permitted in addition to the one exempt sign for a residential subdivision situated within the city limits that has been approved by the city and duly platted and recorded in the records of the county. The size of such sign inclusive of all sides shall not exceed a total of 70 square feet. Such sign is allowed for a maximum period of two years and shall be promptly removed at the end of the two-year period. If the subdivision is less than 95 percent sold, the sign may be re-permitted for two years. 
(i)	Location. No off-premises sign shall be located in a primarily residential area. 
(j)	Relocation, removal and construction. 
(1)	Relocation of off-premises signs will be permitted only in the case of a governmental taking of the land used for the sign location and no compensation paid to the sign owner. 
(2)	The owner of the billboard or portable sign must obtain a site for relocation of the billboard or portable sign within one month of removal and construction or placement must be completed within 90 days thereafter. 
(3)	The city will only permit reconstruction if the sign proposed to be constructed will be in compliance with all the provisions of this chapter. 
(4)	Removal of any sign may be required if, in the opinion of the sign administrator, the sign unnecessarily distracts motorists, hinders the view of the natural landscape or although grandfatherered is still in too close of proximity to other signs. 
(k)	Off-premises signs on private property. No person shall place an off-premises sign on private property without the consent of the owner or agent for the owner of said private property. Further, no person shall place an off-premises portable sign on private property without the authorized written notarized consent of the owner or agent for the owner of said private property. 
(l)	Accumulation of rainwater prohibited. All signs shall be designed, constructed and maintained to prevent the accumulation of rainwater in or on the sign. 
(m)	Garage sale signs. All garage sale signs shall be governed by the existing ordinance which is incorporated herein and made a part hereof for all purposes. 
(Code 1996, § 4.1413)  
Sec. 42-14. - Structural requirements; generally and for specific signs. 
(a)	Design. 
(1)	General. 
a.	All sites and sign structures shall be designed and constructed to resist wind forces as specified in this section. All bracing systems shall be designed and constructed to transfer lateral forces to the foundations. For signs on building the dead and lateral loads shall be transmitted through the structural frame of the building to the ground in such manner as not to over stress any of the elements thereof. 
b.	The overturning movement produced from lateral forces shall in no case exceed two-thirds of the dead load resisting movement for all signs. Uplift due to overturning shall be adequately resisted by proper anchorage to the ground or to the structural frame of the building for all signs. The weight of earth superimposed over footing may be used in determining the dead-load resisting movement. Such earth shall be carefully placed and thoroughly compacted. 
(2)	Wind loads. All signs and sign structures shall be designed to resist wind loads as follows: 
Wind Load Pressures in Pounds Per Square Foot for All Signs 
Height Above Ground*, Feet 	Pressure Pounds/Ft2 
0—50 	30 
51—99 	35 
 
*Measured above the average level of the ground adjacent to the structure 
(3)	Vertical design loads. Vertical design loads, except roof live loads, shall be assumed to be acting simultaneously with the wind loads. 
(4)	Working stresses. All signs shall be designed to conform with the requirements of the any building and construction technical code as adopted by reference by the city in the building and construction chapter of this Code regarding allowable working stresses. The working strength of chains, cables, guys or steel rods shall not exceed one-fifth of the ultimate strength of such chains, cables, guys or steel rods. 
(5)	Registered engineer's seal. All commercially erected signs over 12 feet shall be approved by a professional registered engineer registered in the state and all plans shall contain the engineer's seal. 
(b)	Construction. 
(1)	General. The supports for all signs or sign structures shall be placed in or upon private property and shall be securely built, constructed and erected in conformance with the requirements of the any building and construction technical code as adopted by reference by the city in the building and construction chapter of this Code. 
(2)	Materials. Materials for construction of all signs and sign structures shall be of the quality and grade as specified for buildings in the any building and construction technical code as adopted by reference by the city in the building and construction chapter of this Code. Notwithstanding any of those provisions to the contrary, examples of approved sign face materials are lexan, acrylic, MDO duraply and luster. 
(3)	Nonstructural trim. Nonstructural trim and portable display surface may be of wood, metal, approved plastics, or any combination thereof, consistent with any building and construction technical code as adopted by reference by the city in the building and construction chapter of this Code. 
(4)	Anchorage. Members supporting unbraced signs shall be so proportioned that the bearing loads imposed on the soil in either direction, horizontal or vertical, shall not exceed the safe values load specified in subsection (a)(2) of this section acting in any direction. Anchors and supports shall be designed for safe bearing loads on the soil and for an effective resistance to pull out amounting to a force 25 percent greater than the required resistance to overturning. 
(c)	Electrical requirements. All electrical fixtures, equipment and appurtenances installed in conjunction with a sign shall be designed and installed in accordance with the city electrical code as it now exists or may hereinafter be amended. 
(d)	Clearances. 
(1)	Clearances from high voltage power lines. Signs shall be located a minimum distance of 12 feet measured horizontally and 12 feet measured vertically from overhead electrical conductors commonly called distributions lines, and a minimum distance of five feet measured horizontally and five feet measured vertically from what are commonly called service drop lines. The term "electrical conductors," as used in this subsection, means any electrical conductor, either bare or insulated, installed above the ground. 
(2)	Clearance from poles. No sign shall be erected nearer than five feet horizontally or eight feet vertically from any telephone pole or cable pole or cross-member of that pole. 
(e)	Exempt signs, not exempt from this section. No sign which is otherwise exempt is exempt from the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1996, § 4.1414)  
Sec. 42-15. - Portable signs. 
(a)	Standards. Portable signs for the purpose of this chapter shall be subject to all provisions of this chapter, including the structural requirements, spacing requirements, permitting and fee requirements, insurance and bonding requirements and all other provisions of this chapter applicable to ground signs, unless a provision specifically includes or excludes a portable sign. 
(b)	Maintenance. The area where any portable sign is located must be maintained and kept clean by the owner. Grass will be cut a minimum of six feet from said sign on all sides and entirely to the street curb of the side nearest the street and debris etc. will be removed at least every seven days.
