(c)	Number on premises. Each business will be allowed one on-premises improved portable sign or one portable on-premises sign displayed for no more than 60 days per calendar year and meets all requirements of this chapter. 
(d)	Electrical. No portable sign may contain electrical components unless it fully meets the city electrical code. Extension cords may not be laid across any sidewalk, driveway or any other line of traffic. 
(e)	Size. No portable sign shall exceed in outside dimension 6½ feet vertical or 12½ feet horizontal. The advertising space on each side shall not exceed 72 square feet or a dimension of six feet by 12 feet. 
(f)	City permit is not an endorsement. Any approval of a sign or its structure by the city is not a verification or endorsement of the worthiness of the sign and any failure of the sign or its structure is strictly the responsibility of the owner, operator, designer or person erecting the sign and its structure. 
(g)	The sanitation division is designated to assist in removals. The sanitation division of the public works department is designated as the division of the city government to assist and aid the sign administrator in the removal of signs. The sign administrator shall make a request in writing on forms provided and prepared by him to the sanitation division indicating the sign and its location and the location to which it is to be removed. 
(h)	Signs advertising an event of a non profit organization. City functions and government entities will be permitted to display their signs not over 60 days prior to the event without permit provided the signs meet all other requirements of this chapter. 
(i)	Official state historical signs and markers. Official state historical signs and markers are exempt from the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1996, § 4.1415; Ord. of 5-15-2001)  
Chapter 46 - SUBDIVISION REGULATIONS 
(RESERVED)  
Chapter 50 - TAXATION  
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 50-1. - Penalty for delinquent taxes. 
The city hereby adopts the provisions of Texas Tax Code § 33.01 et seq., to defray costs of collection of delinquent taxes. 
(Code 1996, art. 1.1100; Res. No. R09-2000, 5-2-2000) 
State Law reference— Imposition of penalty for collection of delinquent taxes, Texas Tax Code § 33.01 et seq.  
Sec. 50-2. - Goods in transit. 
All such goods in transit personal property as covered by Texas Tax Code § 11.253 shall be, and are hereby declared to be, taxable by the city for every year, all as provided for and in accordance with Texas Tax Code § 11.253. 
(Code 1996, art. 1.1900; Ord. of 2011-04, 10-11-2011) 
State Law reference— Tax exemption for goods in transit, Texas Tax Code § 11.253.  
Secs. 50-3—50-22. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - LOCAL OPTION MUNICIPAL SALES AND USE TAX[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Municipal Sales and Use Tax Act, Texas Tax Code § 321.001 et seq. 
 
Sec. 50-23. - Adoption. 
There is hereby enacted a one percent local sales tax to be collected by the state along with the state sales tax. 
(Code 1996, § 1.701) 
Editor's note— This section was approved by referendum in December, 1968.  
Sec. 50-24. - Exemptions. 
(a)	There is hereby exempted from the one percent city sales tax, residential use of gas and electricity by consumers within the territorial limits of the city, to become effective on October 1, 1978. 
(b)	As provided in this exemption, the term "residential use" means use of gas and electricity in a family dwelling, a multifamily apartment, a housing complex or building or portion of a building occupied as a home or residence within the city limits. 
(Code 1975, § 1-6; Code 1996, § 1.702)  
Secs. 50-25—50-51. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - AD VALOREM TAX EXEMPTIONS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Residence homestead exemptions, Texas Tax Code § 11.13. 
 
Sec. 50-52. - Residence homestead tax exemption for the elderly. 
(a)	There is hereby granted to the resident home owners of the city, who are 65 years of age by January 1 of each year, a property tax exemption in the sum of $30,000.00 of the assessed evaluation of said resident homestead. 
(b)	Said property owners should make application for said tax exemption with the city tax collector between January 1 and April 30 of each year and present proof of age and ownership of said property. 
(Code 1996, § 1.801; Res. No. R08-2013, § 1, 9-3-2013)  
Sec. 50-53. - Residence homestead tax exemption for the disabled. 
(a)	There is hereby granted to the resident home owners of the city, who are disabled as of January 1, of each year, a property tax exemption in the sum of $30,000.00 of the assessed evaluation of said resident homestead. 
(b)	The term "disabled" means under a disability for purposes of payment of disability insurance benefits under Federal Old-Age, Survivors and Disability Insurance. 
(c)	Said property owners should make application for said tax exemption with the city tax collector between January 1 and April 30 of each year and present proof of disability and ownership of said property. 
(Code 1975, Ch. 1, § 7; Code 1996, § 2-1.802; Res. No. R08-2013, § 1, 9-3-2013)  
Sec. 50-54. - Tax freeze for residential homestead property owners of the city who are disabled or 65 years of age or older. 
(a)	Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Disabled has the same meaning as set forth in Texas Tax Code § 11.13(m)(1), as it currently exists or may be amended. 
Residence homestead has the same meaning as set forth in Texas Tax Code § 11.13(j)(1), as it currently exists or may be amended. 
Tax code means the Texas Tax Code as it currently exists or may be amended. 
(b)	Residence homestead tax freeze for elderly or disabled people. 
(1)	There is hereby created and established a tax freeze on the amount of property taxes imposed by the city on the homesteads of disabled individuals or individuals age 65 or older, which shall be governed by Texas Tax Code § 11.261, as follows: 
a.	The tax freeze shall become effective beginning with the 2004 tax year, and shall remain effective for each successive tax year until otherwise amended or repealed by the city commission or other appropriate authority. 
b.	The total amount of ad valorem taxes imposed on the residence homesteads of a person who qualified that residence homestead for the exemption in accordance with the tax code as that of a person who is disabled or is 65 years of age or older shall not be increased while it remains the residence homestead of that person or that person's spouse who is disabled or 65 years of age or older. 
c.	If the person who is disabled or is 65 years of age or older dies in a year in which the person received a residence homestead exemption, the total amount of ad valorem taxes imposed on the residence homestead shall not be increased while it remains the residence homestead of that person's surviving spouse if: 
1.	The surviving spouse is 55 years of age or older at the time of the person's death; 
2.	The residence homestead of the deceased person is also the residence homestead of the surviving spouse on the date of the person's death; and 
3.	The residence homestead remains the residence homestead of the surviving spouse. 
d.	Notwithstanding anything contained herein, taxes on the residence homestead may be increased to the extent the value of the homestead is increased by improvements other than repairs and other than improvements made to comply with governmental requirements. 
e.	An improvement to property that would otherwise constitute an improvement is not treated as an improvement if the improvement is a replacement structure for a structure that was rendered uninhabitable or unusable by a casualty or by wind or water damage. For purposes of appraising the property in the tax year in which the structure would have constituted an improvement, the replacement structure is considered to be an improvement under that subsection only if: 
1.	The square footage of the replacement structure exceeds that of the replaced structure as that structure existed before the casualty or damage occurred; or 
2.	The exterior of the replacement structure is of higher quality construction and composition than that of the replaced structure. 
f.	A person may not receive freeze taxes for more than one residence homestead, no matter where located, in the same year. A person may designate a new residence homestead within the city in accordance with the tax code. 
(2)	The limitation on taxes provided by this section may expire in accordance with Texas Tax Code § 11.261(d). If a tax limitation is erroneously allowed, back taxes may be assessed in accordance with Texas Tax Code § 11.261(e). 
(Code 1996, § 1.803; Ord. No. 2004-01, 2-3-2004)  
Chapter 54 - TRAFFIC CONTROL[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Rules of the Road, Texas Transportation Code § 541.001 et seq.; powers of local authorities regarding regulation of traffic, Texas Transportation Code § 542.202; limitations on local authorities, Texas Transportation Code § 542.203. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 54-1. - Definitions. 
(a)	The definitions contained in state traffic laws and in the manual on uniform traffic control devices shall be applicable to the words and phrases used in this Code, except the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
Alley means any narrow street having no legal or official name other than alley. 
Business district includes every block in which the greater portion of the street frontage is used for commercial or business purposes. 
Holidays includes only such holidays as are designated by the city commission. 
One-way street means any street or highway on which traffic is restricted to movement in one direction only. 
Safety zones means areas or spaces set apart within a roadway for the exclusive use of pedestrians pursuant to authority from the city commission, wherein vehicular parking or movement is prohibited. 
Taxicab stand means that portion of a street set aside, pursuant to authority from the city commission, for the use of taxicabs licensed as such by the city. 
(b)	The definitions set forth in Texas Transportation Code § 541.001 et seq. (Rules of the Road - Definitions), as amended, shall be effective as definitions of the words, terms and phrases used in this chapter. All words, terms and phrases used herein, other than those specifically defined elsewhere in this chapter, shall have the respective meanings ascribed to them in Texas Transportation Code § 541.001 et seq., as amended, and shall have the same scope and effect that the same words, terms and phrases have where used in Texas Transportation Code § 541.001 et seq., as amended. 
(Code 1975, § 9-1; Code 1996, § 10.100)  
Sec. 54-2. - Vehicles not to drive on fresh pavement. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to drive any vehicle or ride any horse or other animal upon any portion of the streets in the city that has been freshly paved, unless all barriers or signal lights have been lawfully removed therefrom indicating that said street is ready for travel. 
(Code 1996, § 10.801)  
Sec. 54-3. - Unlawful to store property on street. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to permit any junk, property, object or obstruction of any kind whatsoever under his control to be or remain in or upon any public street or sidewalk of the city, so as to obstruct or prevent the free use of an established public or private driveway or sidewalk or entrance from such street into any public or private place or property. 
(Code 1996, § 10.802)  
Sec. 54-4. - Delivery of bottled beverages prohibited at certain times. 
The operation of automobiles, trucks, horse-drawn trucks or any other character of vehicle upon the streets of the city for the transportation or delivery, wholesale or retail, to residences, places of business or other points within the city limits, of bottled milk or milk products or other forms of bottled foods, beverages or drinks or any empty bottles used in connection with such foods between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m., is hereby prohibited; provided that individual deliveries by drugstores, restaurants and grocery stores in response to specific orders, placed within two hours before such delivery, may be made notwithstanding this section. The provisions of this section, however, shall not apply to trucks or other vehicles entering or leaving the city for the purpose of transporting such bottled goods, beer or malt liquors as are above enumerated to or from points outside the city; provided that the loading or unloading of such long-haul trucks or other vehicles shall require not more than three stops within the city limits. 
(Code 1996, § 10.803)  
Sec. 54-5. - Erecting detour or barricade signs. 
Contractors or other persons authorized to erect detour or barricade signs on streets before, during or after construction work shall, before erecting such detour or barricade signs, obtain the written permission of the traffic director to do so, who shall notify the chief of the fire department, the chief of the police department and the head of the street and bridge department immediately upon granting such permission. 
(Code 1975, § 9-8; Code 1996, § 10.804)  
Sec. 54-6. - Garage keeper to report damaged vehicle. 
The person in charge of any garage or repair shop to which is brought any motor vehicle which shows evidence of having been involved in an accident or struck by any bullet shall file written report of same with the police department within 24 hours after such vehicle is received and before any repairs have been made, giving the make of car, engine number and name and address of the person representing himself as being in charge of said vehicle. 
(Code 1975, § 9-8; Code 1996, § 10.805)  
Sec. 54-7. - Failure to appear for trial. 
It shall be unlawful for any person knowingly to fail to appear for the trial of any charge against such person pending in the corporation court of the city. 
(Code 1996, § 10.806)  
Sec. 54-8. - Unnecessary to deny exceptions, etc., in complaint or indictment. 
In any complaint, information or indictment, and in any action or proceeding brought for the enforcement of any provisions of this chapter, it shall not be necessary to deny any exception, excuse, proviso or exemption contained in this chapter, and such exception, excuse, proviso or exemption shall be a matter of defense that must be claimed by a defendant, and the burden of proving such defense shall be on defendant. 
(Code 1996, § 10.807)  
Sec. 54-9. - Knowledge of ordinances. 
It shall be the duty of every police officer to thoroughly acquaint himself with provisions of all of the traffic code and to assist all persons using the streets of the city to become acquainted and to comply therewith. 
(Code 1996, § 10.808)  
Sec. 54-10. - Enforcement of ordinances. 
It shall be the duty of the police department of the city to enforce all of the terms and provisions of all ordinances and laws regulating traffic. 
(Code 1996, § 10.809)  
Sec. 54-11. - Special orders. 
The chief of police or any police officer of the city, in case of necessity or emergency or of congestion by traffic, may make such special orders to pedestrians or to drivers of vehicles as in his judgment may be necessary to meet the emergency or relieve the congestion. 
(Code 1996, § 10.810)  
Sec. 54-12. - Arrest without warrant. 
Any police officer of the city shall have the power and is hereby authorized to arrest, without a warrant of arrest being first issued, any person who violates any ordinance of the city in the presence of or within the view of such arresting officer. Any such officer may also arrest without warrant any person whom said officer has probable cause to believe has recently committed a violation of any such ordinance. 
(Code 1975, § 9-8; Code 1996, § 10.811)  
Sec. 54-13. - Riding or driving animals in parks and city recreation areas. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to ride or drive any horse, mule or livestock of any character, upon, over or across the grounds of any public park, playground or other recreational facility in the city, including public school campuses. Nothing herein shall be construed to prohibit riders of horses or mules from riding or driving along roadways, driveways, streets or other areas designated for such use in said public parks, playgrounds, or other recreational facilities, including public school campuses. 
(Code 1975, § 9-10; Code 1996, art. 10.1000)  
Sec. 54-14. - Riding or driving motor vehicles upon public lands. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to ride or drive a motor vehicle, as herein defined, upon, over or across the grounds of any public park, playgrounds or other recreational facility, including public school campuses; or upon any esplanade within the city limits. Nothing herein shall be construed to prohibit riding or driving any vehicle licensed by the state along roadways, driveways or streets through park grounds. The term "motor vehicles," as used in this chapter, means any vehicle which is, or can be, self-propelled. 
(Code 1975, § 9-11; Code 1996, art. 10.1100)  
Sec. 54-15. - Street names. 
(a)	Where a duplication exists in a street's name, the city will change the name of that street where the least amount of people will be affected. 
(b)	Approval of the county planning commission will be obtained before any change in a street name is adopted. 
(c)	Where the street bears a number such as 1st Street, 2nd Street and 3rd Street or an alphabetical designation such as "A" Street, "B" Street and "C" Street, where it is practical and possible, a preface will be added to the name of said street. In the city, the streets will be known as Galena "A," Galena "B," and Galena "C," or Galena 1st, Galena 2nd and Galena 3rd. 
(d)	Any street which has been dedicated but not fully developed with a duplicated name will be changed immediately by the governing body. 
(e)	Where two streets are connected and the two streets become one street, then a single name will be given the two streets provided the streets are a continuation of each. 
(f)	Before changing the names of any streets, the city will request from the post office a recommendation as to such change. 
(g)	Changes of identical duplications will be given priority. For example, where two streets are spelled the same, the governing body will attempt to change these streets before changing two streets that are spelled differently but that are pronounced the same. 
(h)	The city commission recommends the placing of house numbers on the house and on the curbline. 
(Code 1975, § 1-12; Code 1996, art. 10.1300)  
Sec. 54-16. - Registration of bicycles. 
(a)	It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or use a bicycle propelled wholly or in part by muscular power upon any of the streets, alleys or public highways of the city without first obtaining from the police department a license therefor. 
(b)	The police department is hereby authorized and directed to issue, upon written application, bicycle licenses, and said licenses shall be issued for the calendar year commencing on January 1 of each of said calendar years and ending on December 31 of said calendar year. Said licenses when issued shall entitle the licensee to operate such bicycle for which said license has been issued, upon all streets, alleys and public highways, exclusive of the sidewalks thereof, in the city. 
(c)	The city shall provide each year metallic license plates and seals, together with registration cards and holders therefor, said metallic license plates and registration cards having numbers stamped thereon in numerical order, beginning with Number 1, and indicating the year for which the same are issued, and the letters GPBL stamped thereon; such metallic license plates shall be suitable for attachment upon the frames of bicycles, and it shall be the duty of the police department to attach one such metallic license plate to the frame of each bicycle and to issue a corresponding registration card to the licensee upon the payment of the license fee herein provided for. Such metallic license plate shall remain attached during the existence of such license. The police department shall also keep a record of the date of issue of each license, to whom issued, and the number thereof. 
(d)	All persons engaged in the business of buying secondhand bicycles are hereby required to make daily report to the police department, giving the name and address of the person from whom each bicycle is purchased, the description of each bicycle purchased, the frame number thereof, and the number of the metallic license plate found thereon, if any. All persons engaged in the business of selling new or secondhand bicycles are hereby required to make a daily report to the police department, giving a list of all sales made by such dealer, which list shall include the name and address of each person to whom sold, the kind of bicycle sold, together with a description and frame number thereof, and the number of the metallic license plate attached thereto, if any. 
(e)	It shall be the duty of every person who sells or transfers ownership of any bicycle to report such sale or transfer by returning to the police department the registration card issued to such person as licensee thereof, together with the name and address of the person to whom said bicycle was sold or transferred, and such report shall be made within five days of the date of said sale or transfer. It shall be the duty of the purchaser or transferee of such bicycle to apply for a transfer of registration therefor within five days of said sale or transfer. 
(f)	It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully or maliciously remove, destroy, mutilate or alter the number of any bicycle frame licensed pursuant to this section. It shall also be unlawful for any person to remove, destroy, mutilate or alter any license plate, seal or registration card during the time in which such license plate, seal or registration card is operative. Provided, however, that nothing in this section shall prohibit the police department from stamping numbers on the frames of bicycles on which no serial number can be found, or on which said number is illegible or insufficient for identification purposes. 
(g)	The annual license fee to be paid for each bicycle shall be as provided for in the fee schedule and shall be paid in advance. All license fees collected under this section shall be paid into the general fund of the city. 
(h)	It shall be unlawful for any person to ride or propel a bicycle on the streets, alleys and public highways of the city not equipped with lights or reflectors that cannot be seen at a distance of 100 feet during the night time. 
(Code 1975, § 9-14; Code 1996, § 10.1400)  
Sec. 54-17. - [Motor vehicle idling limitations.] 
It shall be unlawful for an owner or operator of a motor vehicle, with gross vehicle weight rating of more than 14,000 pounds, operated within the City of Galena Park, Texas, to cause or allow the engine of the vehicle to idle for more than five minutes when the vehicle is not in motion. Provide however, it shall be an affirmative defense for which the underlying prohibited does not apply including: 
(1)	A vehicle that is equipped with a 2008 or subsequent model year heavy-duty diesel engine or liquefied or compressed natural gas engine that has been certified by the United States Environmental Protection Agency or another state environmental agency to emit no more than 30 grams of nitrogen oxides emission per hour when idling; 
(2)	A motor vehicle force to remain motionless because of traffic conditions over which the operator has no control; 
(3)	The engine of a motor vehicle that is being used to supply heat or air conditioning necessary for passengers comfort and safety in vehicles intended for commercial or public passengers transportation, or passenger transit operations, in which case idling up to a maximum of 15 minutes is allowed; 
(4)	The engine of a motor vehicle being used to provide air conditioning or heating necessary for employee health or safety in an armored vehicle while the employee remains inside the vehicle to guard the contents while the vehicle is being loaded or unloaded. 
(5)	The engine motor vehicle being used to provide air conditioning or heating necessary for employee health or safety while the employee is using the vehicle to perform an essential job function related to roadway construction or maintenance; 
(6)	The engine of a motor vehicle providing a power source necessary for mechanical operations, other than propulsion and/or passengers compartment heating, or air conditioning; 
(7)	The engine of a motor vehicle being operated for maintenance or diagnostic purposes; 
(8)	The engine of a motor vehicle being operated solely to defrost a windshield; 
(9)	The engine of a motor vehicle being used as airport ground support equipment; 
(10)	The owner of the motor vehicle rented or leased to a person that operates the vehicle and is not employed by the owner; or 
(11)	The motor vehicle when idling is necessary to power a heater or air conditioner while a driver is using the vehicle's sleeper berth for government-mandated rest period and is not within two miles of a facility offering external heating and air conditioning connections at a time when those connections are available. 
(Ord. No. 2015-13, § 1, 10-20-2015) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2015-13, § 1, adopted Oct. 20, 2015, did not specify manner of inclusion, hence, codification as § 54-17 was at the discretion of the editor.  
Secs. 54-18—54-35. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - OBEDIENCE TO TRAFFIC REGULATIONS 
 
Sec. 54-36. - Required obedience to traffic regulations. 
It shall be unlawful and an offense for any person to perform any act forbidden or fail to perform any act required in this Code. 
(Code 1996, § 10.201)  
Sec. 54-37. - Obedience to police. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully fail or refuse to comply with any lawful order or direction of a police officer pertaining to the movement of traffic or pedestrians on the public streets, whether given in person or by means of visible or audible signals. 
(Code 1996, § 10.202)  
Sec. 54-38. - Exemptions to authorized emergency vehicles. 
(a)	The provisions of this Code regulating the operation, parking and standing of vehicles shall apply to authorized emergency vehicles, as defined in this article, other than vehicles of the police and fire departments, except as follows: 
(b)	A driver when operating any such vehicle in an emergency, except when otherwise directed by a police officer, may: 
(1)	Park or stand notwithstanding the provisions of this Code; 
(2)	Proceed past a red or stop signal or stop sign, but only after slowing down as may be necessary for safe operation; 
(3)	Exceed a maximum speed limit, except as provided by an ordinance adopted under Texas Transportation Code § 545.365, as long as the operator does not endanger life or property; and 
(4)	Disregard regulations governing direction of movement or turning in specified direction, so long as he does not endanger life or property. 
(c)	The foregoing exemptions shall not, however, protect the driver of any such vehicle from the consequences of his reckless disregard of the safety of others. Notwithstanding any other provision of this Code, vehicles of the police and fire departments of the city, while sounding a siren or bell, shall have the right-of-way over all other vehicles, and, at such times, all ordinances and regulations pertaining to official traffic signals, stop signs or official traffic control devices shall not apply to such police and fire department vehicles. 
(Code 1996, § 10.203)  
Sec. 54-39. - Persons propelling push carts or riding bicycles or animals to obey traffic regulations. 
Every person propelling any push cart or riding a bicycle or an animal upon a roadway, and every person driving any animal-driven vehicle or any type of vehicle whatever, whether named herein or not, shall be subject to the provisions of this Code, except those which by their nature can have no application. 
(Code 1996, § 10.204)  
Sec. 54-40. - State traffic laws. 
Texas Transportation Code ch. 541 et seq., as amended, and all other state laws applicable to motor vehicles and to traffic regulations within the city are hereby adopted in full and may be considered as included in the city traffic code. 
(Code 1975, § 9-2; Code 1996, § 10.205)  
Secs. 54-41—54-68. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Authority to regulate parking, Texas Transportation Code § 542.202(a)(2). 
 
Sec. 54-69. - Parking prohibited on certain streets. 
When signs designating an area where parking is prohibited are erected or placed pursuant to authority from the city commission on any street, bridge or parkway in the city, no person shall park a vehicle in any such designated place. 
(Code 1996, § 10.301)  
Sec. 54-70. - Parking prohibited in certain places. 
No person shall stop, stand or park any vehicle upon a street, other than an alley, in such a manner or under such conditions as to leave available less than ten feet of the width of the roadway for free movement of vehicular traffic, except that a driver may stop temporarily during the actual loading or unloading of passengers or when necessary in obedience to traffic regulations or traffic signs or signals of a police officer. No person shall park a vehicle within an alley in such a manner or under such conditions as to leave available less than ten feet of the width of the roadway for the free movement of vehicular traffic. 
(Code 1996, § 10.302)  
Sec. 54-71. - Parking prohibited during certain hours in designated places. 
When signs are erected or curbs or streets painted pursuant to authority from the city commission, prohibiting parking during designated hours in the area thus marked, it shall be unlawful and an offense for any person or driver or owner to park or stand any vehicle, or for any owner knowingly to suffer or permit any driver of any vehicle belonging to such owner, to park or stand the same at the place and during the hours so designated, except Sundays and holidays and after 6:00 p.m. on any day. 
(Code 1996, § 10.303)  
Sec. 54-72. - Parking time limited in designated places. 
When signs are erected or curbs or streets painted or parking meters installed giving notice of time limits for the parking of vehicles, it shall be unlawful and an offense for a person to park a vehicle for a longer period of time than that designated on the signs, streets or curb markings or parking meters. 
(Code 1996, § 10.304)  
Sec. 54-73. - Standing for loading only. 
It is prohibited and shall be unlawful and an offense for a person to stop, stand or park any vehicle for any purpose or period of time other than for the expeditious loading or unloading of passengers, in any place marked as a passenger loading zone, between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. of any day, and then only for a period not to exceed two minutes, except Sundays and legal holidays. It shall be unlawful for any person to park or stand any vehicle other than a commercial vehicle in any truck loading zone between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. No person shall park or stand any commercial vehicle in any truck loading zone between such hours except for the purpose of unloading and delivery, or pickup and loading of materials. In no case shall such stop exceed 30 minutes unless otherwise designated by appropriate signs or markings. This section shall not apply on Sundays or legal holidays. 
(Code 1996, § 10.305)  
Sec. 54-74. - Bus stops and taxicab stands. 
The driver of a bus or taxicab shall not stand or park the vehicle operated by him upon any street in any business district at any place other than at a bus stop or taxicab stand, respectively, except that this provision shall not prevent the driver of any such vehicle from temporarily stopping in accordance with other stopping or parking regulations at any place for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading and unloading passengers. No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle other than a bus in a bus stop, or other than a taxicab in a taxicab stand, when any such stop or stand has been officially designated and appropriately marked, except for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading passengers when such stopping does not interfere with any bus or taxicab waiting to enter or about to enter such zone, and in no case shall the driver of a vehicle leave the same while it is in such bus stop or taxicab stand. 
(Code 1996, § 10.306)  
Sec. 54-75. - Methods of standing or parking. 
Except when necessary, in obedience to traffic regulations or traffic signs or signals or to avoid contact with another vehicle or a pedestrian, the driver of any vehicle shall not stop, stand or park such vehicle in a roadway other than parallel with the edge of the roadway, headed in the direction of traffic, and with the curb-side wheels of the vehicle within 18 inches of the edge of the roadway, and, if in any parking meter zone, such vehicle shall be parked with the hood of such vehicle along-side of or next to the parking meter; provided that other methods of parking than those above described shall be followed at places where such other methods are indicated by appropriate signs or markings. 
(Code 1996, § 10.307)  
Sec. 54-76. - Unlawful parking. 
No person shall stand or park a vehicle upon any roadway for the principal purpose of: 
(1)	Displaying it for sale. 
(2)	Washing, greasing, repairing or dismantling such vehicle, except for making repairs necessitated by the physical impossibility of removing such vehicle until such repairs have been made. 
(Code 1996, § 10.308)  
Sec. 54-77. - Stopping, standing or parking prohibited in specified places. 
No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a police officer or a traffic control device or marking, at any of the following places: 
(1)	Upon any street or at any place thereon, at any time when signs are erected or markings established showing a loading zone, unless it is a commercial vehicle, and in this case only for the purpose of loading and unloading as provided in this article. 
(2)	In front of the entrance or exit of any theater, hotel, inn or depot for a space of 30 feet immediately in front of said theaters, hotels, inns or depots and ten feet immediately in front of all other exits thereof. 
(3)	Within two blocks of any burning building or structure, nor shall any vehicle be driven or operated within two blocks of any burning building or structure except to drive away from said burning building, or when within four blocks of any burning building or structure, to drive past, either to the left or to the right of any vehicle, except to drive away from said building. These provisions, however, shall not apply to any member of the city fire department or police department or any city official when actually engaged in an official duty, or to the owner or other person directly interested in the building or structure on fire, or to the operators of public utility service cars and ambulances in the case of an emergency or to those persons who are assisting in the extinguishing of the fire, or in salvage. 
(Code 1996, § 10.310)  
Sec. 54-78. - Vehicles backed to curb. 
The driver of any horse-drawn vehicle backed to the curb for the purpose of loading or unloading is required to stand the horses parallel to the curb and headed in the direction of traffic. When an articulated vehicle of six wheels or more is backed to the curb for the purpose of unloading or loading, the front or tractor portion shall, as far as physically possible, be turned parallel to the curb and headed in the direction of traffic, and the rear or trailer portion shall be parked at an angle to the curb of not more than 45 degrees. 
(Code 1996, § 10.311)  
Sec. 54-79. - Maximum time trucks and trailers to be parked on-streets. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to leave, stand, or park a truck in excess of one ton and trailers, either attached or unattached to a motor vehicle, on the public streets of the city for a period of time in excess of two hours. Police are authorized and directed to have said vehicles towed away by private wreckers at the owner's expense. 
(Code 1996, § 10.312)  
Sec. 54-80. - Continuous parking in excess of 24 hours. 
It shall be unlawful for any person or any owner knowingly to leave standing in any public street, alley or other public place any vehicle, automobile, wagon or other character of private property unattended for a longer continuous period of time than 24 hours. 
(Code 1996, § 10.313)  
Sec. 54-81. - Manner of stopping, etc., at curb. 
No operator of a vehicle shall stop, stand or park the same with its left side nearer to the curb than its right side, except when it has been specifically provided otherwise on one-way streets now or hereafter designated. 
(Code 1996, § 10.314)  
Sec. 54-82. - Cut-back curbs. 
It shall be unlawful and an offense for any person to cut back any curb in front of any place or establishment for the purpose of providing individual parking space or parking space for the use of customers of such person without the consent of the city commission; provided that this article shall not apply where curbs heretofore have been cut back under authority granted by previous city ordinances, and at such locations parking may be at a 27½ degree angle to the curb, but in no event shall any portion of a parked vehicle extend more than six feet into the roadway from the curbline as it would exist in the absence of such a cut-back; and provided, further, that this article shall not be construed so as to prevent the owner or person in charge of any property from providing parking space for vehicles wholly on property owned or controlled by him if no part of the space thus provided includes any portion of the right-of-way of a street, and if such person otherwise complies with all valid ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1996, § 10.315)  
Sec. 54-83. - Owner and operator responsible for illegal parking. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, having registered in his name or owning or operating or having in charge any vehicle, knowingly to allow or suffer or permit same to stop, stand or be parked in any street in the city in violation of any of the ordinances of the city regulating the stopping, standing or parking of vehicles. 
(Code 1996, § 10.316)  
Sec. 54-84. - Presumption of parking by owner when car illegally parked. 
When any person is charged with having parked or left standing a vehicle on any street in the city at a place on said street where parking of vehicles is prohibited, or with parking such vehicle on said street in a manner which violates the manner of parking a vehicle as designated, or with parking such vehicle for a length of time in excess of that allowed in the space where said vehicle was parked, proof that said vehicle was, at the date of the offense alleged, owned by the person charged with the offense, shall constitute prima facie evidence that said vehicle was parked or left standing at the place charged by said owner, but the owner shall have the right to introduce evidence to show that said vehicle was not parked by him as charged in the complaint. In any proceeding where a person is charged with parking a vehicle on the streets of the city in violation of any ordinance of the city regulating the parking of vehicles, a certified copy of the registration receipt issued by the assessor and collector of taxes of any county in the state shall be admissible in evidence for the purpose of proving that the license plate displayed on said vehicle at the time of the offense was issued to the person so charged, and proof of such fact shall constitute a prima facie presumption that the vehicle was parked by the person to whom said registration receipt was issued. 
(Code 1975, § 9-3; Code 1996, § 10.317)  
Sec. 54-85. - No parking areas. 
(a)	No parking areas are hereby established along the following streets on Mondays through Fridays during the time when school is in session from 7:30 a.m. until 3:30 p.m.: 
Street 	Limit of Zones 	Direction

East side of North Main Street 	From the north line of 3rd Street to the south line of 5th Street 	N & S 
East side of North Main Street 	From the north line of 16th Street to the south line of 18th Street 	E & W

(b)	The parking of any motor vehicle, Mondays through Fridays, during the hours of 7:00 a.m. until 5:00 p.m., in the 1700 block of Ninth Street, and more particularly described hereinbelow shall be prohibited; to-wit: 
(1)	Beginning where the existing Ninth Street intersects to the west R-O-W line of the existing Parkside Drive, this place of beginning being the Ezekial Thomas Survey "A," Harris County, Texas. 
(2)	Thence go west a distance of 350 feet to the beginning (east boundary line of Clinton Subdivision). This distance of 350 feet is commonly known as the 1700 Block of Ninth Street. 
(c)	The above described area is hereby designated as a tow-away zone during the days and hours specified hereinabove and any motor vehicle parked or standing in the prohibited area may be towed away at no cost to the city at the direction of the police chief. 
(Code 1975, § 9-3; Code 1996, § 10.318; Ord. of 3-6-1990, §§ 1, 2; Ord. No. 95-12-19-01, 12-19-1995)  
Sec. 54-86. - Ratification of existing devices. 
All parking regulations and no parking areas heretofore established and all yield signs, stop signs, and traffic control devices heretofore erected are hereby confirmed and ratified. Additional parking regulations and no parking areas may be established and additional yield signs, stop signs, and traffic control devices erected in accordance with the provisions of this Code. 
(Code 1975, § 9-3; Code 1996, § 10.319)  
Secs. 54-87—54-115. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - STARTING, DRIVING, STOPPING AND TURNING 
 
Sec. 54-116. - One-way streets. 
Upon these streets and parts of streets which have been designated for use as one-way streets as provided in this article, and on which appropriate signs have been erected indicating the permitted direction of travel, it shall be unlawful for the driver of any vehicle to operate such vehicle on such streets or parts of streets except in the direction thus indicated. Specified one-way streets are as follows: 
(1)	On First Street from the west line of Center Drive to the west line of Westway Street: one-way for vehicles westbound on First Street. 
(2)	From the north line of First Street south to Clinton Drive on Westway Street: one-way for vehicles traveling south on Westway Street. 
(3)	It shall be unlawful for the driver of any vehicle to operate such vehicle on such streets or parts of streets except in the direction indicated by appropriate signs erected indicating the permitted direction of travel upon the following additional streets from Monday through Friday of every week during school days between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m., to-wit: 
a.	3 rd Street between Main Street and Keene Street from the 1500 block of 3 rd Street thru the 1800 block of 3 rd Street. 
b.	1700 Keene Street to Parkside Drive. 
c.	1600 block of 9 th Street thru the 1800 block of 9 th Street. 
(Code 1996, § 10.401; Ord. No. 2015-14, § 1, 11-3-2015)  
Sec. 54-117. - Limitations on backing. 
The driver of a vehicle shall not back the same into an intersection or over a crosswalk at any intersection. The driver shall not in any event or at any place back a vehicle unless such movement can be made in safety. 
(Code 1996, § 10.402)  
Sec. 54-118. - Permits for parades and processions. 
No parade, excepting of the forces of the United States Army or Navy, the military forces of this state and the forces of the police and fire departments, shall occupy, march or proceed along any street except in accordance with a permit issued pursuant to the terms of the ordinances now in effect governing parades or any amendments thereto which may be made. 
(Code 1996, § 10.403)  
Sec. 54-119. - Funeral and other processions. 
A funeral composed of a procession of vehicles shall be identified as such by the display upon the outside of each vehicle of a pennant of a type approved by the traffic director. Each driver in a funeral or other procession shall drive as near to the right-hand edge of the roadway as practical and follow the vehicle ahead as closely as is practical and safe. It shall be unlawful for the operator of any vehicle other than ambulances on emergency calls, or vehicles of the fire and police departments to drive across or through the line of vehicles comprising a funeral or other procession authorized by the city commission. It shall be unlawful for any person operating a vehicle, except drivers of ambulances on emergency calls, and drivers of police and fire department vehicles, to overtake or to pass any funeral procession that is proceeding in the same direction as the vehicle that said person is operating. 
(Code 1996, § 10.404)  
Sec. 54-120. - Limitations on turning around. 
The driver of any vehicle shall not turn such vehicle so as to proceed in the opposite direction upon any street in the downtown business district or at any signalized intersection or at those intersections where turns are prohibited by official signs or markings, unless such turn is affirmatively authorized by an appropriate sign or signal. The driver of any vehicle shall not upon any other street so turn a vehicle unless such movement can be made in safety and without interfering with other traffic, and then only where a street is crossed or makes intersection with another street. 
(Code 1996, § 10.405)  
Sec. 54-121. - Emerging from and entering alley or private driveway. 
The driver of a vehicle emerging from an alley, driveway, or building shall stop such vehicle immediately prior to driving onto a sidewalk or into the sidewalk area extending across any alleyway, and upon entering the roadway shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles approaching on said roadway. Any vehicle emerging from an alley or private driveway in a business district shall proceed straight ahead or make a right turn. It shall be unlawful and an offense to make a left turn upon emerging from or entering any alley or driveway in a business district. 
(Code 1996, § 10.406)  
Sec. 54-122. - Cutting corners. 
It shall be unlawful and an offense to drive a vehicle over any sidewalk area and through any driveway, parking lot or any business entrance at any intersection, in making either a right or left turn, except for the purpose of coming to a complete stop to obtain or render some service or make a sale or purchase. It is the intention of this article to prohibit corner cutting by driving a vehicle from one street into another across any sidewalk and driveway and through any driveway. 
(Code 1996, § 10.407)  
Sec. 54-123. - Vehicles not to be driven on sidewalk. 
The rider or driver of any animal or vehicle shall not ride, drive or park such animal or vehicle within any sidewalk area except at a permanent or temporary driveway. 
(Code 1996, § 10.408)  
Sec. 54-124. - Clinging to moving vehicles. 
Any person riding upon any bicycle, motorcycle, coaster, sled, roller skates or any toy vehicle shall not attach the same or himself to any moving vehicle upon any roadway. 
(Code 1996, § 10.409)  
Sec. 54-125. - Unlawful riding. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to ride or jump on any vehicle without the consent of the driver, or with any part of his person protruding beyond the limits of said vehicle. It shall be unlawful for any person to ride on any portion of any vehicle not designed or intended for the use or passengers. However, this provision shall not apply to any employee engaged in the necessary discharge of a duty or to persons riding within the space of truck bodies intended for merchandise. 
(Code 1996, § 10.410)  
Sec. 54-126. - Riding on handle bars, etc., prohibited. 
The operator of a motorcycle or bicycle when in use on a street shall not carry any other person upon the handle bars, frame or tank of any such vehicle, nor shall any person so ride upon any such vehicle. 
(Code 1996, § 10.411)  
Sec. 54-127. - Use of coasters, roller skates and similar devices restricted. 
No person upon roller skates, or riding in or by means of any coaster, toy vehicle or similar device, shall go upon any roadway. 
(Code 1975, § 9-4; Code 1996, § 10.412)  
Secs. 54-128—54-152. - Reserved.
