Sec. 54-154. - In general. 
A person commits an offense if he drives a vehicle on any street within the city at a speed greater than is reasonable and prudent under the circumstances then existing. Any speed in excess of 30 miles per hour on a public street, or 15 miles per hour in a public alley or city park, unless otherwise provided by this article, shall be prima facie evidence that the speed is not reasonable or prudent and that it is unlawful. 
(Code 1975, § 9-6; Code 1996, art. 10.600)  
Secs. 54-155—54-176. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - VEHICULAR ROUTES, PERMITS, LIMITS AND APPLICATION FEES 
 
Sec. 54-177. - Vehicular routes. 
No truck, tractor, trailer or other heavy vehicular equipment in excess of 8,000 pounds, 25 feet maximum total length, 96 inches in width and/or a height which exceeds 13 feet six inches, including load, shall be operated on the streets or roadways of the city except for the following streets: Clinton Drive, Federal Road, Industrial Road east of Federal Road, Mayo Shell Road, Main Street south of Clinton Drive, Holland Avenue between Clinton Drive and Eighteenth Street, Avenue K west of Main Street, Eastway Street south of Clinton Drive, Magnolia Street, Pine Street, South Fourth Street, Philpot Drive, First Street to Eastway Street to Westway Street and Avenues F, G, and H south of the Southern Pacific Railroad and east of Main Street, and hereinafter the above streets shall be designated as vehicular routes and be referred to as "commercial streets." 
(Code 1975, § 9-7; Code 1996, § 10.701)  
Sec. 54-178. - Vehicular limits. 
The maximum weight, height, width and length limits on all commercial streets in the city shall be as follows: 
(1)	Weight limits. The maximum weight limits shall be 80,000 pounds and shall not have a greater weight than 20,000 pounds carried on any one axle, including all enforcement tolerances; or with a tandem axle in excess of 34,000 pounds including all enforcement tolerances; and no turning axle shall have a greater weight that 12,000 pounds if said vehicle has tandem axles on the same vehicle. 
(2)	Height limits. No vehicle unladen or with load shall exceed a height of 14 feet, including load. 
(3)	Width limits. No vehicle shall exceed a total outside width, including any load thereon, of 102 inches. 
(4)	Length limits. There is no length limitation for a truck-tractor, semi-trailer combination other than the trailer is limited to not more than 59 feet in length. All other vehicles and combinations may not exceed 65 feet in length. 
(Code 1996, § 10.702; Ord. No. 2001-02, 3-20-2001)  
Sec. 54-179. - Permits required. 
Any owner or operator desiring to operate any trucks, tractors, trucks in tandem, heavy equipment graders, pavement rollers, bulldozers, cranes, maintainer equipment or any other type of vehicle which exceeds the limits set out in sections 54-177 and 54-178 or any owner or operator desiring to operate said vehicle with or without a police escort shall be required to make written application for a special permit and obtain such special permit before said vehicle is operated on the streets and roadways of the city. The application and permit shall be obtained from the city secretary, traffic director, or their designated agent and shall contain such information as shall be deemed necessary to effectuate the purpose of this article. A permit is required for each vehicle which exceeds the limits set out in sections 54-177 and 54-178 and such permit shall be good for only that date as is specified on the permit. The limits prescribed in sections 54-177 and 54-178 shall not apply to public busses, school busses or to any equipment used by the United States, the state, the county, the city, or any contractor building or repairing the streets or roadways within the city limits. 
(Code 1975, § 9-7; Code 1996, § 10.703)  
Sec. 54-180. - Application fees. 
There shall be and is hereby levied, and there shall be collected from every person, firm, company, or association of persons pursuing a permit required by section 54-179, an application fee in the sum as provided for in the fee schedule for each and every oversized or overweight truck, tractor and tractor trailer loads operating in the city. 
(Code 1996, § 10.704; Ord. No. 2009-05, § 1, 6-16-2009)  
Sec. 54-181. - Liabilities. 
Any person moving, or causing to be moved, a load which together with the weight of the vehicle exceeds four tons on any street other than those commercial streets prescribed in section 54-177, or moves or causes to be moved any load which exceeds those limits prescribed in section 54-178 for commercial streets, shall be liable to the city for any damage done by such load to the streets, bridges, culverts, collection basins, curbs, gutters, water valves or lines, sewer lines, manholes or cleanouts, traffic signals, traffic signs, poles or wiring within the city limits. The acceptance of either of the aforesaid permits shall be conclusive evidence that the person to whom such permit is issued agrees to make good and pay all such damages and related costs upon demand therefore being made by the city. 
(Code 1996, § 10.705)  
Secs. 54-182—54-200. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VII. - TRAFFIC DIRECTOR AND TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Authority to place and maintain traffic control devices, Texas Transportation Code § 542.202(a)(1); interference with traffic control device or railroad sign, Texas Transportation Code § 544.005. 
 
Sec. 54-201. - Traffic director designated. 
The director of public works is hereby designated as traffic director of the city, and shall cause traffic control devices to be erected and maintained in the city. All traffic control devices including signs, signals, and markings (pavement and/or curb) installed or used for the purpose of directing and controlling traffic within the city shall conform with the Texas Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices for Streets and Highways, hereafter called the manual. 
(Code 1996, § 10.901)  
Sec. 54-202. - Traffic condition studies. 
The traffic director shall submit to the city commission in writing based on a study of all traffic conditions, including, but not limited to, the dimensions of the streets and sidewalks and the use of property abutting the streets, the frequency of passage of vehicles or pedestrians, or both, railroad crossings, curbs, and congestion of traffic, recommendations necessary for the free flow of traffic and expeditious handling of traffic and safety of persons and property. 
(Code 1996, § 10.902)  
Sec. 54-203. - Authority of traffic director. 
Whenever and wherever the congestion of traffic, the frequency of passage of vehicles or pedestrians, or both, the direction of the flow of traffic, the dimensions of the streets and sidewalks and the use of property abutting the streets are such that he finds it to be necessary for the safety of persons and property, the traffic director is authorized upon approval of the city commission to: 
(1)	Designate and maintain crosswalks at intersections by appropriate devices, marks or lines upon the surface of the roadway. 
(2)	Establish safety zones and school zones on any of the streets of the city. 
(3)	Mark lanes for traffic on the streets of the city. 
(4)	Place proper signs, signals or markings prohibiting the making of right, left or complete turns at any intersection of streets in the city. 
(5)	Place signs, signals, or markings within or adjacent to intersections, indicating the course to be traveled by vehicles turning at such intersection. 
(6)	Install or cause to be displayed signs, signals or markings for the direction of traffic near public or private schools, parks and public buildings. 
(7)	Determine the location of passenger zones and freight loading zones and to place and maintain appropriate signs or markings indicating the same. 
(8)	Designate spaces on the streets of the city for exclusive use as bus stops and to mark the same with appropriate signs or markings. 
(9)	Designate areas on the streets of the city which shall not be used as spaces for the parking of vehicles and to mark such areas with appropriate signs or markings. 
(10)	Designate intersections of streets at which drivers operating vehicles approaching the intersection on one or more of the intersecting streets must bring such vehicle to a complete stop before proceeding into such intersection, and to install and maintain appropriate signs and markings directing such drivers to stop at such intersections. 
(11)	Designate intersections of streets at which drivers operating vehicles approaching the intersection of one or more of the intersecting streets must reduce the speed of such vehicle to not to exceed ten miles per hour upon reaching such intersection and continue at not more than such speed for a distance of 100 feet, and to install appropriate signs and markings directing such drivers thus to reduce the speed of their vehicles. 
(12)	Designate streets and portions of streets on which drivers of vehicles are prohibited from driving except in one direction and to designate the direction in which driving is prohibited and that in which driving is permitted, and to install appropriate signs and markings designating such one-way streets. 
(13)	Designate the routes which must be followed by commercial vehicles in using the streets of the city; provided that no such vehicle shall be prohibited from using any street for the purpose of going directly to or from any residential, commercial or industrial establishment abutting on such street. 
(14)	Determine and allocate parking time limits on streets and portions of streets and place appropriate signs or markings giving notice thereof. 
(15)	Designate intersections, the crossing of which shall be controlled by red, green and amber lights and arrows as elsewhere provided in this Code, and to determine the type of such lights or traffic control devices to be installed at each intersection and to cause the same to be installed, and it shall be unlawful for any person to fail or refuse to obey the instructions transmitted by means of such lights or traffic control devices. 
(16)	Make such changes as changing conditions may require in any designation, determination or regulation he is herein authorized to make. 
(Code 1996, § 10.903)  
Sec. 54-204. - Designation of "quiet zones." 
Whenever he finds it is necessary to the public health, comfort and safety, the traffic director is hereby authorized to designate areas of the streets of the city to be known as "quiet zones" in the vicinity of any hospital, church, school or public institution, and to mark such area with appropriate signs directing the drivers of vehicles not to sound a horn or other warning device while traveling in the area thus designated. 
(Code 1996, § 10.904)  
Sec. 54-205. - Regulations, etc., to be in writing and filed with city secretary. 
Every regulation, designation, delineation or determination promulgated by the traffic director pursuant to the authority granted in this Code shall, unless otherwise provided herein, be described in writing and filed with the city secretary. Such writing shall constitute a public record, and all persons shall be charged with notice of the contents of the same. 
(Code 1996, § 10.905)  
Sec. 54-206. - Effect of installing traffic control device, signal, etc. 
The installation under the direction of the traffic director of any traffic control device, sign, signal or marking provided for in this article shall at once cause to be effective the instruction to pedestrians or drivers of vehicles transmitted by means of such device, sign, signal or marking. 
(Code 1996, § 10.906)  
Sec. 54-207. - Installation of signs by other than traffic director prohibited. 
It is unlawful for any person other than the traffic director to install or cause to be installed any sign purporting to direct the use of the streets or the activities on the streets of pedestrians or vehicles. 
(Code 1996, § 10.907)  
Sec. 54-208. - Instructions to be conveyed by lights, signals, etc.; location of lights, signals, etc., to be established by traffic director. 
Any of the well-known types of lights, signals, signs and markings, the instructions intended to be conveyed by which are matters of common knowledge in the city, when installed in or near any street in the city shall convey the instruction commonly known to be intended. The location of each such device, light, sign, signal and marking shall be established by the traffic director in accordance with his findings as to the existing facts when applied to the standards laid down in this Code for his guidance. 
(Code 1996, § 10.908)  
Sec. 54-209. - Failure to observe instructions of traffic control devices, lights, etc. 
It shall be unlawful for any person knowingly to fail to observe or obey any instruction of any traffic control device, signal light, sign or marking installed as provided for in this article. 
(Code 1996, § 10.909)  
Sec. 54-210. - Proof of violation. 
Proof, in any prosecution for a violation of this Code that any traffic control device, sign, signal or marking was actually in place on any street in the city shall constitute prima facie evidence that the same was installed by the traffic director or under his direction pursuant to the authority herein granted. 
(Code 1996, § 10.910)  
Sec. 54-211. - Emergency measures. 
The chief of police or any police officer of the city, in case of necessity or emergency or of congestion by traffic, may make such special orders to pedestrians or to drivers of vehicles as in his judgment may be necessary to meet the emergency or relieve congestion. 
(Code 1975, § 9-9; Code 1996, § 10.911)  
Secs. 54-212—54-230. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VIII. - PARADES 
 
Sec. 54-231. - Permit required. 
(a)	A person seeking to hold a parade consisting of 12 or more people in or on a public place within the city shall file an application with the city secretary for a parade permit not less than ten days nor more than 30 days before the date upon which the parade is proposed to be conducted. Any person who participates in a parade that has not been issued a permit by the chief of police, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and fined in accordance with the general penalty provision found in section 1-6. 
(b)	The term "public place," as used in this article, means any road, street, alley or sidewalk within the city. 
(Code 1996, § 10.1501)  
Sec. 54-232. - Manner in which to apply for permit. 
Any person desiring to acquire a permit to parade within the city may make application for such with the city commission of said city or their designees, either in writing or verbally, setting out the general purpose of said parade and the beginning point and point of termination of such and the route generally to be followed during said parade. 
(Code 1996, § 10.1502)  
Sec. 54-233. - Standards for issuance. 
The chief of police shall issue a parade permit when, from a consideration of the application and from such other information as may otherwise be obtained, it is found: 
(1)	The conduct of the parade will not substantially interrupt the safe and orderly movement of other traffic contiguous to its route or place of occurrence. 
(2)	The conduct of the parade will not require the diversion of so great a number of police officers of the city to properly police the line of movement or the place of occurrence and the areas contiguous thereto as to prevent normal police protection to the city. 
(3)	The conduct of such parade will not require the diversion of so great a number of ambulances and other emergency vehicles as to prevent normal ambulance and other emergency service to portions of the city other than that to be occupied by the proposed parade and areas contiguous thereto. 
(4)	The concentration of persons, animals and vehicles at assembly points of the parade will not unduly interfere with police, fire and other emergency services to areas contiguous to such assembly areas. 
(5)	The conduct of such parade will not interfere with the movement of fire fighting equipment en route to a fire. 
(6)	The conduct of the parade is not reasonably likely to cause injury to persons or property, to provoke disorderly conduct or to create a disturbance. 
(7)	The parade is scheduled to move from its point of origin to its point of termination expeditiously and without unreasonable delays en route.  
Sec. 54-234. - Notice of rejection. 
The chief of police shall act upon the application for a parade permit within three business days after the filing thereof. If the chief of police disapproves the application, he shall mail to the applicant, within three business days after the date which the application was filed, a notice of his action stating the reasons for his denial of the permit. Notice shall be deemed complete when mailed.  
Sec. 54-235. - Appeal procedure. 
Any person aggrieved shall have the right to appeal the denial of a parade permit to the mayor. The appeal shall be taken within 60 days after notice. The mayor shall act upon the appeal within 30 days after its receipts. 
(Ord. No. 2016-03A, 8-16-2016)  
Sec. 54-236. - Alternative permits. 
The chief of police, in denying an application for a parade permit, shall be empowered to authorize the conduct of the parade on a date, at a time, or over a route, or in a place, different from that named by the applicant. An applicant desiring to accept an alternate permit shall, within five days after notice of the action of the chief of police, file a written notice of acceptance with the chief of police. An alternate parade permit shall conform to the requirements of and shall have the effect of a parade permit under this article.  
Secs. 54-237—54-265. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IX. - PARKING LOTS AND OFF-STREET PARKING 
 
Sec. 54-266. - Parking lots. 
The parking of trucks, automobiles or any motor vehicles on any commercial parking lots or other property used for the parking or storage of trucks, automobiles or other motor vehicles for which a fee, lease payment or rental payment or other consideration is paid or given to the owner of such parking lot or other property used to park or store said motor vehicles shall be unlawful, unless a special use permit is first issued by the city. 
(Code 1996, § 10.1601)  
Sec. 54-267. - Special use permit. 
A special use permit may be granted by the city upon an application requesting the issuance of a permit for the construction and operation of said commercial parking lot or other parking or storage lots used for the parking or storage of trucks, automobiles or other motor vehicles. The application shall be furnished by the city secretary and shall be submitted to the building official for approval. The building official shall approve or deny the issuance of the permit. Any denial of said permit may be appealed to the mayor in writing within ten days of such denial by the building official. The mayor shall review such denial and shall approve or set aside such denial in writing within 15 days of the appeal of such denial. The decision of the mayor shall be final. 
(Code 1996, § 10.1602; Ord. No. 2016-03A, 8-16-2016)  
Sec. 54-268. - General requirements. 
(a)	Paving. All commercial parking lots or other property used for the parking or storage of trucks, automobiles or other motor vehicles, any portion of driveway, or any entrance or exit, that is on city property, shall be paved with concrete or with a minimum of two inches of asphalt laid upon a substantial base material. The remaining portion of the parking lot may consist of any substantial base material, firm enough to support trucks, so that no mud or debris will come from the parking lot or vehicle onto city streets. Plans and specifications for such paving shall first be approved by the city's building official prior to construction of said paving. 
(b)	Setback lines. All setback lines required by the zoning ordinances, deed restrictions, or other legal requirements shall be strictly enforced. 
(c)	Fencing. Fencing shall be installed on all lots where there are residential homes adjacent to such parking lot as determined by the building official. This fencing shall be a privacy fence at a minimum of eight feet tall. 
(d)	Traffic hazard. No permit shall be issued if the parking or storage of such motor vehicles constitute a traffic hazard to persons traveling on the public streets near or adjoining said parking or storage lots. Appropriate safety procedures must be taken when pulling or backing into said lots. 
(e)	Access. All said parking or storage lots shall have adequate turning space and safe access to and from said lots. 
(f)	Adjoining lots. No such special use permit shall be granted if the said parking or storage lot unreasonably interferes with the use or enjoyment of any adjoining residential lot. 
(Code 1996, § 10.1603)  
Sec. 54-269. - Residential lots. 
No such parking or storage lots shall be allowed on any residential lot in the city. 
(Code 1996, § 10.1604)  
Sec. 54-270. - Permit fee. 
The city secretary shall collect a nonrefundable fee for such special use permit as provided for in the fee schedule. 
(Code 1996, § 10.1605)  
Sec. 54-271. - Penalty. 
Any person who violates any section or part of this article shall be guilty of a Class C misdemeanor and shall be fined as provided for in the general penalty provision found in section 1-6, and each day such violation shall continue shall also constitute a separate and distinct offense. 
(Code 1996, § 10.1606; Ord. No. 98-02, 2-3-1998)  
Chapter 58 - UTILITIES AND SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Municipal power concerning sewers and privies, Texas Health and Safety Code § 342.002; exclusive original jurisdiction of municipality over electric utility rates, operations and services within the municipal territory, Texas Utilities Code § 33.001 et seq.; municipal utility systems generally, Texas Local Government Code § 552.001 et seq.; certain public services and utility systems in home rule municipalities, Texas Local Government Code § 552.002; water systems in home rule municipalities, Texas Local Government Code § 552.017. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 58-1. - Utility billing procedures. 
After the tenth day of each month, if the water bill exceeds the customer's deposit, the customer shall be notified of the same by sending a delinquent notice giving the customer a period of 15 days in which to pay the same. If not paid during the 15-day period, the water service shall be discontinued without further notice. A charge, as provided for in the fee schedule, shall be made to reinstate the service. In the event a meter is removed for non-payment of a water bill, there shall be a charge, as provided for in the fee schedule, for reinstallation. The owner of any delinquent account shall deposit an amount equal to the amount that exceeded the original deposit. These fees and all bills shall be payable before water service is restored. 
(Code 1996, § 11.300; Ord. No. 93-10-05-02, § 13, 10-5-1993)  
Secs. 58-2—58-20. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - WATER AND SEWER, GARBAGE, AND MOSQUITO SERVICE RATES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Authority of home rule municipality to prescribe rates for the use of water to compel the payment thereof, Texas Local Government Code § 552.017. 
 
Sec. 58-21. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Owner means any person having legal or equitable interest in the property establishing ownership. 
Residential means a dwelling where one resides; a place that is used mainly for the purpose of residing. The term "residential" includes apartment houses and churches. 
Residential other than owner means any person who rents or leases from a landlord, agent, firm or corporation. 
(Code 1996, § 11.101; Ord. No. 93-10-05-02, § 1, 10-5-1993)  
Sec. 58-22. - Rate change. 
There shall be an automatic annual increase of three percent in the minimum bills for water usage and an annual increase of three percent for sewer usage for all residential, commercial and industrial customers for a period of five years with the first such annual increase for water and for sewer usage to commence August 1, 2014, and a like annual increase on August 1 of each year thereafter for said five-year period. The final annual increase for such water and sewer usage shall be on August 1, 2018, unless continued by a resolution of the city commission extending such annual increase in the minimum water and minimum sewer rates. 
(Ord. No. 2013-07, § 2, 7-16-2013)  
Sec. 58-23. - Residential water service rates. 
The monthly rates to be charged residential accounts by the city for water service shall be as provided for in the fee schedule. 
(Code 1996, § 11.102; Ord. No. 93-10-05-02, § 2, 10-5-1993)  
Sec. 58-24. - Residential sewer service rates. 
The monthly rates to be charged residential accounts by said city for sewer service shall be as provided for in the fee schedule. 
(Code 1996, § 11.103; Ord. No. 93-10-05-02, § 3, 10-5-1993)  
Sec. 58-25. - Commercial water service rates. 
The monthly rates to be charged commercial accounts by the said city for water service shall be as provided for in the fee schedule. 
(Code 1996, § 11.104; Ord. No. 93-10-05-02, § 4, 10-5-1993)  
Sec. 58-26. - Commercial sewer service rates. 
The monthly rates to be charged commercial accounts by said city for sewer service shall be as provided for in the fee schedule. 
(Code 1996, § 11.105; Ord. No. 93-10-05-02, § 5, 10-5-1993)  
Sec. 58-27. - Industrial water service rates. 
The monthly rates to be charged industrial accounts by said city for water service shall be as provided for in the fee schedule. 
(Code 1996, § 11.106; Ord. No. 93-10-05-02, § 6, 10-5-1993)  
Sec. 58-28. - Industrial sewer service rates. 
The monthly rates to be charged industrial accounts by said city for sewer service shall be as provided for in the fee schedule. 
(Code 1996, § 11.107; Ord. No. 93-10-05-02, § 7, 10-5-1993)  
Sec. 58-29. - Water and sewer service rates outside city. 
The monthly rates to be charged outside customers by said city for water and sewer service shall be as provided for in the fee schedule. 
(Code 1996, § 11.108; Ord. No. 93-10-05-02, § 8, 10-5-1993)  
Sec. 58-30. - Water rates applicable to contractors. 
(a)	The rates to be charged contractors for the purpose of water, when the meter and connections are supplied by the contractor, shall be as provided for in the fee schedule. 
(b)	The rate to be charged contractors for the purchase of water, when the meter and connections are supplied by the city, shall be as provided for in the fee schedule. 
(Code 1996, § 11.109; Ord. No. 93-10-05-02, §§ 9, 10, 10-5-1993)  
Sec. 58-31. - Water turn off charge. 
There shall be a minimum charge, as provided for in the fee schedule, for people living inside the city to have the water turned on or off for repair and for cleaning purposes. 
(Code 1996, § 11.110; Ord. No. 93-10-05-02, § 11, 10-5-1993)  
Sec. 58-32. - Mosquito control fee. 
A fee, as provided for in the fee schedule, shall be added to each water customer's monthly bill for the purpose of providing funds for the control of mosquitoes. 
(Code 1996, § 11.111; Ord. No. 83-10-18-01, § 2, 10-18-1983)  
Sec. 58-33. - Temporary water and sewer service. 
There shall be a minimum charge, as provided for in the fee schedule, for temporary water and sewer service to a vacant property. Temporary service cannot exceed one month. Additional charges for usage in excess of 3,000 gallons will be billed at the published rates. The owner or owner's agent must make application and pay the minimum charge at city hall prior to receiving temporary service. The city will discontinue the temporary service at the end of one month, unless prior arrangements are made. 
(Code 1996, § 11.112; Ord. No. 95-11-06-02, 11-6-1995)  
Sec. 58-34. - Water and sewer tap fees and deposits. 
The rate to be charged by the city for tap fees and deposits for water and sewer users shall be as provided for in the fee schedule. 
(Code 1996, § 11.200; Ord. No. 93-10-05-02, § 12, 10-5-1993)  
Secs. 58-35—58-56. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - HANDLING AND DISPOSAL OF GARBAGE AND WASTE 
 
Sec. 58-57. - Placement for collection. 
It shall be the duty of every person in charge of inhabited premises within the city to prepare the garbage, trash, and rubbish from such premises and timely place the same for collection by the city in accordance with the terms and conditions of this article. 
(1)	The owner of each residence within the city shall prepare for disposal of dry kitchen refuse, kitchen garbage and rubbish in disposable bags or containers that are entirely sealed and disposable. Cardboard boxes and other disposal containers may be used in addition to sacks, provided that they are tightly sealed and disposable. No containers of any shape, size or form will be emptied and returned to the curb. Containers having a total loaded weight in excess of 75 pounds will not be handled by city crews. 
(2)	All loose trash accumulations shall be deposited in receptacles as specified in subsection (1) of this section, and set out for collection. No single item of trash shall exceed four feet in length or width or two feet in diameter. No item or trash subject to being blown by winds from its place of deposit for collection on the premises shall be deposited loose on the premises, but shall be placed in required receptacle. 
(3)	Garbage sacks and other disposable containers used for dry kitchen refuse, kitchen garbage and rubbish shall be maintained in a sanitary condition and closed tightly when containing any dry kitchen refuse, kitchen garbage and/or rubbish. Lime must be used at places where such receptacles are located to be collected by the city if needed to abate odors, flies, or vermin. 
(4)	Garbage cans or other nondisposable containers and containers which are broken, split or open, or which are capable of causing injury to city handling personnel, shall not be touched by city personnel or the contents of such cans or receptacles collected except as set out in this article. 
(5)	Garbage sacks and other disposable containers to be collected by city personnel shall be placed inside the curb or drain ditch line of the street near the front property line of the premises, no later than 7:30 a.m. on those days designated from time to time for garbage pick up. 
(6)	Tree limbs and shrubbery shall be cut or broken into lengths of not more than four feet and suitably bundled, baled or interlaced through limb branches so as to permit collection without gathering up individual limbs. 
(7)	Apartments and commercial establishments may continue to use garbage cans and other watertight receptacles which shall have a close-fitting cover and with handles and of sufficient capacity and of sufficient numbers to accommodate and securely keep all the garbage, rubbish, trash and miscellaneous wastes that may accumulate from any such premises. 
(8)	The city shall not collect kitchen garbage, rubbish, trash or tree limbs where the same are not prepared for collection and placed in accordance with this article. 
(9)	It shall be unlawful for any person to tamper with garbage sacks, other containers, trash receptacles or city sanitation container units or to pilfer or scatter the contents thereof in any city street, alley or easement. 
(10)	All garbage, trash, rubbish, ashes, or miscellaneous waste, which may be disposed of by any person, shall not be deposited at any place within the city, and within the police jurisdiction thereof, except at a city dump ground, or at such other place as may be directed by the city officials. 
(11)	Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined in accordance with the general penalty provision found in section 1-6; and each day that any person shall violate any of the provisions of this article shall constitute a separate offense and be punishable as such. 
(Code 1975, § 10-4; Code 1996, § 11.401)  
Sec. 58-58. - Garbage rates. 
(a)	The fees to be charged for garbage service shall be as provided for in the fee schedule. 
(b)	Customers over the age of 65 years shall be eligible for a monthly reduction in said garbage rate, as provided for in the fee schedule. Such persons must apply for this discount and show acceptable proof of age. Said discount is applicable to the occupant of the subject property (as opposed to the owner). 
(Code 1996, § 11.402; Ord. No. 93-10-05-02, § 14, 10-5-1993)  
Sec. 58-59. - Commercial rates for garbage and trash service. 
The fees to be charged for collection of commercial garbage and brush and limb shall be as provided for in the fee schedule. 
(Code 1996, § 11.404; Ord. No. 93-10-05-02, § 16, 10-5-1993)  
Secs. 58-60—58-76. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - SANITARY CONTROL OF SEWAGE 
 
Sec. 58-77. - Generally. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to dispose of any human excreta or waste within the corporate limits of the city except in a sanitary water flush tank connected to the city's sanitary sewer system or to a septic tank built and installed according to the specifications of the Texas State Department of Health for Harris County. 
(Code 1975, § 10-5; Code 1996, § 11.500(a))  
Sec. 58-78. - Sewer connection required. 
Every building intended for human habitation or occupancy abutting upon any road, street or alley in which there is a public sewer line, or within 300 feet of such public sewer line, shall as provided in this article be connected to such public sewer line by the owner or agent of the premises in the most direct manner possible. 
(Code 1975, § 10-5; Code 1996, § 11.500(b))  
Sec. 58-79. - Application required for connection. 
It shall be necessary for the owner or agent of any such premises mentioned in this article, and he is hereby expressly required, to make application to the city for connection of said premises to such public sewer line and such connection shall be made according to the requirements and subject of the approval of the city and its duly authorized representative and after connection the same shall be inspected by such representative for compliance with existing regulations. 
(Code 1975, § 10-5; Code 1996, § 11.500(c))  
Sec. 58-80. - Water, gas and sewer lines in separate trenches. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to lay any water service line, gas service line or sewer line in the same trench within the corporate limits of the city. All water service lines and sewer lines shall be laid in separate trenches and such trenches shall be separated by a distance of at least ten feet. 
(Code 1975, § 10-5; Code 1996, § 11.500(d))  
Sec. 58-81. - Septic tanks. 
In areas and localities within the corporate limits of the city where the public sanitary sewer lines are distant from any building inhabited or occupied by human beings of more than 300 feet, or where such public sanitary sewer service is not available, then and in such event, each house or building occupied or inhabited by human beings within such area or locality shall be connected to a sanitary septic tank built, constructed and installed to meet the requirements and specifications of the Texas State Department of Health for Harris County, and it shall be necessary for the owner or agent of such premises to notify the city and the county health unit of his intention to construct and install such septic tank. The city and the county health unit shall approve or disapprove the location of the septic tank prior to its installation, and if the location or site thereof is so approved, such septic tank shall be constructed and installed but shall be finally inspected by said city and health unit and approved or disapproved prior to being put into actual use. 
(Code 1975, § 10-5; Code 1996, § 11.500(e))  
Sec. 58-82. - Declaration of public nuisance. 
All outdoor privies, and all cesspools or tanks constructed in manner contrary to this article, existing or being used or maintained within the corporate limits of the city are hereby declared to be a public nuisance and a menace to the public health, and shall immediately be abandoned and replaced by suitable means of sewage disposal as provided by this article. 
(Code 1975, § 10-5; Code 1996, § 11.500(f))  
Sec. 58-83. - Violation and penalty. 
Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the terms or conditions of this article shall be guilty of an offense punishable by fine in accordance with the general penalty provision found in section 1-6, and each day of such violation shall be a separate offense. 
(Code 1975, § 10-5; Code 1996, § 11.500(g))  
Secs. 58-84—58-109. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - INDUSTRIAL WASTE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Authority of municipality to adopt rules to control and regulate disposal system waste, Texas Water Code § 26.176; water pollution control duties, Texas Water Code § 26.177. 
 
Sec. 58-110. - Purpose. 
(a)	This article sets forth uniform requirements for contributors into the wastewater facilities of the city and enables the city to comply with all applicable federal, state and local regulations. 
(b)	The objectives of this article are to prevent the introduction of pollutants into the city's wastewater facilities which: 
(1)	Will interfere with the operation of the facilities or contaminate the resulting sludge; and 
(2)	Could pass through said facilities, resulting in inadequately treated effluent, into the receiving waters or the atmosphere or otherwise be incompatible with the sanitary sewer facilities. 
(c)	This article provides for the regulation of all contributors to the city's wastewater facilities and the enforcement of these general requirements authorizes monitoring and enforcement activities, requires user reporting, and provides for the setting of fees for the equitable distribution of costs resulting from the program established herein. 
(d)	This article shall apply to all users of the city's wastewater facilities, whether such users are located within or outside the boundaries of the city. Except as otherwise provided herein, the commission shall administer, implement and enforce the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1996, § 11.601; Ord. No. 2006-01, 4-18-2006)  
Sec. 58-111. - Definitions. 
Unless the context requires otherwise, the following terms and phrases as used in this article shall have the meanings hereinafter designated: 
Amenable to treatment means susceptible to reduction in concentration by treatment routinely provided in the wastewater treatment plant to a level which is in compliance with federal and state effluent limitations for discharge into a watercourse. 
Building sewer means a sewer conveying wastewater from the premises of a user to the wastewater facilities. 
City's engineer means SCL Engineering or such other company or person as may from time to time be duly appointed by the city. 
Cooling water means the water discharges from any use such as air conditioning, cooling or refrigeration, or to which the only pollutant added is heat. 
Domestic waste means waterborne wastes normally discharged into the sanitary conveniences of dwellings (including apartments, hotels and motels), office buildings, factories and institutions, that are free of stormwater, surface water, and industrial wastes; concentrations for five-day 20 degrees C BOD or CBOD and total suspended solids shall not exceed 200 ppm (mg/l) and ammonia (ammonia-nitrogen) shall not exceed 25 ppm (mg/l) as nitrogen. 
Floatable grease means grease, oil or fat in a physical state such that it will separate or stratify by gravity in water. 
Grease means fatty acids, soaps, fats, waxes, petroleum products, oil and any material which is extractable by hexane or Freon solvent from an acidified sample and which is not volatilized during evaporation of the solvent. 
Industrial user means a person who discharges industrial waste, provided that schools, churches and day care centers shall not be considered to be industrial users for the purpose of this article. 
Industrial waste means the waterborne solids, liquids, and/or gaseous wastes (including cooling water), excluding domestic waste, resulting from any industrial, manufacturing, trade, business, commercial, or food processing operation or process, or from the development of any natural resource, or any mixture of such solids, liquids or wastes with water, stormwater or domestic waste. 
Interference means any discharge of wastewater into a sanitary sewer system which, alone or in conjunction with a discharge or discharges from other sources, inhibits or disrupts the wastewater treatment plant, its treatment processes and operations, or its sludge processes, use or disposal, and therefore causes or contributes to causing a violation of any federal, state or local regulation or statute applicable to the city or its wastewater treatment plant. 
mgd means million gallons per day. 
Milligrams per liter (mg/l) means a weight-to-volume ratio; the milligrams per liter value multiplied by the factors 8.337 (pounds per gallon of water) is equivalent to pounds of constituent per million gallons of water. The term "milligrams per liter (mg/l)" is the same as parts per million (ppm) for wastewater. 
National categorical pretreatment standard or pretreatment standard or federal categorical pretreatment standard means any regulation containing pollutant discharge limits promulgated by the EPA in accordance with Section 307(b) and (c) of the Federal Clean Water Act which applies to a specific category of industrial users. 
National pollution discharge elimination system or NPDES permit means a permit issued pursuant to Section 402 of the Federal Clean Water Act. 
Pass through means a discharge that exits the city's wastewater treatment plant into a watercourse in quantities or concentrations which, alone or in conjunction with a discharge or discharges from other sources, causes or contributes to causing a violation of any federal, state or local regulation or statute applicable to the city or its wastewater treatment plant. 
Pollutant means any substance or material in any form that may degrade the quality of the effluent from treatment facilities, may cause violation of the permit, may cause degradation of water quality in the receiving stream, may cause damage to the sanitary sewer system, or may endanger public health in any manner. 
ppb means parts per billion, weight-to-weight ratio, equivalent to micrograms per liter; the ppb value multiplied by a factor of 8.337 shall be equivalent to pounds per billion gallons of water. 
ppm means parts per million, weight-to-weight ratio, equivalent to milligrams per liter; the ppm value multiplied by a factor of 8.337 shall be equivalent to pounds per million gallons of water. 
Pretreatment or treatment means the reduction of the amount of pollutants, the elimination of pollutants, or the alteration of the nature of pollutant properties in wastewater to a less harmful state prior to or in lieu of discharging or otherwise introducing such pollutants into the wastewater facilities. 
Sanitary sewer means a public sewer which carries wastewater and/or industrial wastes, and to which stormwater, surface water, and groundwater is not intentionally admitted. 
Sanitary sewer system means all facilities owned or operated by the city for collecting, conveying, pumping, treating, and discharging sewage to the wastewater treatment plant, as well as any extensions of or additions to these facilities that the city may construct, acquire or operate from time to time. 
Significant industrial user means any industry which discharges to the city's wastewater facilities that: 
(1)	Is subject to National Categorical Pretreatment Standards; 
(2)	Discharges a nondomestic waste stream of 25,000 gallons per day (0.025 mgd) or more; 
(3)	Contributes a nondomestic waste stream which makes up five percent or more of the average dry weather hydraulic or organic capacity of the wastewater facilities; or 
(4)	Has a reasonable potential, in the opinion of the commission, to adversely affect the city's wastewater facilities whether by inhibition, pass through of pollutants, sludge contamination or endangerment of personnel of the wastewater facilities or any other means. 
Standard methods means the laboratory procedures set forth in the latest edition, at the time of analysis, of "Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater," as prepared, approved, and published jointly by the American Public Health Association, the American Water Works Association and the Federation of Sewage and Industrial Wastes Association. 
Stormwater means that portion of the rainfall that is drained into any sanitary or stormwater sewer. 
TCEQ means the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality and any of its predecessor or successor agencies. 
Trap means a device designed to skim, settle or otherwise remove grease, oil, sand, flammable wastes or other harmful substances. 
User means any person who has a building sewer connected to the city's sewer, or contributes, causes or permits the contribution of wastewater into the city's wastewater facilities, including those who discharge holding tank waste into the wastewater facilities. 
Wastewater means the liquid and water-carried industrial or domestic wastes from dwellings, commercial buildings, industrial facilities, and institutions, together with any groundwater, surface water, and stormwater that may be present, whether treated or untreated, which is contributed or discharged into or permitted to enter the city's sanitary sewer system. 
Wastewater facilities means all city-owned equipment, devices and structures used for receiving, collecting, pumping and disposing of sewage, sludges and residues. 
Wastewater treatment plant means any city facilities, devices and structures used for receiving, processing and treating wastewater, industrial waste and sludges from the sanitary sewers. 
(Code 1996, § 11.602; Ord. No. 2006-01, 4-18-2006)  
Sec. 58-112. - Prohibited discharges. 
(a)	No user shall contribute or cause to be contributed, directly or indirectly, any pollutant or wastewater which will interfere with the operation or performance of the wastewater facilities. No user shall contribute any of the following to any sanitary sewer: 
(1)	Any wastewater with concentrations of any substances above the limits as set by federal, state or local regulations. 
(2)	Any wastewater with concentrations of any substances prohibited by federal, state or local regulations. 
(3)	Any substance that is not amenable to treatment or reduction to acceptable levels by process units or that would cause interference or pass through at the wastewater treatment plant or is amenable to treatment only to such a degree that the wastewater treatment plant's effluent cannot meet the requirements of agencies having jurisdiction over discharge to the receiving stream. 
(4)	Any wastewater discharged at rates or times in excess of flow regulation or equalization requirements as determined from time to time by the city. 
(5)	Any wastewater containing any fats, wax, grease, or oil, whether emulsified or not, in excess of 100 mg/l or containing substances which may solidify or become viscous between 32 and 120 degrees Fahrenheit. These prohibitions include, but are not limited to: 
a.	Floatable grease of any origin; and 
b.	Free or emulsified grease of petroleum or mineral origin, or both, including, but not limited to: 
1.	Cooling or quenching oil; 
2.	Lubrication oil; 
3.	Cutting oil; or 
4.	Nonsaponifiable oil. 
(6)	Any inflows or infiltration, including, but not limited to, stormwater, groundwater, roof runoff, subsurface drainage, noncontact cooling water or from sources such as downspouts, yard drains, yard fountains or ponds, swimming pools or lawn sprinklers. 
(7)	Any substance which will cause the wastewater treatment plant to violate the NPDES and/or Texas Commission on Environmental Quality's permit or the receiving water quality standards. 
(8)	Any liquid having a temperature higher than 120 degrees Fahrenheit. 
(9)	Any solids, liquids or gases which by themselves or by interaction with other substances may cause fire or explosion hazards, or in any other way is injurious to persons, property or the operator of the sewage disposal works. 
(10)	Any solids, slurries, or viscous substances of such character as to be capable of causing obstruction to the flow in sewers or other interference with the proper operation of the sewage works, such as ashes, cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, feathers, tar, plastics, wood, whole blood, hair and fleshings, entrails, lime slurry, lime residues, slops, chemical residues, paint residues or bulk solids. 
(11)	Any noxious or malodorous substance, except human excretions, which either singly or by interaction with other substances is capable of causing objectionable odors or hazard to life; or forms of solids in concentrations exceeding limits established in this article or creates any other condition deleterious to structures or treatment processes; or requires unusual provisions, alteration or expense to handle such materials. 
(12)	Any waters or wastes having a pH lower than 5.5 or higher than 9.5 or having any corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazards to structures, equipment or personnel of the sewage disposal works. 
(13)	Any wastes or waters containing suspended or dissolved solids of such character and quantity that unusual attention or expense is required to handle such materials at the sewage treatment facility or in the public sewage works. 
(14)	Any waters or wastes containing toxic or poisonous substances such as plating or wastes from heat treating processes in sufficient quantity to injure or interfere with any sewage treatment process, to constitute a hazard to humans or animals, or to create any hazard in the receiving waters of the sewage treatment plant. 
(15)	Any cyanide in concentrations greater than 1.0 mg/l as CN. 
(16)	Any hexavalent chromium in concentrations greater than 1.0 mg/l. 
(17)	Any trivalent chromium in concentrations greater than 3.0 mg/l. 
(18)	Any copper in concentrations greater than 1.0 mg/l. 
(19)	Any nickel in concentrations greater than 1.0 mg/l. 
(20)	Any cadmium in concentrations greater than 0.5 mg/l. 
(21)	Any zinc in concentrations greater than 1.0 mg/l. 
(22)	Any phenols in concentrations greater than 10 mg/l. 
(23)	Any iron in concentrations greater than 5.0 mg/l. 
(24)	Any tin in concentrations greater than 1.0 mg/l. 
(25)	Any arsenic in concentrations greater than 0.05 mg/l. 
(26)	Any barium in concentrations greater than 5.0 mg/l. 
(27)	Any boron in concentrations greater than 0.5 mg/l. 
(28)	Any lead in concentrations greater than 1.0 mg/l. 
(29)	Any manganese in concentrations greater than 1.0 mg/l. 
(30)	Any mercury in concentrations greater than 0.005 mg/l. 
(31)	Any radioactive wastes in concentrations greater than allowable releases specified by current United States Bureau of Standards Handbooks dealing with the handling and release of radioactivity and radioactive substances. 
(32)	Except in quantities or concentrations or with provisions as stipulated herein, it shall be unlawful for any person, corporation or individual to discharge waters or wastes to the sanitary sewer containing: 
a.	Cyanides or cyanogens compounds capable of liberation hydrocyanic gas or acidification in excess of one-half mg/l as CN in the wastes from any outlet into the public sewers. 
b.	Materials which exert or cause: 
1.	Unusual concentrations of solids or composition; 
2.	Excessive discoloration; 
3.	Unusual BOD or an immediate oxygen demand; 
4.	High hydrogen sulfide content; or 
5.	Unusual flow and concentration. 
(b)	The commission may add or delete pollutants and/or substances to be controlled or the city may modify specific concentrations as necessary to comply with federal, state and local regulations or to protect the treatment facilities and the public health and the environment. 
(Code 1996, § 11.603; Ord. No. 2006-01, 4-18-2006)  
Sec. 58-113. - Supervision. 
If the city or its designated representative determines that a discharge or a proposed discharge into the wastewater facilities may deleteriously affect the wastewater facilities or receiving waters, or create a hazard to life or health, or create a public nuisance, it may require any one or more of the following: 
(1)	Require such user to dispose of such waste otherwise and prevent it from entering the system; 
(2)	Require pretreatment to an acceptable condition for discharge into the wastewater facilities; and 
(3)	Exercise control over the quantities and rates of discharge. 
(Code 1996, § 11.604; Ord. No. 2006-01, 4-18-2006)  
Sec. 58-114. - Permits. 
(a)	Generally. An industrial waste permit is required for any industrial user that, in the opinion of the city, contributes or could contribute industrial waste to the sanitary sewer system. All industrial users, upon request by the city, shall submit to the city an industrial waste permit application. 
(b)	Permit application. The permit application shall include the following information and shall be submitted within 30 days of request from the city: 
(1)	Application fee. A fee as provided for in the fee schedule shall accompany the permit application. 
(2)	Industrial waste permit application. An example of the industrial waste permit application form is located in Appendix A attached to Ordinance 2006-01 adopted April 18, 2006, on file in the office of the city secretary. 
(3)	Inspection and testing. At the discretion of the city, inspection and testing may be required or performed by the city's personnel and/or other qualified personnel whose services are retained by the city. If inspection and testing are required, the applicant shall be required to pay for all such additional costs. The applicant shall not be issued an industrial waste permit if its discharge fails to meet applicable standards or requirements. 
(c)	City review of permit application. Within 30 days, the city will respond to the applicant. If the city determines that no additional information is required and the application is otherwise satisfactory, the city will send the applicant a letter stating that the application is complete. 
(d)	Permit issuance and conditions. At such time that all information requested of the applicant has been submitted and reviewed and found to be satisfactory by the city, the city will then send the applicant a letter stating that the application is complete. Following the review of the permit application and providing the applicant has met all of the terms as outlined herein, the city will issue the user an industrial waste permit which is valid for a period of one year from the date of issuance. The permit shall be expressly subject to all provisions of this article and all other applicable ordinances or regulations. The permit may be subject to but not limited to the following requirements or conditions: 
(1)	User charges and surcharges as adopted and revised from time to time by the city. 
(2)	Average and maximum concentrations, characteristics, or constituents of the user's wastewater discharge into the sanitary sewer system. 
(3)	Limits on the rate and time of discharge or requirements for flow regulation or equalization. 
(4)	Regulations for installation of inspection and sampling facilities which allow the city access to such facilities at the user's expense. 
(5)	Regulations relating to pretreatment requirements. 
(6)	Regulations for monitoring programs, which may include sampling locations, frequency and method of sampling, number, types and standards of tests, and reporting schedule. 
(7)	Requirements for the submission of technical reports or discharge reports. 
(8)	Requirements for the maintenance of the user's records relating to wastewater discharge and affording the city access thereto. 
(9)	Other conditions as deemed appropriate by the city to ensure compliance with this article. 
(e)	Permit compliance. 
(1)	Annual report. A report shall be filed annually by all industrial waste permittees. The report, to be made upon a form provided by the city, shall state that the permittee has not made any change in the operation of its business which will, within the term of the permit, increase the strength, volume or any other characteristic of the permittee's discharge into the sanitary sewer system. If the permittee has made any changes in its operations, then the permittee shall describe the changes in the annual report. 
(2)	Notification to city of change in discharge. A permittee which proposes to change its industrial process in such a manner as to cause any change in the quantity or quality of its discharge into the sanitary sewer system shall notify the city at least 60 days prior to such change. 
(3)	Accidental discharge. Each permittee shall provide protection from accidental discharge of prohibited materials or other wastes regulated by this article. The permittee shall make available copies of this article and other wastewater information and notices furnished by the city to all employees and agents. A notice shall be displayed in clear view for all employees and agents of the permittee regarding who to call in case of an accidental discharge in excess of the limits authorized by the permit. The permittee or its employees or agents shall immediately notify the city upon accidental discharge into the sanitary sewer system. This notification shall be followed within 15 days of the date of the occurrence by a detailed written statement describing the causes of the accidental discharge, the duration of the discharge, the estimated quantity in gallons that was accidentally discharged, the action taken by the permittee and the measures being taken to prevent future occurrence. Such notification will not relieve the permittee of liability for any expense, loss, or damage to the sanitary sewer system, or for any fines imposed on enforcement action pursuant to this occurrence. 
(4)	Change of ownership or location of discharge. Industrial waste permits may neither be assigned nor transferred to a new discharge location. Whenever a person other than the permittee becomes the user at a permitted establishment, or whenever there is a change in discharge location, a new application for a permit shall be made. A violation of this subsection shall be grounds for suspension or revocation of the permit. 
(5)	Renewal of permit. The permittee shall file an application for renewal 60 days prior to the annual expiration date. A fee as provided for in the fee schedule shall accompany the permit renewal application. All testing, as may be required as part of the permit application, shall be at the expense of the applicant. Any such renewal shall be valid for a period of one year. 
(6)	Change in permit conditions. The city may change the conditions or user charges of any permit from time to time, as circumstances or laws or regulations enacted by the state or governmental agency may require. 
(f)	Permit denial. Upon receipt of an application for an industrial waste permit, the city shall issue or deny such permit. If such permit is denied, the city shall, within 45 days, notify the applicant of such denial and state the reasons for such denial in writing by certified mail. If the applicant still desires to obtain a permit, the applicant shall, within 30 days of such notice, revise the application to comply with the reasons for the denial as stated in the city's letter of denial. 
(g)	Violations and penalties. The following are considered violators of this article: 
(1)	An industrial user who is required by this article to obtain an industrial waste permit to be connected to the sanitary sewer system, but connects to the sanitary sewer system without obtaining a valid industrial waste permit; or 
(2)	A permittee who violates any provision included in its industrial waste permit or this article. 
(Code 1996, § 11.605; Ord. No. 2006-01, 4-18-2006)  
Sec. 58-115. - Pretreatment. 
(a)	The owner of premises from which industrial waste is discharged shall provide grease and sand traps for the proper handling of liquid wastes containing grease or sand. The traps must be of a type and capacity approved by the city to adequately handle the waste and must be located so that they are easily accessible for cleaning, inspection and monitoring by the city. 
(b)	When pretreatment of waste is required by the city as a condition for acceptance of the waste into the city's sanitary sewer, the owner of the premises from which the waste is discharged shall plan, construct, operate and maintain waste treatment facilities in an efficient manner at his sole cost and expense. In the event that the installation of pretreatment facilities is necessary for a user to meet applicable federal and state standards, the city shall establish and enforce deadlines for the installation of such facilities. The city and other authorized representatives or employees of the city may conduct an inspection of such facilities as hereinafter set forth. When pretreatment of waste is required by the city as a condition for acceptance of the waste into the city's sanitary sewer, the owner of the premises from which the waste is discharged shall not allow waste to bypass the waste treatment facilities. 
(c)	No owner or operator of premises from which industrial waste is discharged shall allow the use of extraneous water intermixed for the purpose of diluting the concentration of waste. 
(Code 1996, § 11.606; Ord. No. 2006-01, 4-18-2006)  
Sec. 58-116. - Inspection chambers. 
(a)	An industrial user that discharges waste into the city's sanitary sewer or wastewater facilities shall provide, at his sole cost and expense, an inspection manhole or chamber in an accessible location on the premises from which such waste is discharged. 
(b)	An inspection manhole or chamber must be: 
(1)	Located reasonably near the outlet of each sewer, drain, pipe, or channel that connects with the sanitary sewer or wastewater facility; 
(2)	Designed and constructed to prevent infiltration by groundwater and surface water; and 
(3)	Maintained so that a person may easily and safely measure volume and obtain flow samples. 
(c)	Before beginning construction of an inspection manhole or chamber, an industrial user shall submit plans to the city for review and approval to ensure compliance with this section. Plans must include the sewage metering device if one is to be installed. 
(Code 1996, § 11.607; Ord. No. 2006-01, 4-18-2006)  
Sec. 58-117. - Sampling of waste. 
(a)	The city is authorized to obtain or require routinely scheduled samples of waste discharges from users as often as necessary to adequately monitor and control the discharges. In the event the city obtains or requires such samples, the city or the user, as appropriate, in order to determine and report the wastewater characteristics of the samples, shall retain the services of a commercial laboratory to perform such services in accordance with analytical methods found in 40 CFR 136, or any other analytical method approved or accepted by the Environmental Protection Agency for wastewater analysis. The user shall pay all costs associated with sample collection and laboratory services. Should the user's discharge be in violation of this article, the user shall pay all costs, including, but not limited to, legal and engineering fees associated with sample collection and laboratory services and the enforcement of this article. These costs shall be in addition to any fees assessed in connection with the normal inspection of grease and sand traps conducted by the city. 
(b)	Each user subject to federal categorical pretreatment standards shall submit a copy of any self-monitoring reports as required by 40 CFR 403.12 to the city. 
(c)	The city may take samples of waste discharges from users as often as is necessary to adequately monitor and control the discharges. The cost of such sampling and laboratory analysis shall be paid as set forth in section 58-121. 
(d)	Samples may be taken manually or by use of mechanical equipment at the city's discretion. Analytical methods found in 40 CFR 136, or any other analytical method approved or accepted by the Environmental Protection Agency for wastewater analysis laboratory procedures shall be used for determining concentrations of industrial waste. The user may be requested by the city to install and maintain monitoring equipment, and shall be required to pay all costs of same. 
(Code 1996, § 11.608; Ord. No. 2006-01, 4-18-2006)  
Sec. 58-118. - Flow metering equipment. 
The city may require installation of flow meters for industrial users at the user's expense. The user shall be responsible for the operation, maintenance and accuracy of the flow meters. 
(Code 1996, § 11.609; Ord. No. 2006-01, 4-18-2006)  
Sec. 58-119. - Right of entry. 
The city and other authorized representatives or employees of the city, bearing proper credentials and identification, shall be permitted to enter immediately upon any premises in which a wastewater source is located, or in which any records required to be maintained pursuant to this article are located, and may at reasonable times have access to and copy any records, and conduct any inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, or testing necessary to enforce this article. Reasonable times shall mean any time when waste is being discharged or any time during normal operating hours. 
(Code 1996, § 11.610; Ord. No. 2006-01, 4-18-2006)  
Sec. 58-120. - Trade secrets. 
All information and data relating to a user which is obtained from reports, questionnaires, monitoring programs or inspection shall be available to the public without restriction unless the user specifically requests that specific information be withheld and such user is able to demonstrate to the satisfaction of the city that the release of such information to the general public would give a business advantage to competitors who do not otherwise have this information. In such case, the city will use its best efforts to prevent the release of such information to the general public. 
(Code 1996, § 11.611; Ord. No. 2006-01, 4-18-2006)  
Sec. 58-121. - Fees. 
(a)	It is the purpose of this section to provide for the recovery of costs from users of the city's wastewater facilities related to the implementation of the programs established herein. The applicable charges or fees shall be set forth by the city and may be revised from time to time. 
(b)	The city may adopt any one or more of the following charges and fees: 
(1)	Fees for reimbursement of costs of setting up and operating the city's pretreatment program; 
(2)	Fees for monitoring, inspections and surveillance procedures; 
(3)	Fees for reviewing accidental discharge procedures and construction; 
(4)	Fees for removal (by the city) of pollutants otherwise subject to national categorical pretreatment standards; and 
(5)	Other fees as the city may deem necessary to carry out the requirements contained herein. 
(Code 1996, § 11.612; Ord. No. 2006-01, 4-18-2006)  
Sec. 58-122. - Notification of violation. 
Whenever the city finds that any user has violated or is violating this article, the city shall serve notice, either personally or by certified mail, return receipt requested, upon such person stating the nature of the violation. Within 15 days of service of such notice, a plan for satisfactory correction thereof shall be submitted to the city by such user; provided, however, upon notification of the violation user shall use its best efforts to immediately cease all activities which cause or contribute to the violation. If such a plan is not submitted, or if such violation is not corrected within such 15-day period, unless the user has perfected his right to review pursuant to section 58-123, the city shall proceed with enforcement pursuant to section 58-127; provided, however, nothing contained in this section or any other section of this article shall prevent the city or the commission from taking action in an emergency situation pursuant to section 58-124. No prior notice shall be required for the imposition of the fine described in section 58-126, if such fine is assessed for a violation of this section. 
(Code 1996, § 11.613; Ord. No. 2006-01, 4-18-2006)  
Sec. 58-123. - Review. 
Any user objecting to a finding by the city of a violation of this article shall have the right as set forth herein to a hearing before the city. In the event such user disagrees with the city's finding of such violation, the user shall, within 15 days of service of such notice by the city, serve notice by certified mail, return receipt requested, on the city, that such user disagrees with the city's finding and, further, that such user requests a hearing before the city. Such hearing shall be scheduled and conducted within 45 calendar days following the date of user's service of notice on the city. At such hearing, both sides will be allowed to present such testimony as is reasonably necessary to present a clear understanding of the contested issues. The mayor, or other designated city representative in the absence of the mayor, shall be the presiding officer and may at his discretion request other professional opinions prior to the city's rendering a decision on the matter of review. 
(Code 1996, § 11.614; Ord. No. 2006-01, 4-18-2006)  
Sec. 58-124. - Emergency relief. 
Notwithstanding anything contained herein to the contrary, the city may immediately suspend water supply and wastewater treatment service to a user when such suspension is necessary, in the opinion of the city, in order to stop or prevent an actual or threatened discharge that presents an imminent and/or substantial danger to the health or welfare of persons, the environment, or the city's wastewater facilities or the water treatment plant that causes, or would cause, the city to violate any of the terms of the NPDES permit or state commission on environmental quality permit. The city may immediately suspend the water supply and wastewater service of a user when such suspension is necessary, in the opinion of the city, to prevent contamination of sludge and effluent from the wastewater treatment plant. The city shall reinstate the water supply and wastewater service upon clear and convincing proof by the user of the elimination of the noncomplying discharge. Such disconnection and reconnection shall be at the expense of the user. The city may permanently disconnect any user who, in the city's sole discretion, exhibits a history of flagrant or habitual violation of this article. 
(Code 1996, § 11.615; Ord. No. 2006-01, 4-18-2006)  
Sec. 58-125. - Notice. 
Notice to the city required in this article shall be served at the following address: 
City of Galena Park 
2000 Clinton Drive 
Galena Park, Texas 77547 
(Code 1996, § 11.616; Ord. No. 2006-01, 4-18-2006)  
Sec. 58-126. - Penalty for violation. 
Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall become liable to the city for any expense, loss or damage occasioned by the city by reason of such violation. 
(Code 1996, § 11.617; Ord. No. 2006-01, 4-18-2006)  
Sec. 58-127. - Enforcement. 
Any one or more of the following remedies may be utilized by the city to abate or prevent any violation of this article: 
(1)	Disconnection and sealing of sanitary sewer connection and termination of water supply to the user. 
(2)	Suspension or revocation of a user's industrial waste permit. 
(3)	The city may and is hereby authorized to: 
a.	File suit in a court of competent jurisdiction to secure appropriate judicial relief, including, but not limited to, injunctive relief and/or the penalty provided in section 58-126 for the violation by such user of the provisions of this article. 
b.	Seek a resolution of the city authorizing the filing of a lawsuit under the provision of the Texas Water Code § 26.124 or pursuant to other valid authority. 
(4)	A user found in violation of this article shall be liable to the city for all expenses incurred by the city, including, but not limited to, legal and engineering fees, in establishing the violation and resolving the cause of the violation. These costs shall be in addition to any fees assessed in connection with the normal inspection of grease and sand traps conducted by the city. 
(5)	A user found in violation of this article that causes or contributes to a violation of the wastewater treatment plant of effluent parameters shall be liable to the city for all fines and expenses borne by the city, including, but not limited to, any administrative fines, legal fees, and engineering fees related to any lawsuit filed by federal, state or local authorities regarding violations by the city of effluent parameters applicable to the wastewater treatment plant. 
(6)	Where a user discharges wastewater to the sanitary sewer system leading to the wastewater treatment plant in violation of this article and such discharge causes or contributes to contamination of sludge from the wastewater treatment plant, the user shall be liable for all costs incurred by the city in disposing of the contaminated sludge over and above costs regularly incurred in sludge disposal. 
(Code 1996, § 11.618; Ord. No. 2006-01, 4-18-2006)  
Sec. 58-128. - Conflicting provisions. 
Whenever any applicable statute, regulation or permit of any state, federal or other agency having jurisdiction over the subject matter of this article is in conflict with this article, the stricter requirement shall apply, unless mandated otherwise. 
(Code 1996, § 11.619; Ord. No. 2006-01, 4-18-2006)  
Secs. 58-129—58-154. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - WATER CONSERVATION AND DROUGHT CONTINGENCY[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference— Drought contingency plans generally, Texas Water Code § 11.1272. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Secs. 58-155—58-176. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - WATER CONSERVATION PLAN 
 
Sec. 58-177. - Introduction. 
(a)	The city adopted its city Charter on April 12, 1946. The city is primarily a residential community with few commercial and industrial customers. The city has an efficient "mayor/commission form of government." The mayor is responsible to the city commission. 
(b)	The mayor has authorization to manage and control the city departments and other city functions. The water and wastewater superintendent is responsible for the operations and maintenance of the water and wastewater systems for the city. 
(c)	The city is located in the county and has the following approximate boundaries: Turkey Run Creek to the north, Federal Road to the east, Fidelity Road to the west, and the Houston Ship Channel to the south. 
(d)	The city's mission is to effectively manage the city's water supply, production and distribution system in order to meet water supply needs and to provide safe drinking water that meets or exceeds state and federal regulations; to review the design and construction of water facilities to ensure the adequacy of the water system; to meet projected growth requirements; and to identify and meet consumer needs and expectations. The city plans and executes activities necessary to provide expected quality services to the citizens, so that the opportunity to enjoy a high quality of life is afforded to all. 
(e)	The 2000 census reflected a population of 10,591, and the estimated 2008 population is 10,998 (TWDB population projection) and serves an area of 2.9 square miles (1,856 acres). The city experienced very slow growth as only 28 residential meters were installed during the last three years. The city is built out and has very limited land remaining for residential and commercial growth. 
(f)	The city serves 10,988 water and wastewater customers. 
(g)	The city receives treated surface water from the City of Houston's East Surface Water Treatment Plant located at Federal Road and Clinton Drive. The city has a ten-inch tap on the City of Houston's 96-inch distribution line which transverses Clinton Drive, the main street in the city. 
(h)	The city also has two groundwater plants with a well and booster pumps at each location. The wells are on standby and are used for emergencies and peak demands. Total capacity of both water wells is 3.67 mgd. 
(i)	The city is committed to maintaining and improving the city's water conservation plan by expanding the existing plan, expanding the educational program and following the guidelines and information provided by the Texas Water Development Board (TWDB). 
(j)	The best management practices (BMPs), all or part, that will be included in the city's water conservation plan includes mandatory elements, such as metering, system water audit, retro-fit BMPs, school educational programs and prohibition of wasting water. 
(Code 1996, § 11.721; Ord. No. 2016-03A, 8-16-2016)  
Sec. 58-178. - Goals. 
(a)	The city's water conservation plan objectives are to improve the efficiency of water use through practices and techniques that will reduce water consumption, reduce summertime usage, especially during dry weather, reduce water loss and increase water reuse. 
(b)	It is also the goal of the city to expand and improve the water conservation plan to achieve a one percent reduction per year in total gallons per capita per day (gpcd) over the next five- and ten-year periods. The one percent reduction per year is recommended by the state water conservation implementation task force. 
(c)	The city has been proactive in water conservation, as the city's consumption of 82 gpcd in 2006, 77 gpcd in 2007 and 73 gpcd in 2008 reflected a reduction of nine gpcd. This reduction exceeds the one percent recommended reduction. 
(d)	The reduction in per capita consumption is a result of a combination of conservation efforts, including the city's accounting program, water system inspection program, the water meter program, system repairs and public education. 
(e)	The five- and ten-year gpcd target goals are shown in Table 1. 
Table 1. Water Consumption Goals Based on Gallons Per Capita Per Day (gpcd) 
	Actual 	Target Goals 
Year 	2004 	2008 	2008 	2013 	2018 
Total gpcd 	85 	73 	73 	72 	70 
 
(f)	The above calculations were made by dividing the water diverted or pumped for treatment for potable use by population served. 
(Code 1996, § 11.722)

(a)	Water loss is a primary concern for the city and percent water losses and losses in gallons per capita per day (gpcd) for the last three years (2006 through 2008) are shown in Table 2.

(b)	The goal/target of the city is to reduce water loss by six percent per year over five- and ten-year periods.

Sec. 58-180. - Best management practices. 
(a)	Water consumption in the city is driven by a wide variety of domestic, commercial, industrial and institutional needs. BMPs, as recommended by the TWDB, have been developed and utilized by the city to improve water use efficiency and for programs to assist and improve the city's water customers in the efficient use of water.
